DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT SELECT COMMITTEE ON CORPORATIONS LEGISLATION

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr ACTING SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received the following message from the Senate:

INTERJECT.PARA: The Senate transmits to the House of Representatives the following Resolution which was agreed to by the Senate this day in relation to the following Bills-
Australian Securities Commission Bill 1988 Corporations Bill 1988
Securities Exchanges (Application for Membership) Fidelity Funds Contribution Bill 1988
Securities Exchanges (Membership) Fidelity Funds Contribution Bill 1988
Securities Exchanges Fidelity Funds Levy Bill 1988
National Guarantee Fund (Reportable Transactions) Levy Bill 1988
National Guarantee Fund (Participating Exchanges) Levy Bill 1988
National Guarantee Fund (Members of Participating Exchanges) Levy Bill 1988
Futures Organisations (Application for Membership) Fidelity Funds Contribution Bill 1988
Futures Organisations (Membership) Fidelity Funds Contribution Bill 1988
Futures Organisations Fidelity Funds Levy Bill 1988
Close Corporations (Liquidators' Recovery Trust Fund Contribution) Bill 1988
Close Corporations (Additional Liquidators' Recovery Trust Fund Contribution) Bill 1988:

(1) That, acknowledging that the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs has unanimously recommended that the Commonwealth should introduce comprehensive legislation to assume responsibility for all areas covered by the co-operative scheme and that a package of Bills for this purpose is now before the Senate, the Bills be referred to a select committee, to be known as the Joint Select Committee on Corporations Legislation, and the Committee inquire into and report on the Bills for the regulation of companies and the securities and futures industries with reference only to the adequacy of the proposed legislative provisions to:
(b) facilitate the performance of the securities and futures markets; and
(c) ensure adequate protection for investors in companies and the securities and futures markets;
and, in particular, report on the adequacy of the fund-raising provisions.
(2) That the Committee consist of 10 members, as follows:
(a) 2 Senators to be nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate;
(b) 2 Senators to be nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate;
(c) 1 Senator to be nominated by the Leader of the Australian Democrats;
(d) 3 members of the House of Representatives to be nominated by or on behalf of the Prime Minister; and
(e) 2 members of the House of Representatives to be nominated by the Leader of the Opposition.
(3) That the Committee may proceed to the despatch of business notwithstanding that all members have not been duly nominated and appointed and notwithstanding any vacancy.
(4) That the Committee elect as Chairman one of the members nominated by or on behalf of the Prime Minister or by the Leader of the Government in the Senate.

(5) That the Chairman of the Committee may, from time to time, appoint another member of the Committee to be the Deputy-Chairman of the Committee, and that the member so appointed act as Chairman of the Committee at any time when there is no Chairman or the Chairman is not present at a meeting of the Committee.
(6) That, in the event of the votes on any question before the Committee being equally divided, the Chairman, or the Deputy-Chairman when acting as Chairman, have a casting vote.
(7) That the quorum of the Committee be 5 members.

(8) That the Committee and any sub-committee have power to send for and examine persons, papers and records, to move from place to place, to sit in public or in private, and the Committee have leave to report from time to time its proceedings and the evidence taken and such interim recommendations it may deem fit.

(9) That the Committee have power to appoint sub-committees consisting of 3 or more of its members, and to refer to any such sub-committee any of the matters which the Committee is empowered to consider, and that the quorum of a sub-committee be all the members appointed to the sub-committee.

(10) That the Committee be provided with all necessary staff, facilities and resources and be empowered to appoint persons with specialist knowledge for the purposes of the Committee with the approval of the President.
(11) That the Committee be empowered to print from day to day such papers and evidence as may be ordered by it, and a daily Hansard be published of such proceedings as take place in public.
(12) That the Committee report to each House of the Parliament by the first day of sitting of that House in 1989.

(13) That the Committee have access to any relevant evidence and records of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs and the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs.
(14) That the Committee cease upon the dissolution or expiration of the House of Representatives.
(15) That the foregoing provisions of this Resolution, so far as they are inconsistent with the Standing Orders, have effect notwithstanding anything contained in the Standing Orders.
The Senate requests the concurrence of the House of Representatives in this Resolution.
Ordered that the message be taken into consideration forthwith.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Mr Staples) proposed:
That this House concurs in the resolution transmitted in message No. 218 of the Senate relating to the appointment of a joint select committee on corporations legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —This motion continues the farce going on in relation to the Commonwealth package on company law.
—This follows the 280 amendments.

—The 280 amendments were the last effort in relation to this. Now we have before the House a recommendation for a select committee, on very narrow terms as proposed by the Australian Democrats, on which the Government seems to have an open position. Senator Tate, who is responsible for this legislation in the Senate, said the Government was going to take a wider view of things than the motion put forward by the Democrats. Where is the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen), who is responsible for this legislation? I understand he is cruising around the Pacific or to South America or somewhere, while we are bringing before the House the most controversial attempt at constitutional reform in Australia without a referendum, the most sweeping changes in company law that affect the whole area of Australian commerce. We still cannot resolve it here, except that in debate, when the Attorney-General was sitting across the table, he indicated that there was a prospect for some changes in the plan. Where is he today when this recommendation for a committee comes back, suggesting a totally different position? I am amazed at what goes on. On top of that, while we must set up a joint committee today, on 1 November the Federal Attorney-General is going to meet with the State Attorneys-General to discuss what they think about it all. That will be another round of discussions on company law, which is completely irrelevant.

SPEECH.PARA: So we have the Federal Attorney-General meeting the State Attorneys-General on 1 November. In the House we are establishing a joint committee to discuss the Bills. In the Senate the Minister who introduced the matter completely contradicted what the Attorney-General had said in this House in relation to these matters. Where is the Australian Labor Party in relation to company law? Last time the Government had the legislation in the House it bombed down 280 amendments the night before the debate and wondered why it took so long to get through the House. This is another example of inadequate consultation with the public of Australia.

I will quote briefly from an address by one of the 36 members of the consultative group who advised the Government on this matter. Honourable members took so much interest in the company law debate on the last occasion that they will not need to have it repeated. Mr Beerworth, who was one of the 12 who advised the Government, said in relation to consultation:

I worked in Canberra for 3 years, and I practised law for over 20. I must tell you that my heart sinks whenever a government promises consultation because that word does not have its dictionary meaning in government circles. Consultation there means the appearance of consultation or the establishment of a procedure designed to suggest consultation.

I have no doubt that the individual Ministers who talk sincerely about consultation mean what they say at the time they say it. The problem is that they are not personally involved and the consultative process is delegated away.
In this case-
referring to company law-
the Attorney asked prominent identities to form a small steering committee and also asked other individuals, some representative of relevant organisations, to form a wider consultative committee.

I was invited to join that consultative committee and it may be instructive if I relay my experience to you. The whole committee met together once only in December last year for about 3 hours. We were given some simple proposals for reform and told that we would be broken down into sub-committees.

Little happened for 3 months and I volunteered to serve on two sub-committees, legal and securities. The securities sub-committee has met twice. On the first occasion, we had no idea that the draft legislation would be shortly forthcoming and we had no idea of its form or likely content (other than that some of the issues in a discussion paper would be dealt with). We amiably decided to form a series of sub-committees to handle the real work.

I was unable to attend the first meeting of the legal committee but have attended all others. It has met more consistently, but at an early stage we were told that we would not consider any detail or individual sections of the legislation because the amount involved was simply too vast. I thought that was an extraordinary approach for a bunch of prominent lawyers.

Hear, hear! That is not bad. It came from Bill Beerworth, one of the 12 advisers on the steering committee that advised the Attorney-General on this package. That is what he had to say about the consultation process that took place. Now that Government proposes to establish a committee at the end of October to report to the House on the first occasion it meets in February. What sort of consultation will take place on this in Australia in December and January?

TALK.START.PARA: —None.

—The answer is none. The honourable member for Isaacs admits that; he has owned up. He can see how much work will be done between December and January. The committee will come back here in February and say, `We just did not have time'. What a joke! This is amazing handling of significant legislation before the House. The Government proposes to put up long technical Bills at the last minute before the Christmas break. The Government proposes, in 16 Acts of Parliament, to take over company law when it is very doubtful that it has the constitutional powers to do so. One Government member said that he did not think that members of the proposed committee would do much work over Christmas. I quote again from Mr Beerworth regarding the constitutionality of the legislation. Mr Beerworth is a prominent lawyer and a former senior partner in one of the senior law firms in Sydney. He is now the Executive Director of Wardley Australia Ltd, whose name is well known to all Western Australians. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: My own concerns are strongest in this constitutional area. I frankly regard it as close to irresponsible for the Commonwealth to attempt to take over such an important part of corporate and commercial life when its power to do so is unclear.
That is not a bad statement from one of the Government's 12 advisers on the steering committee. He continued:

The difficulties will not be simply brushed away by the one contrived case which the supporters of the legislation assert will be quickly brought on. For those of you who are lawyers, and particularly constitutional lawyers, you will know that it may take 5 or 6 or even 10 cases before the proper ambit of the Commonwealth's jurisdiction in this area has been settled by the High Court. This process may take a number of years. The problem is that in the meantime, business must carry on and may find out retrospectively that it has followed a Commonwealth (or a State) law which is declared void years later.

What an imposition on business which has opposed sweeping changes not only to the administration of company law in Australia but also detailed changes to company law itself, as these Bills provide, when the constitutional powers under which the Government proposes to act are very questionable. I am quoting here from the remarks of one of the Government's advisers. One really wonders what takes place in relation to these matters. Mr Beerworth continued:

That is an absurd situation and not one which should obtain in a country with our traditions. The uncertainty and cost to business should not be underestimated, and we are not only merely talking about the act of incorporation: We are talking about all matters affecting the organisation, administration and operation of a company in Australia.

The third problem area is that of administration. Whilst an asserted need for more certainty and uniformity in administration was the genesis of the Commonwealth's move, those are the last attributes which will be achieved by this legislation.
There has been talk of reaching an accommodation with the States-
I referred before to the meeting on 1 November-

about the use of their existing administration, and I am assured that a mysterious `corporate plan' will somehow magically bring about a better level of administration than under the present cooperative scheme.

Hear, hear! Here we have one of the 12 advisers saying that this new Commonwealth administration will involve some mysterious corporate plan that `will somehow magically bring about a better level of administration'. When the Government's own supporters are saying such things, surely the Government must think about it. Mr Beerworth continued:

But the administration of this scheme has not been clearly thought out and no accommodation has been reached with the States. Nor is it likely to be given the adversarial approach the Commonwealth has consistently taken during the last year or so.

That is quite a bucket from one of the Government's own advisers. That is from a person who has pretty high standing within the corporate world in Australia. Mr Beerworth is well known in all States. He is a person who has been around for a while.

With all these uncertainties before us there is a constitutional doubt. There is a mixture of a number of Government versions. There is the version of the Attorney-General; there is Senator Tate's version; and now there is the version of this Committee. The Government has appointed a committee to look at highly controversial company law in November, December and January. Honourable members can imagine how much work goes on over that period of the year. On top of all this, while all this has been going on, on 1 November the Commonwealth Attorney-General will meet the State Attorneys-General to see whether some other plan of cooperation can be reached. It is no wonder that 280 amendments were needed to clean up the Bills the first time. The Government will need 500 amendments next time to clean up the legislation after the 1 November meeting if an accommodation is to be reached with the States in relation to this very technical area.

I must say that the proposal brought forward in the House has limited appeal. We do not support a close look at the narrow areas of company reform contained in this Bill; we want to look at the legislation as it affects wider Australia. We want to ensure that this Committee travels to all capital cities; that it has the views of people who live in Perth, Adelaide, Hobart and Brisbane-not just the people in Pitt Street and Collins Street, but the wider commercial levels in Australia. This legislation affects everyone in this nation-not just a few people who have a vested interest in centralising power, which is basically what the legislation is all about. We want to ensure that the matters which have been brought forward concern only the administration of company law-as we were told in their initial presentation. However, when we look at the 16 Bills concerned we see that there are wide areas involving law reform. These are areas about which prominent people outside this place have raised very grave questions. Professor Austin, of Sydney University, has gone on record about the technical review of prospectuses as it relates to these Bills. He claims that there are very grave doubts about the proposals. But in the Attorney-General's presentation there was no mention of change to company law. That is rubbish. That is blatantly untrue. This committee is to be set up at the behest of the Democrats so that they can look at the technical aspects of the legislation. As the honourable member has so rightly said: what is going to happen in December and January?

The Opposition will not be supporting the establishment of this Committee. Our proposal is for a committee to take a wider view of the legislation and, as a consequence, we will not support the proposal before the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Staples The Hon P.R.

TALKER.NAME: Mr STAPLES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Housing and Aged Care)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I was disappointed by the cheap shots of the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore) when he spoke earlier about the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) cruising around. I think he said he was on a cruise. The honourable member knows that is not a fact. If he does not, he should. The fact is that the Attorney-General is travelling to various countries working on extradition treaties, which I thought might have been important to honourable members opposite. But no, they have to rely upon a few cheap shots-the same old stuff. Right at the beginning of this debate they showed that they are very short on substance, as they are in all of their policy areas, even on this issue, an issue with which one would think they would be far more familiar and comfortable, but that is not the case.

SPEECH.PARA: On 25 May of this year the Attorney-General introduced a package of Bills comprising national companies legislation, which will replace the existing complementary State-Commonwealth legislation that is based on a cooperative scheme. On 28 September of this year the Attorney-General introduced Government amendments to the Bills. When the Attorney-General introduced the Bills he said they would lie on the table over the winter recess for public examination and comment, and the amendments reflect those comments. On 29 September the package was passed in the House of Representatives and on 14 October it was introduced into the Senate. Before the second reading debate Senator Macklin moved a motion that the Bills be referred to a joint select committee that would examine them. That motion is now before this House because the committee is to be a joint committee.

The Government supported the motion for the following reasons: The committee will facilitate parliamentary consideration of the Bills; there are some significant reforms in the Bills and the committee will enable informed review and analysis; the membership of that committee will enable fair and equitable representation by the Government, the Opposition and the Senate; and the reporting date of the first sitting day of next year will ensure that there is minimum time for uncertainty for the business investors which a long, drawn out inquiry, as is proposed by the Opposition, would bring about, but that is again symptomatic of the way in which it handled the economy as well as most other matters when it was in government.

The terms of reference directed that the fundamental objectives of the legislation will not permit a wide ranging inquiry. On this point the terms of reference acknowledged the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs report of April 1987, which concluded that the Commonwealth should move to introduce comprehensive legislation in the field of companies and securities.

The Opposition supports the idea of a reference to a committee, but opposes the terms of reference. Senator Hill, an Opposition senator, moved an amendment to substitute much broader terms of reference, in particular a term of reference that would permit the re-examination of the issue of whether the Commonwealth should introduce legislation in this area and whether it has any constitutional authority. On the point of whether the Commonwealth should legislate, the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, in its report on the role of Parliament and the national companies scheme-Senator Hill was on that Committee and he has since said that the Committee may have been wrong-unanimously concluded that the Commonwealth should introduce comprehensive legislation. The business community, of which the honourable member for Ryan sees himself being a prominent member, gave evidence to that Committee and was in favour of the Commonwealth legislating. The Business Council of Australia, the Company Directors Association of Australia, the Metal Trades Industry Association of Australia, the Australian Merchant Bankers Association and the Life Insurance Federation of Australia have all supported it. Business has remained strongly in support of the Commonwealth legislative initiatives. The problem with the present scheme is the lack of parliamentary accountability and ministerial responsibility. Under the cooperative scheme no parliament has any control over the legislation but the Commonwealth legislation will rectify this. The Opposition wants to canvass whether the States should have legislative responsibility.

In December last year the Attorney-General put a split scheme to the States. They unanimously rejected that proposal. At that time the honourable member for Ryan also strongly opposed the proposal. He now says he favours a split scheme approach. Last year Senator Hill from the Opposition in the Senate supported the concept of Commonwealth legislation as part of a Senate committee. This year he thinks he made a mistake. What will the Opposition's position be next week? The Attorney-General is concerned that the legislation be properly examined, but he also believes that it is time to replace the current scheme which the Senate committee concluded had `outlived its usefulness'.

The sooner the Opposition realises what is really going on in corporate Australia, the better it will be for it. The reality is that this provides a single national code of regulation for Australian companies. It is a major, long overdue step in streamlining and modernising Australia's legal and corporate system. We will have one national framework in one national market. That is the difference between the dark old days of the Fraser years and the times before that, and what Australia has to deal with today.

We, in this Government, have been building a springboard for Australian companies to intervene and operate in global markets. We can see that it has been of tremendous benefit to Australia. We, as a country, as an economy, as a society, are now in a position to take full advantage of the dynamic economy that this Government has fostered. For years Australia's leading companies have been crying out for this reform to get rid of the unnecessary duplication, the cost barriers to trade, and outmoded, anachronistic controls that have been in place under the decades of Liberal and National Party government. Only this Government has had the political will to match the political vision, to achieve and to bring forward legislation such as this, unlike the discredited honourable members opposite who failed to do anything about this during the decades that they were in government--

TALK.START.PARA: —Who brought in the cooperative scheme?
—They left the economy to run itself while they just swanned around pretending to govern the country.
—Who brought in the co-operative scheme?
—They were unable to make decisions. They were incapable of vision or reform.
—Order! I warn the honourable member for Ryan.

—Their timidity, their fear, their conservative, incoherent, divided ideology left them, this country, and Australian business right up the creek. In government and in opposition they have proved what we now know. The people of Australia have now shown on three occasions at general elections who they trust to govern this country. The business community, if not on the first occasion in 1983, certainly in 1987, backed this Government right down the line. The Opposition is so timid, so beholden to vested and cosy interests, that it cannot and will not act in the interests of the corporate sector it claims is its base.

SPEECH.PARA: Is it any wonder that Australia's serious business interests are deserting those opposite in droves. There would hardly be a strong voice in any sector of the business community that would support the Opposition. The Business Council of Australia, the Confederation of Australian Industry, the car industry, the financial institutions and the steel industry, in terms of economic management or corporate legislation, will not touch the Opposition. It does not have the answers, it does not have the vision and the policies, and it certainly does not have a future in this House. This Government has a constructive and viable wages policy. We are improving economic efficiency; we are freeing up the economy that those opposite smothered in cotton wool to protect their old school mates; and we are tackling the real challenges that confront Australia today, in the 1980s, and will confront us in the 1990s and well into the twenty-first century. The Opposition keeps changing its mind on this legislation-for whatever reason I do not know; I am sure that the Attorney-General and the business community do not know--

TALK.START.PARA: —Changing its mind?

—The Opposition keeps changing its mind. With all the backwards and forwards that is going on in the Senate and the House of Representatives we have a situation in which no-one opposite really knows what he or she is doing. The reality is that those opposite promise everything and do not back it up; they talk a lot and do not follow it up with action. The Australian people, Australian industry and Australian business know that. They are waiting for members of the Opposition to come up with something constructive and useful, but they cannot because they do not know where to start. It is too hard and it will always be too hard. That is why it is up to this Labor Government to reform and renovate the corporate sector.

SPEECH.PARA: The Attorney-General-it appears that the honourable member for Ryan misses him very much-has achieved this with his usual quiet, patient work with the States. He has achieved a lot in this area with the legal profession and the corporate sector. This legislation will stand as historic reform in this country. The Government welcomes the role of this committee, as will the rest of the business community. This legislation will stand as historic reform on a par with our other financial, social and economic reforms. I commend this motion to the House.

That the motion (Mr Staples's) be agreed to.

DEBATE.TITLE: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 4) 1988[COGNATE BILLS:INCOME TAX AMENDMENT BILL 1988MEDICARE LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1988]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 18 October, on motion by Mr Peter Morris:
That the Bill be now read a second time.
upon which Mr Peacock had moved by way of amendment:
That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: `whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House:
(1) notes that this is the highest taxing Government in the post-war history of Australia;

(2) notes that this Government's so-called tax reforms invariably involve simply offsetting tax reductions in one area by tax increases in others, as witnessed in this Bill by the termination of the 5/3 depreciation arrangement to offset a reduction in the corporate tax rate;
(3) notes that the Government continues its propensity for taxation by stealth by again unaccountably raising the provisional tax uplift factor;

(4) notes that the Treasurer has failed to meet his responsibilities in respect of the administration of the taxation system and has hidden behind the rhetoric of the Commissioner for Taxation and encouraged the undermining of the rule of law in taxation matters; and

(5) condemns the Government for its practice of `government by press release' which can cause otherwise legitimate legislation to be called into question because of the unacceptable retrospectivity thus introduced'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the debate is resumed on this Bill, I remind the House that it has been agreed that a general debate be allowed covering this Bill and orders of the day Nos 2 and 3.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles Mr D.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1988 is an omnibus Bill in that it incorporates numerous changes to our income tax laws covering a range of matters, including unfranked dividends or dividend imputations, the termination of section 26aaa of the Income Tax Assessment Act, which relates to the capital gains tax area, and pensioner rebates, and numerous other matters. Today I will concentrate on the three items that I have just mentioned.
—Especially the pensioner rebates.

—Especially pensioner rebates, as the honourable member for Dobell reminds me, and I will tackle that area first. Numerous members on this side of the House, including the honourable member for Dobell and I, perceived that the taxation question with regard to pensions could have been a problem if it had been allowed to continue in the form it was in some months ago. The Government reacted to the many representations from members on this side of the House and promptly made numerous changes to pensioner rebates which were set out in the May statement. In fact, this legislation will increase from $250 to $430 this rebate which is available to taxpayers who are in receipt of Australian social security or repatriation pensions.

SPEECH.PARA: The income level at which the rebate begins to shade out will also be increased from $6,142 to $6,892. The maximum rebate will shade out at a rate of 12 1/2c for each dollar of taxable income in excess of $6,892. Thus, no rebate will be available on taxable incomes in excess of $10,331, or just under $200 a week. This will also mean that approximately a quarter of a million pensioners will benefit by not having to pay taxation in advance.

TALK.START.PARA: —Provisional tax.

—Provisional tax-I should have remembered that because I used to pay it myself. As I have said, several hundred thousand pensioners will benefit from the lifting of the tax rebate from $250 to $430. This significant increase will mean that more pensioners will pay no tax this year.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government and many individual members who made representations to the Cabinet are concerned about pensioners and this concern is reflected in part of the legislation now before the House. Pensioners are always one of the top priorities of members on this side of the House in particular and they have received many benefits since this Government has come into office, not the least being the continuation of indexation of pensions, which are now just on 25 per cent of average weekly earnings, with the married couple rate being in excess of $200 a week.

The rebate situation which this proposed legislation introduces will mean that quite a few hundred thousand pensioners will not pay tax this year. It is a situation the Government will have to keep its eye on. I believe, and have believed for some time, that we may have to find some other solution in the long term because I can see that, if nothing is done again for another few years, we will be back basically introducing similar legislation and upping the ante again and again. While one may always do that, and it may be the only solution in the long run, there are people on this side of the House trying to find more appropriate solutions, if that is possible, so that pensioners, particularly the middle and lower income pensioners on full pensions, or pensioners who receive only a small amount of income, are accommodated and do not have to start paying taxation.

While I generally believe that all people should, of course, pay their appropriate taxation, it does gall some pensioners when they say, `Look, here we are; we have worked all our lives, and we have not much income', if they are receiving not much more than the pension and they are being forced to pay tax. We have solved that situation for the time being, and I can assure the House and all pensioners throughout Australia that the Government will keep an eye on and is working towards solving that situation in the long term. Indeed, it reminds me that you, Mr Deputy Speaker, as the honourable member for Stirling, were one of the people who were at the forefront of bringing this to the notice of the Government over the past six or 12 months.

A couple of other items include the unfranked departed dividends received by private companies. This raises the general issue, if I may comment, of the dividend imputation scheme which is one of the purest dividend imputation schemes in the world. It has been a resounding success, and that can be seen by looking again at the stock market and some of the major companies that give full franked dividends. Their stocks have risen in many cases. For example, one is BTR-Nylex Packaging Division, whose stock prices have risen to levels above those prior to the 19 October crash of last year. The banks are another group, if I can use the banks collectively, and that development has mainly been propelled because of the dividend imputation scheme introduced by this Government and the fully franked dividends that those organisations that I have mentioned have delivered to their shareholders. Indeed, the stopping of double taxation is a very important policy that this Government has introduced. It corrects a situation which incredibly was left as it was for many decades. Incredibly, again, for the previous three decades that taxation policy operated virtually unhindered under the administration of conservative governments that are supposed to look after business. They did not do anything about it. It was left to a Labor Government to introduce legislation that was more equitable in that regard.

The termination of section 26aaa again raises questions of capital gains. Indeed, it also knocks over an anomaly. I am sure that you, Mr Deputy Speaker, have had representations, as I have, from time to time from constituents, who have come to you and who have said, `Look, I have had to sell my house because I have been shifted interstate, or whatever, and we have been in the house only six or nine months and the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) wants to slug me capital gains tax under the old section 26aaa part of the legislation'. Those people had to wage war with the ATO in order to get an exemption on that. I had several constituents in that situation. Now the repeal of this section does away with that anomaly in the sense that now everything involved in buying and selling property will come under the general capital gains tax Act that we introduced a couple of years ago now, which has also been so successful. Of course, in line with that there are exemptions, the main one being the principal residence of a family or individual. That is exempt, and that is how the anomaly will disappear.

It is interesting that we have seen the introduction of dividend imputation, which has been so successful; the capital gains tax, about which we have had so much hoo-ha; and also the fringe benefits tax, about which we heard a hue and cry from the other side of the House and many sections of the community. It is amazing how all that hue and cry has died away completely. People see the equity, the fairness in the legislation the Government introduced. The Government will probably receive about four times the amount of money it had anticipated this year from the fringe benefits tax. That is an amazing amount of money. It just shows how much was locked away in fringe benefits and other `avoidance' areas with people trying not to pay their full amount of tax. The Government paid great attention to that and our taxation system is now much fairer and has greater equity.

I wish to touch on the wider taxation area. As I said at the start of my speech, this omnibus Bill touches on many aspects of the Taxation Act. We are looking at tax cuts next year. As the Treasurer (Mr Keating) said yesterday, I am not here to determine how much those tax cuts are going to be. Circumstances will vary from now to then and we will determine at that time how much the tax cuts will be and, more importantly, progressive rates of taxation. It is important to note that we are in a position where the Government is considering bringing down substantial tax cuts next year. When we came to office in 1983 we were facing a proposed Budget deficit of $9.6 billion. This year we had a surplus of $5.5 billion and we are in a situation where the economy is now growing more strongly than ever before. In fact, it may be growing too strongly; domestic demand is probably too strong at the moment. We are now able to deliver tax cuts to the average Australian. Honourable members opposite can hoo-ha about taxation, but the facts are that after 30 years of their administration we still had very high tax rates, the top rates being 60c in the dollar. That is now 49c, and I anticipate that rate coming down even further. The company rate is down to 39c in the dollar. No matter what the Opposition says, it did not do anything constructive for the taxation system.

Talking informally to a number of American congressmen recently, it was interesting that they said to me-Republicans and Democrats alike were in the room and they nodded-that once and for all, after the presidential election in a couple of weeks, they would blow away the myth that a country can keep increasing services and lowering taxation. I thought, `I have heard all that before'. They are following on behind us. We have had this myth perpetrated by the other side of the House that we can keep lowering taxes but at the same time continue to increase services; we will not do away with this and we will have money for that. In the debate on defence yesterday the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White) said he wanted another billion dollars or so for defence; the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) said he wanted more money for local hospitals, transport and local government; but at the same time they would continue to lower taxation.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is why no-one trusts them.

—Yes, that is exactly right. It is a mathematical equation. We cannot keep lowering taxes and increasing services. It is an impossibility. It was interesting that the American congressmen to whom I was speaking a few weeks ago said that after the presidential election that myth-that was the word they used-would be blown away. They have had all that nonsense from President Reagan and it will be blown away. Both the Democrats and Republicans agreed with that statement.

SPEECH.PARA: This is very important legislation which covers many aspects of the Taxation Act. I have touched on three areas that are very important-the unfranked dividends, the capital gains tax area, and the pensioner rebate which will enable over a quarter of a million pensioners to benefit directly from this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woods Dr R. L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak-if I can survive the attacks from these kamikaze bogong moths-on the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill 1988. This is another attempt to prop up the second rate health care system we have now, the Clayton's system-the health care system we have when we do not have any caring. It is the system which has introduced two-tier health care into the Australian way of life, one for the rich and one for the poor. This is quite contrary to what the Government claims to have done in terms of universality. It has created divisions which have never been there before and which, hopefully, will soon disappear. It has created waiting lists as high as 40,000 in some States. In every single State there are problems with waiting lists directly as a result of Medicare and the lack of access to private hospitals. At the same time, 9,000 private beds are sitting there waiting to be filled. We have no access to those beds for the vast majority of people on this so-called Medicare system.

SPEECH.PARA: We also find that people are unable to insure completely against costs when they are sick and they have to pay extra bills at that time. There is a deliberate policy by the Government to deter people from covering their own potential disabilities by refusing to allow them to insure for the gap. They face enormous bills in many cases when they are sick and need operations.

We have a system which encourages overservicing. Last night we heard the honourable member for Canning (Mr Gear) trying to defend the system. He was saying that all was wonderful and everything was nice and rosy. When we look at what the honourable member for Canning said, the truth is that he was not trying to defend the Medicare system; he was going about his usual business of attacking the doctors. The honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar) suggested during the debate, by way of interjection, that the honourable member ought to be careful not to get sick. In his own ignorance and misunderstanding of the situation the honourable member for Canning assumed that if he got sick the doctors would not treat him. We all know that that is not true. What the honourable member for Warringah was saying was that the honourable member ought not to get sick for exactly the opposite reason; if he did get sick and went to doctors they might treat him for his paranoia about doctors in particular.

This fellow has shown some aberrations over a number of months. He was not embarrassed about causing his own Minister problems by the breach of confidentiality in terms of taking documents. He still persists with this tunnel vision about attacking doctors. He asked about providing health care. He asked why doctors should provide health care. I do not know who on earth he thought was going to provide health care if it was not the doctors.

We get back to the question of the Australian Medical Association (AMA) proposed new fee structure, which the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) said in the first place was a wonderful idea. He said it was an excellent proposition. A couple of days later he thought about it again and said no, it was not, because it might increase costs. The proposed fee structure from the AMA basically suggests that instead of having a stopwatch beside the consultation couch, meaning the length of the consultation, the content of consultations should be assessed. There are many situations in which this is a very reasonable approach. For example, if one goes for an immunisation for measles it takes a few minutes. On the other hand, one may have a major diagnosis made which may also take the same amount of time, or a procedure which will involve a lot of skill, such as a long biopsy or something of that order. Those things will take enormous skill, knowledge and understanding. Yet there is no reward for doctors to undertake these sorts of things.

What the Government is basically encouraging doctors to do is to have a very rapid and shallow turnover of patients. It is not encouraging excellence and quality of care. It is quite the opposite; it is discouraging that and encouraging rapid turnover. The actual financial structure of fees at present encourages many short consultations. It encourages doctors to say, `Look, we will give you a quick five minutes now and send you away and get you back again', rather than getting into the depths of a diagnostic problem or whatever the situation might require. In that regard I support the AMA's fees. There have been no detailed published estimates as to whether there will be an increase in fees, but the actual change of structure to reward content must surely be something that we would all support.

There are other aspects of Medicare which concern everybody. I see the Minister responsible for pharmaceutical benefits-the Minister for Housing and Aged Care (Mr Staples)-is in the chamber. He is hiding his head in shame, no doubt, about the 53 drugs which he added to the authority only list. That is a classical example of hiding behind bureaucratic decisions. The Minister is unable to take responsibility for what his Department has decided. Regarding the 53 drugs that he put on the authority only list, basically he gave some instructions to the relevant committee which were, to our understanding, `work out which are the most expensive drugs, put them on the authority only list and we will make sure that fewer people have access to them. It is not a question of whether people need access or whether there is a viable alternative'. I understand that the committee was given some 48 hours-I think that I am being generous here-to consider these matters.

I have in front of me a letter from Dr Raghavan, who is the Chairman of the Medical Oncology Group of Australia-the cancer specialist group; those who are involved in looking after patients with cancer. He is an outside opinion; honourable members do not have to take my word for it. Dr Raghavan referred to the 20 cancer drugs, I think it is, which have been put on the authority only list. Firstly, he said that he had great concern because the action was based upon the false premise that cheaper alternative medications were available for treating cancer. He said:
It is facile to suggest that the few cheaper alternatives that have been omitted from the proposed list-
there are not that many-
can be used for all cancers, as the management of cancer is a highly specific and sophisticated mechanism, with certain drugs being active against only a few cancers.

Anybody with a modicum of understanding of the area would have known that. Quite clearly, the Minister was misadvised. I accept that he is not supposed to be an expert in everything, but clearly his advice was flawed. After all the representations that he has received on this I would have thought that he would have had the guts to change his approach, particularly towards cancer drugs but also in regard to several others on the authority only list. Dr Raghavan went on to say that the proposed action was taken without any consultation with the professional organisations that represent the physicians who treat patients with cancer; that is, those who know what they are doing. He gave a list of the organisations which had not been consulted. In his third point he said:

Rather than achieving a greater level of control, or even any measure of cost-saving, this step will introduce unnecessary delays in achieving cancer control for individual patients, will be time-wasting for a broad range of cancer physicians, and will inconvenience a group of the population that are already burdened with a dreadful spectrum of disease.
I cannot argue with one word that he has used there: he was absolutely spot on. The fourth point he made was:
If the intent is to ensure the more appropriate usage of these drugs, this could be achieved by a system of accreditation or licensing for the use of cytotoxic drugs . . .

That is a mechanism which many cancer specialists have proposed and would support. In summary he said that the proposal is ill-conceived and poorly planned. He said that it is based on inadequate consultation which will substantially increase inconvenience and treatment delays for patients with cancer and result in a major increase in the administrative burden. That letter was written on 10 July. The Minister did not get around to replying. As a result of a further letter on 30 September eventually the Minister replied. His reply of 4 October basically said, `Wait and see because we will know what is going on later on'.

I have a letter from 10 other cancer specialists saying effectively the same thing as Dr Raghavan. There is no doubt about the unanimity of the authors of those letters. The drugs about which we are talking are revolting drugs. They make people lose their hair, throw up and feel like death warmed up. Some are crucial drugs. One of the drugs on the list, Vincristine, is basically a curative drug for childhood leukaemia. Patients with childhood leukaemia have a much lower cure rate if there are delays in starting therapy. At present the cure rate is about 75 per cent, if it is treated straight away. I estimate that if treatment is delayed for three or four weeks the cure rate goes down to around 25 per cent. The Government has set up a bureaucratic procedure aimed at delaying access to those drugs by those kids and, therefore, putting a number of them at risk. The Minister has said, `I have fixed it all. We will institute telephone consultations, we will allow access and we will make sure that the bureaucracy works very well'. How well is it working?

It so happens that last week a patient of Dr Raghavan's required one of the anti-cancer drugs on the list. The patient happened to be the wife of an ex-senator, but that is almost irrelevant here. The authority went off and a letter came back saying, `No, Dr Raghavan, you cannot prescribe this because you work in a public hospital'. I see that the Minister looks surprised. I would be ashamed if I were in his position. I will be charitable and say that it must have been a bureaucratic mistake. I cannot believe that the Minsiter would have approved that sort of procedure. I am happy to give the Minister documents in this regard. This problem is typical of what is happening with Medicare at present.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. The Opposition seems to be concerned about relevance but only in Question Time. I do not understand how what the honourable member for Lowe is talking about is in any way relevant to the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill and the taxation legislation.
—I understand that the honourable member for Lowe is explaining the relationship between the conduct of Medicare and the conduct of medical practice. The Chair is happy to let him proceed.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. To try to suggest that the Medicare system can be separated from access to drugs that are required for health care is rather stretching things. I am happy to give the Minister the relevant documentation because I am sure that he will want to sort out the matter in terms of allowing access to the drugs which he has said publicly will be freely available to every Medicare and other patient in Australia. Clearly, that is not the case.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer to a few other things which have occurred recently. The Minister for Community Services and Health wrote to the Sydney Morning Herald and suddenly it became clear what is happening in terms of the socialising of medicine in Australia. The letter, dated 13 September, was in reply to a previous letter from Dr Bruce Shepherd, which, as he said, sought to persuade readers of the Sydney Morning Herald that their freedom was threatened by the Minister's secret plans to introduce a `participating doctors' scheme. The Minister said:
Your readers should, however, take heart from the fact that so alive and well is democracy in Australia that an esteemed newspaper such as the Herald-
in which the letter was written-
will afford generous space . . . to make nonsensically false claims.
I have stated repeatedly that this Government never has had any plans to introduce a participating doctors' scheme.
He went on to say:
. . . the real threat to democracy is posed by the fact that my plans are so secret that even I, the minister, am not aware of them.
I am sure your readers will not be fooled by this transparent political stunt.

Yet again, the Minister does not know what he has said on previous occasions. On 26 August 1986 the Minister advocated health maintenance organisations (HMOs): that is, participating doctors schemes-the very thing that in his letter of 13 September he said he did not support. I quote what he said on 26 August:

HMOs could provide advantages to the Australian health care system at several levels. I believe it is appropriate to examine a greater diversity of health care delivery systems. Genuinely enhanced competitiveness and diversity through a system such as the health maintenance organisation offers a real possibility for socially productive change.

If that is not supporting HMOs, I do not know what is. He made a mockery of his recent statements by saying that the information paper on HMOs had been considered by Cabinet, which had approved its release to stimulate both debate and some definite proposals of developing HMOs in Australia. I wish the Minister knew what he intends to do. Again, I am happy to provide copies of his press statement in this regard.

Let me point out what HMOs do. HMOs and other similar participating doctors' schemes involve paying a fixed annual fee to a group of doctors who, in return, agree to provide health care regardless of whether people get sick or not. It is a capitation fee. Naturally this gives doctors an incentive to minimise expensive investigations and to avoid procedures because effectively they are paying for those items out of their own pockets. They are encouraged to make short cuts, to cut corners, rather than to provide quality health care. It is another example, like Medicare, of cost saving at the expense of quality. HMOs effectively mean a bargain basement, second-rate health system which provides incentives to enrol the younger, and the fitter, leaving the elderly and the sick to fend for themselves without any good health cover. I am amazed at the Minister's confusion. I am also amazed at the hidden agenda which is quite clearly tucked away in the releases of the Minister for Community Services and Health.

A couple of days later, in an interview, the Minister said that he was in favour of capitation fees, which basically mean the same sort of thing. Doctors are paid a fixed annual sum per head of population under their care regardless of whether the patients are sick or not. It is similar to the dreaded national health system that exists in the United Kingdom-the one that is falling apart. It means effectively that general practitioners are paid a salary according to the size of their practice, not according to how well they work, how hard they work or how much caring they show for their patients. This may benefit the Government's Budget, but pretty well everyone else in the community loses. Perhaps the Minister had in mind a single, flat fee per visit, regardless of what services a doctor performs. For example, for signing a prescription the doctor would get paid exactly the same as he would for performing an hour long, complex diagnostic procedure or a therapeutic procedure. The Minister should realise that the way to save money is for general practitioners to make an appropriate diagnosis at the patient's first visit, rather than have patients make repeated visits. The proposed AMA system, so long as the fee structures themselves are worked out appropriately, allows the content of the work to be rewarded. That is exactly what quality health care needs in this country.

In terms of developing and encouraging research, quality care and access to new therapy the present Medicare pricing system in Australia is very difficult to understand. We are supposed to be encouraging support for doctors, from the pharmaceutical companies and for encouraging exports and research into those drugs. The Government put forward some guidelines which said basically that when a drug was out of patent, so long as the drug company had more than 90 per cent of the market it would be allowed to continue to market that drug at a fair and reasonable price. If the company had less than 90 per cent of the market the price of the generic drug would be the chosen price. In almost all cases that would be lower. Within a few months of the guidelines being proposed, they were counteracted by the Government, particularly in regard to the Wellcome Foundation and its drug called Zyloprim-Allopurinol-which is very widely used for gout. That company actually has 98 per cent of the market and has recently invested $12m on a new plant to produce the drug in Australia and to allow for exports. The Minister himself actually visited the company, saw the plant and encouraged the company in its procedures. However, recently the Government has turned around and said: `We know that you have 98 per cent of the market for this drug but nonetheless you are going to have to reduce your costs down to those of the generic which has only 2 per cent of the market'. I make no comment at all on the quality of the generic drug involved here. However, what confidence can we have in a government which breaks its own guidelines in this regard?

There is a worse example, which affects the very quality of care given to patients receiving drugs. The drug, produced by Ciba-Geigy, is called Tegretol-Carbam-Azepine. It is an anti-convulsant which means that it stops people having fits. It has been available for several years and is very effective. The same situation applies to this drug in terms of pricing policy except that in this case the company has 99.9 per cent of the market. The price of the drug is already a third of that in Canada and the United States and half of that even in Indonesia. There is only a 7 per cent price difference between that drug and the generic drug-which, again, as far as I am aware, is a quality drug.

However, the more significant problem is bio-availability. In other words, the Food and Drug Administration of the United States, which is our leader in this regard, allows drugs to be considered equal in effectiveness if their bio-availability is within 20 per cent of each other. The problem with Tegretol is that it has a very narrow therapeutic range. If patients get above the appropriate dose, they start experiencing side effects; if they get below the dose, then they start having fits. If patients are changed over to another drug, the chances are that with a 20 per cent variation one may well find that young kids who are on this drug are having fits or experiencing toxicity. There is a major risk. Quite clearly, with only a 7 per cent price variation, it is inappropriate to put a number of children through what, clearly, are enormous risks.

Our medicare system is crying out for three things. It is crying out for quality, access to that quality medicine, and affordability. However, the system we have at present is exactly the opposite of that. Instead of quality we have a second rate system. Instead of access we have next to no access-there are numbers of people on large, prolonged waiting lists. Instead of affordability we have considerable expense, as a deliberate policy under which people cannot cover for the risks and the costs involved in becoming sick under this Government's policy. The sooner we change to a system which allows quality of care, access to that quality care and affordability, the better off will be the whole of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Mr S.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a number of comments about the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) and cognate Bills before us this morning. I would like also to address some of the points raised by the honourable member for Lowe (Dr Woods), who, I believe, is certainly a committed doctor in his own right. The technical level of his speech in the debate today on the relationship between generic drugs and brand name drugs and so on I think has certainly been evidence of this. I have no doubt of his sincerity in bringing those sorts of issues to the attention of the Parliament and, indeed, to the attention of the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) and the Minister for Housing and Aged Care (Mr Staples). However, I think one or two points made about Medicare perhaps need answering. I will come to those a little later.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bills before the House this morning represent the opportunity for the people of Australia, once again, to see that the Government is able to deliver on the promises it makes regarding changes to taxation laws and, in fact, improve the tax base and the provision of services in this country. What we are in fact seeing in relation to the three Bills being debated today is the implementation of decisions taken in the May economic statement and the Budget measures that were announced. The Bills relate to a number of issues such as the income tax deductions for depreciation of special write-offs of income producing plant, the treatment of certain dividends, the abolition of section 26aaa of the Income Tax Assessment Act-the valuation of livestock-and the increase in pensioner rebates. In the Bills we are looking also at increasing rebates for the recipients of social security, unemployment, sickness and special benefits and certain training and Commonwealth educational allowances.

All of these sorts of things introduced in the Bills today go to the heart of what this Government is about. They go to the heart of social justice but, at the same time, to economic responsibility. I think that there is, therefore, a stark contrast between what this Government can deliver and what the Opposition proposes at different times. As has been said time and time again, it is very difficult just to draw comparisons between ourselves in government and the Opposition because of the Opposition's lack of comprehensive policy in the taxation area particularly. We have been waiting for the policy. I am sure that honourable members look forward to seeing that policy. When that policy is brought forward obviously it will be subject to a great deal of scrutiny by those of us on this side of the House who have an interest in these matters. If the exercise that was indulged in prior to the last election is anything to go by, that Opposition policy again will be found wanting.

I remind honourable members that back in the 1987 election campaign the Opposition went to the people with the traditional method of bribery, the fistful of dollars campaign, saying that tax cuts would lead to this, that and the other. Of course, when that was costed out it was suddenly found that the figures were more than rubbery; they were totally dissipated because they were found to have no basis in fact whatsoever. Of course, as a result of that the former shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton), was demoted. Since that time he has been demoted even further to the back bench. So much for consistency in the approach to tax matters.

I would like to say something also about the approach adopted by this Government in regard to the taxation Bills and how we are viewed by people in other countries. I had the opportunity recently to discuss Australia's economic performance with a number of people in the United States. My friend and colleague the honourable member for Isaacs (Mr Charles) made some comment about this in his presentation this morning. During my recent visit to the United States I spoke with people in the Treasury, one of the three members of the Council of Economic Advisers-to advise the President of the United States-to a number of economists in New York and people in the Internal Revenue Service (IRS). I was frankly surprised at the degree of understanding and appreciation of what this Labor Government had done in taxation reform in this country and, indeed, an appreciation of just how far we have gone in improving the system. I refer particularly to the capital gains tax and to the fringe benefit tax. Of course, both of those taxes have been decried by those on the Opposition benches as being a tax grab and not appropriate in Australia. Interestingly enough, however, in talking to United States officials in Treasury, IRS and the Council of Economic Advisers, one hears them saying, `You have done a great job. I wish we and our politicians had the same intestinal fortitude to go in the same direction'. There is a capital gains tax in the United States but it is not discounted for the inflation rate. Time and again we hear people say that the tax rates in Australia are far greater than those in countries with which we trade. But if we look at the United States we see that there is not a great deal of difference between the total tax take there, based on state and federal taxes and charges, and what we have in Australia. I am sure honourable members on the other side will have to admit that this Government has, since 1983, progressively reduced marginal tax rates, and we are continuing to do so. We are reducing business tax imposts-39c in the dollar in the coming tax year. That is real progress. That is a fact and we cannot get away from it.

We have heard spurious arguments and have been told, `Yes, but look at the amount of money that is there. The total tax take is up'. Yes, it is and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has admitted this. But why is it up? Simply because more people are paying their fair share. This Government has cracked down on tax avoidance, and will continue to do so-at the moment there seems to be some toing and froing in the Opposition on the upgraded tax file number system-and because of that crackdown and those changes a far greater number of people in the community, who in the past have perhaps evaded or avoided paying tax, or who blatantly did not want to pay tax, will pay it. It is a fact and we cannot get away from it.

As I have mentioned, included in the Bills before us this morning is some consideration of the capital gains tax and the removal of section 26aaa, and so on. It is interesting to look at the snippets of information that have come from time to time from the Opposition, and particularly the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) in respect of his policies. The Opposition at this stage has not got a comprehensive set of policies on economics, tax or half a dozen other things. But during the last election campaign we heard this wonderful phrase used by the Leader of the Opposition, that when the Opposition got into government all of these dreadful taxes that the Labor Party had introduced in government would be eliminated `lock, stock and barrel'. People thought that was a firm of solicitors, but in fact it was not; it was the Leader of the Opposition suggesting that, lock, stock and barrel, everything would be wiped out because it would not be fair on the Opposition's mates in the business community. It is interesting to see now that the Leader of the Opposition has backed away from that. In press releases over recent months he has said that, `The fringe benefits tax (FBT) is not so bad and it will have to stay, but we might modify it in some way'.

I think in the week before last there was a press release suggesting that the Liberal Party and the National Party of Australia, if in government, would retain the pensioner assets test, which they had decried and over which they had fought a campaign of fear amongst the pensioner communities. Suddenly it has been blessed and it is okay. The Capital gains tax has gone the same way.

Obviously we need to get the facts straight from the Opposition. Where does it stand on these issues? Is it simply going to play politics over the upgraded tax file number system or is it going to support the Government in its fair and reasonable endeavours to ensure that the tax cheats continue to be caught? Is it going to help to ensure that a fair share of tax is paid by those who in the past have not done so, so that it can come to the Government to provide services? I have stood in this place previously and argued the case as to why governments impose taxes. They do so simply to provide services which any government, whether it be made up of the ladies and gentlemen on the other side of this place, or us, has to under the Constitution. We have a role to play and we must provide those services. We can do that only if we have the financial base with which to do so.

I did indicate that I wanted to make some comments about the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill that we are debating today. To set the scene I think it is important to note that the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill 1988 will amend the Medicare Levy Act 1986 to impose the basic rate of Medicare levy for 1988-89 and 1989-90. It will remain at 1.25 per cent of taxable income, the rate which has applied since 1 December 1986. Accordingly, for 1988-89 and 1989-90, individuals with taxable incomes of up to $9,560, and married couples and sole parents with family incomes of up to $16,110, will not be required to pay the levy. I think that needs to be said at the outset.

What does concern me is that in this debate, which has ranged reasonably far and wide on the question of Medicare and the philosophical basis of it, it cannot be denied that Medicare is a universal health system. The poorest two million people in our community are now covered. Yet speaker after speaker for the Opposition stand up here and say that Medicare is a second rate health care system. The honourable member for Lowe (Dr Woods) said that. He said it has created divisions. But the divisions that have been created have, in the main, been caused by an unscrupulous group of doctors, but not all doctors. I suggest that the majority of family general practitioners and some of the specialists that we know in our electorates, play the game fairly and are concerned about the welfare of their patients.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who are you accusing then?

—But there is a small group in the community which perhaps is not. The honourable member for Curtin interjects and asks who I am accusing. I will get to that in a moment because I think it is relevant to this debate. Concern was also expressed by the honourable member for Lowe, who, I remind honourable members, is a doctor, about this so-called second rate health care system created by Medicare. He talked about it creating waiting lists. That is absolute rubbish. The creation of the waiting lists in New South Wales was caused by a certain group of doctors, particularly orthopaedic surgeons, who refused point blank to come into the public health system to conduct operations.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me again recount to the members of this House a story about one of my pensioner constituents. As is the wont of all members of this place, we invariably travel to our constituents and talk to pensioner groups to get a feeling for their problems. During a visit to a pensioner association in Corrimal, in my electorate, one lady shuffled up to me-I use the term `shuffled up' because she had a problem with one of her knees-and I said to her, `What seems to be the problem?' She said, `I have got a knee problem and I need an operation. I have been to an orthopaedic specialist and he said to me, ``Excuse me, dear, are you in a private health fund?''.' She said, `No, I am not. I am on Medicare. I am a pensioner and I am not going to pay out some of my money to go into a private health fund.' He said, `I am sorry, luv, I cannot fix you up until you get into a private health fund'. So she said that on principle she refused to do so. She would be prepared to put up with the agony of having to drag herself around rather than submit to this demand by this `caring' person in society. I think this typifies some of the attitudes displayed by some in the medical profession.

We talk about whether these caring people are recompensed in line with their worth. I refer honourable members to an article that appeared yesterday in the Canberra Times-I spoke about this during the adjournment debate last night-headed `Doctors plan fund to change Medicare'. The honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher), who has just left the chamber, wanted to know to whom I was referring earlier when I was directing some criticism at certain members of the profession. This article mentioned the convener of a group, a Dr Michael Aroney, a blast from the past, a former Liberal candidate in a Federal election, who was organising a `freedom-fighting fund to campaign for changes to Medicare'. That group is trying to raise $10m for a fighting fund to change Medicare. Dr Aroney, who is the President of the Australian Association of Surgeons, said-now get this-that the fund would be politically motivated but would not necessarily aim to end the Hawke Government or Medicare. It would be politically motivated. He was quoted-I ask honourable members on the other side, particularly the honourable member for Lowe, to listen because I want to know whether he supports Dr Aroney, a gentleman leading a certain group of doctors in the fight against Medicare-as saying:
This fund is to promulgate and bring about changes in Medicare which would make it more acceptable to all of us in the medical profession . . .

What about the patients? What about care for the old, care for the frail? No, this was not mentioned. These doctors are going to develop a fighting fund to kick Medicare, and this Government which supports it, in the teeth, because they want to make it more acceptable to themselves. We have seen the charging schedule of the Australian Medical Association. We have seen its recommendations. We have seen what this has led to in New South Wales. It has even held the New South Wales Liberal Government to ransom by continuing to refuse-the orthopaedic surgeons in particular-to go back into the public health system unless fees were massively increased. Of course, the Minister for Health in New South Wales, Mr Collins, and the Premier, Mr Greiner, caved in. We now have these people not only developing a fighting fund to overturn Medicare and trying to get conditions acceptable to them-I can only translate that to mean further increases in fees for people-but also trampling further the public health system because they want to direct people to private hospitals where people have to pay an up-front amount of money which is not redeemable to go in--

TALK.START.PARA: —Which half the doctors own.
—As the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs reminds me, half the doctors own these private hospitals. I find this absolutely appalling. Dr Aroney went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: It has to be changed to allow people the option of opting out of Medicare and taking out private medical insurance.

Medicare might be a good thing for people who cannot afford anything else! TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that?
