SPEECH.SPEAKER: Porter Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my comments to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4). The legislation before the House is yet another Labor tax Bill. Despite the massive tax hike already imposed on the Australian community, this Bill imposes still more increases in tax. The impact of these new taxes will be felt most keenly by the rural and manufacturing sector. As with nearly all the tax increases imposed by this Government, they are short-sighted, inequitable and will cost jobs. This Government's taxing record is one of insatiable greed. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) is the biggest taxing Treasurer this country has ever seen. Governments used to increase taxes once a year, every 12 months, but that was too long for this Treasurer. Without more regular tax hits he was starting to get tax withdrawal symptoms but he soon found the remedy. He introduced the May mini-Budget as a feature of this Government's fiscal policy. Each year, the Treasurer now has two goes at increasing tax to feed his Government's voracious demand for funds.

SPEECH.PARA: We know how devious, cunning and dishonest drug addicts become when in search of a hit. Their craving knows no bounds. So it is with this Government. It was not long before it was not satisfied with two tax attacks a year. So the Undertaker found another way to feed his taxing habit. He discovered that one could avoid the harrowing business of bringing down a Budget by indexing taxes and charges, so that without even lifting a finger the tax payable automatically increases. Tax on beer and cigarettes goes up automatically every six months. Fees on passports have also been indexed by this Treasurer. Almost every tax has gone up. If any further proof of this Treasurer's unbelievable tax habit is required, just recall the number of totally new taxes he has discovered and introduced: The capital gains tax; fringe benefits tax; entertainment tax; the Medicare levy; new sales taxes on a range of items including citrus-that is, orange juice-wine, flavoured milk, and so on; a new tax to be implemented on superannuation; and the indexing of excise tax. Since coming to office, this government has introduced 295 taxation measures, and those designed to increase the tax take outnumber those designed to reduce it by at least two to one.

Most experienced addicts try hard to disguise their addiction and the Treasurer is no exception. He has formulated all sorts of excuses and deceptions for his tax habit. There are buzz words such as tax restructuring, tax rationalisation, consistent with the principle of fiscal equalisation-that is a ripper-correction of anomalies, or levelling the playing field. They are the words used by the Treasurer as a means of explaining the tax increases. They all mean exactly the same thing-more tax. Whenever one hears words such as levelling the playing fields, tax restructuring and tax rationalisation, one knows that the Treasurer has found a new way to impose another tax. The only levelling being done is of the Australian community, which is being prostrated by the weight of the Keating tax burden. New taxes, more Budgets to impose them and automatic tax increases are all part of the same debilitating attack which the Hawke-Keating Labor Government has made on Australian taxpayers. The increases in taxation under Labor have been massive.

Tax revenue has doubled since Labor took office. The Treasurer, and indeed the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin) who spoke before me, tried to explain away the enormous increase by claiming the cause is the increase in the number of people in jobs and less tax evasion. However, while there has been some increase in those in work, it certainly has not been sufficient to justify the doubling of the tax take. Taxes on individuals have risen from $23 billion five years ago to $47.5 billion this year-an increase of 107.2 per cent. That is not a bad record for the Treasurer. He has doubled the personal income tax take. Company tax has skyrocketed by 133 per cent. So much for the reductions in corporate tax rates which we heard about from the honourable member for Macarthur. Company tax has gone up 133 per cent, yet the honourable member for Macarthur said that no new taxes have been introduced.

Let us look at the taxes on consumer goods. A whole new range of sales taxes has been introduced. Sales tax revenue has increased by 147.3 per cent. That is not a bad record for a Treasurer, is it? These taxes have resulted in an increase in tax take which is two to three time faster than inflation, giving the Treasurer a massive real increase in revenue. The rate of increase in tax collections has also risen more than twice as fast as average weekly earnings. No wonder the wage and salary earners of Australia are complaining. They are paying more tax now than they have ever paid and the rate of increase in tax collections has been twice as fast as wage increases. In other words, the average Australian is hurting, and hurting badly. The size of the burden shouldered by Australian taxpayers after five years of Labor is graphically illustrated by the fact that today's average wage earners would need a tax reduction of $56 a week by next July to restore them to the level of real income they earned before this Government came to office.

The Treasurer has used a myriad of devices to increase tax. First, he started cutting concessions previously available to taxpayers as deductions. We see a little more of that in this legislation. He took away the health insurance rebate. That was a tax deduction which people got for paying health insurance premiums. He replaced that with a new tax-the Medicare levy. He has taken away a deduction and put on a new tax. That is a great philosophy and it is typical of the Labor socialist Government. Secondly, he established a large number of new taxes, such as the capital gains tax, the fringe benefits tax and the others I have already detailed. Thirdly, he imposed a whole range of new fees and charges. A number of Commonwealth Government services previously paid for out of tax revenue are now available to taxpayers only if they pay a fee. So they pay twice. There are charges for the registration of therapeutic goods, fees for the clearance of agricultural and veterinary chemicals and immigration fees for people coming into the country. These are all new fees and charges-a new tax mechanism discovered by this Government.

Fourthly, he has discovered that statutory authorities are a relatively untapped taxation mechanism, a great new stalking horse. This year the Treasurer will raise some $400m by taxing statutory authorities. Australia Post and Telecom Australia have to raise their charges to pay the extra tax. The advantage of this indirect route by which the Treasurer slugs the hard-pressed Australian taxpayer yet again is that the odium for the tax hike is shifted from the Treasurer to Telecom or Australia Post. The success of the Undertaker's strategy was seen recently when Telecom had to increase charges to cover newly-imposed government taxes. In that instance the Telecom monopoly bore the brunt of the public reaction, not the Treasurer who imposed the taxes leading to the increase in charges. He got away scot-free. In fact, he was away; he was overseas yet again.

This subterfuge has gone even further because the Government is demanding that Telecom and Australia Post now pay local government rates. While consumers will inevitably have to pay more for the services provided by these government authorities, the benefits will not go to the local communities in the form of increased rate revenue. Oh no, the Undertaker has made sure of that. He is going to take back 90 per cent of the revenue collected by local government from the statutory authorities. The statutory authorities now have to pay rates to local government. Will local government get the benefit? Oh no, the Treasurer will whip it back. What do we have now? We have local government as yet another tax collecting agency for the Federal Government.

I turn to the impact of these massive increases in taxation on particular industries. The industries that will be hit by this legislation are the rural sector and the manufacturing sector. Farmers in Australia have suffered a double attack. Not only do they have to bear the general increase in tax; they have also been hit by a selective attack which has increased effective tax rates for farmers. The Treasurer has done this by cutting depreciation and other allowances which were provided to assist the rural sector in meeting adverse and fluctuating seasonal conditions. The extent of the attack on the rural sector was clearly evident in the May mini-Budget, where farmers were really targeted for special attention, not just by the elimination of concessions and allowances of particular importance to the farmer but also by cuts to local government, road funding, wool promotion and the fertiliser subsidy. On top of all that, the Government increased rural inspection charges. The Government claims that these tax increases and cost impositions on the bush will be offset by lower input costs, but the promised tariff reductions are to be phased in and the benefits are years down the track. Farmers are being forced by Labor to pay now in return for a benefit which is years away.

TALK.START.PARA: —It sounds like the tax cuts all over again.

—Exactly. This legislation eliminates the five-year depreciation allowance for storage facilities for hay, grain and fodder for primary production and puts in its place a significantly lower depreciation regime. This is just another short-sighted, stupid attempt by the Government to increase revenue regardless of the consequences. Fodder conservation is one way to protect our livestock against the ravages of our harsh climatic conditions, especially drought. The existing arrangements encourage farmers to conserve fodder so that they can hold livestock in tough times, enhancing our ability as a nation to continue to earn valuable export income without wild fluctuations. Increasing the cost of on-farm storage will result in Australia being more susceptible to our fickle seasonal conditions.

SPEECH.PARA: It is worth noting that other farm conservation measures have been subject to attack by this Labor Government. For example, the depreciation allowances for water storage, irrigation improvement and water conservation are now at their lowest level for years. Management of our water resources is doubtless one of the most crucial conservation issues in Australia. Upgrading of farm irrigation projects will provide substantial improvements in water quality by reducing saline flows. The coalition saw the benefit of improving our environment and encouraged farmers to act. Until September 1985, costs for investment in plant for water conservation or conveyance were allowed to be deducted in the year of expenditure. However, since September 1985 under this short-sighted Government, expenditure on water conservation must be depreciated over three years. This environmental vandalism by the Hawke Government has already resulted in a slowdown in improvement of irrigation practices which further exacerbates the problem of low water quality in rivers such as the Murray-the lifeblood of South Australia.

The change also substantially reduces the incentive for farmers to conserve water and is likely to result in increased claims on the Government in drought years, and lower export sales. There is no doubt that the change in rules for deductibility of depreciation costs for investment in plant for water conservation, like the changes we are considering in this Bill have been designed for one purpose-not to level the playing field, but to increase the tax take of this tax greedy administration.

Turning to the manufacturing industry, the Bill withdraws certain allowances for the write-off of the capital cost of plant and equipment used for producing assessable income, and terminates the accelerated depreciation concession allowing the write-off of most plant over three or five years. In an age when the international competitiveness of Australian industries, especially our export industries, demands the use of the most modern high-tech equipment to ensure increased productivity, the termination of accelerated depreciation for plant and equipment is a regressive step which makes it even more difficult for our capital intensive industries to compete with their overseas rivals.

The corporate tax structure should be providing incentives for our capital intensive manufacturing industries to take advantage of the latest technological advances as one of the ways of improving productivity. Instead, this Bill provides the incentives for industry to maintain existing plant and equipment, not to undertake new investment. A reduction in the corporate tax rate would be welcomed but the offset increased taxation will impact most severely on the large employers, that is the manufacturers, whom the Government has been encouraging to improve their productivity. While manufacturing industry is the loser under this Bill, the service industries, which were already doing well, are the winners. They do not require the same extent of capital investment as manufacturing industry and therefore will not suffer as much from cuts in depreciation allowances. The package is therefore inequitable and provides tax relief to those who need it the least while penalising manufacturers who need it the most. So much for levelling the playing field.

One might also ask why the Treasurer chose to give tax cuts to companies before tax cuts to individuals. Surely the long-suffering pay as you earn taxpayer deserves a break and reducing personal tax would increase incentive and provide further stimulus to the innovators and job creators in our community. But no, the Undertaker wanted to rack up a few points with his rich mates, perhaps hoping they would throw some weight behind his campaign to topple the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). In any event the wage and salary earners have again been forgotten.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —To get a perspective on this debate, 10 years ago a speech was delivered in my home city of Perth to the Institute of Chartered Accountants on behalf of the then Treasurer, the now honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard). The speech was delivered by the honourable member for Goldstein (Mr Macphee), who was then part of the Fraser Ministry. It referred to, appropriately, the need for the accounting profession to eliminate artificial contrivances and arrangements designed to minimise tax. I thought it was a far-reaching speech at the time because it went to the substance of the tax system and, in a sense, called upon the taxation professionals, the chartered accountants present and many public accountants who were there to lift their game. It said, `Do not go down the path of tax evasion and avoidance practices. We want substantial compliance with the system. If you do not do that, we will have to introduce regulation to make you comply'. That was in 1978, 10 years ago.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting for people listening to this debate today because that Government was one of successive Fraser governments and was not voted out until March 1983. It is important to understand when one begins to talk about tax and to listen to contributions from members like the honourable member for Barker (Mr Porter) that tax evasion and avoidance were the order of the day. The problem became so serious that the Commissioner of Taxation went to the then Treasurer, the now honourable member for Bennelong, and said, `We have a serious problem here and we want to do something about the haemorrhage in the tax system. We want your cooperation and assistance'.

There are two interesting observations to make in this debate; firstly, that speech was delivered in a very appropriate place because my home city of Perth was a key centre of tax evasion in Australia. The schemes were dreamt up. It is no coincidence, incidentally, that the Deputy Crown Solicitor's Office in Perth had in its bottom drawer some actions concerning tax which were never taken, and it was only when the McCabe-Lafranchi report came out and blew the whistle and then the report of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union bit the originators of it that the whole tax mess in Australia came to the surface. People in this place who have a memory will understand that in the 1983 election that was a big issue. There is no doubt about that. Given the then Government's failure in this area, it was one of the factors that brought the Labor Party into government. It is important to get that straight. Let us not let the Australian people forget because from time to time there is a collective amnesia in the ranks of the Opposition. Opposition members forget they were part of that process. They may want to do a Pontius Pilate and wash their hands of it but we will not let them do it. The people who now adorn the Opposition benches were part of that process. The ordinary Australian person was angry about it.

Honourable members should get two other things clear. When the Opposition parties left office the top marginal rate was 60c in the dollar. The now Leader of the Opposition, when Treasurer, left office with 60c in the dollar being the top marginal rate. The other thing that they left office with was the enormous hole in the tax system. Not only was there deliberate evasion in relation to tax-which in that sense is criminal evasion, and many such cases have been subsequently fought-but also there was a failure to collect tax that could easily have been collected. People using avoidance measures-and these were not criminal activities-that is, arranging to pay income in other forms, were in fact minimising their income. Therefore, a lot of income tax that ought to have been paid in Australia was not paid.

The consequences were clear. Those who were in the tax system carried a higher burden, and many people who are here listening to the debate were in that tax system and were paying a higher rate than they needed to pay because of that failure, a failure to catch up with not only the criminal evasion of tax, because the then Government did not have the political will, but also the avoidance measures. Another consequence was that the important services that can be provided from revenue were often deficient in their delivery. One could talk about health and hospitals and housing. The number of housing commencements dropped down to 105,000, the lowest for 20 years. But the crucial thing is that when there is the failure of political will that was evident when the coalition parties were in government we have a major problem.

It is important to set the scene of this because if one does not do so, we might be tempted by people like the honourable member for Barker to think that this is a current problem. It is not. Honourable members may remember that newspapers such as the Australian put out car stickers which said, `Join the tax revolt'. Interestingly, the then Government did not fight that. It went along with what was happening; it was complicit in its behaviour. There was a great deal of concern and anger. People in jobs were saying, `Well, I have to pay tax'. But people at the Federal level were ignoring tax evasion and avoidance. There really was a great concern and anger. The anger was sufficient to produce some very large swings in the results of the 1983 election. It is all right for the Opposition to talk about the current circumstances. But we have to keep locked in our minds the sorts of things that happened when those opposite were in government. I think it is interesting that a lot of people in the community still remember. But it is important to remember the circumstance just in case the collective amnesia of the Opposition might overwhelm people in the wider community.

How do we go about redressing the position? We can do a number of things. The first thing is to give the Deputy Commissioner of Taxation in each State sufficient resources to go about restoring some enforcement in respect of the tax system. That has happened. Secondly, we can look at introducing, legally, measures to collect tax that ought to be paid. We have done that. The fringe benefits tax and the capital gains tax are simple measures. At the time these taxes were introduced the Opposition was saying, `We think that is terrible. We will get rid of the fringe benefits tax. We want to go back to the days of the free lunch and all the other subsidies in respect of schools, universities and housing'. One does not have to go too far to find out where members of the Opposition come from. They come from the collective group of the well-to-do who were benefiting more than they ought to. They opposed the fringe benefits tax and the capital gains tax not for good economic reasons but for reasons that caused the tax system to fall into disrepute-because of self-interest. This, again, ought to be placed on the record.

There are other areas that I and many people in the community thought ought to be dealt with. It is fair to say that people in the rural sector were, for some time, able to average their incomes. I think that is a fair system because of the very marked fluctuations that occur in rural incomes. The honourable member for Barker might not recognise that but people on this side do. We also felt that people in other occupations-artists, authors and sports people-also have fluctuations in income. We ought to observe-and the Opposition forgets this-that very often they are people on relatively modest incomes. We addressed this problem by introducing tax averaging for artists, authors and professional sports people.
Let me paint one or two pictures. Many people in Australia, such as jockeys, are from modest backgrounds and do well for a short period.

TALK.START.PARA: —The ones that I back do not seem to be doing too well.

—Not the ones that ride horses backed by the Minister at the table or perhaps one or two other members in this place. Some jockeys make good incomes. But, due to increasing weight, injury or some fall-out with a trainer, their income may collapse. All of a sudden they may have a great inequity in income. We have said, `Let us be fair about that; let them average out their income'. That is a sensible proposition.

SPEECH.PARA: This approach goes to any other area of sporting endeavour. Take, for instance, football, which happens to be an interest of mine. We often see young men-Aboriginal boys in particular-who come from very modest backgrounds getting a break for the first time in their lives. We have said, `When you get that break in your life you are not going to have to pay the top marginal rate of tax. We will allow you to average out your income'. That is socially a very just thing to do. We have said that we think it is sensible to allow young male footballers or jockeys or young girls who happen to succeed in some area of professional activity to average their income. That is something that the Opposition did not grapple with. We have made that substantial reform. I think we have to put that on the record and remind people what we have done. It is all very well for people to come in here and cite a few statistics. But let us talk about the human processes behind what has been done.

Let me talk about another recent reform that we have introduced which I think is very important. It was quite clear to a number of us-this has been mentioned by the honourable member for Isaacs (Mr Charles) and the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl)-that pensioners who were receiving pensioner rebates were paying provisional tax. We suggested to the Treasurer (Mr Keating) that that was wrong because not only was there a degree of distress involved but also, the way it worked out, they generally got all of that tax back. The set of tax arrangements before the House changes that. Pensioners who qualify for the pensioner rebate will no longer be required to pay provisional tax. I think that is a very important reform. Colleagues of mine such as the honourable member for Moore (Mr Blanchard), who works very hard in his electorate and who has very extensive contacts with people in the community--

TALK.START.PARA: —He is sitting in the gallery.

—The honourable member, who is in the gallery, works very well with aged persons, and he is a strong supporter of this important reform. The Treasurer has introduced this much needed change and I acknowledge the support of people like the honourable member for Moore.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me continue the narrative, because I think we can easily be deluded into thinking that it is all bad news. On the corporate side, some honourable members in this place have looked at the performance of corporations. For a long time the position has been that a corporation paid tax and then the shareholder paid tax on the dividends that he received. So, tax was paid twice, at an effective rate of 78c. This arrangement had two effects. Not only was there a tax penalty, but also corporations in Australia were encouraged to fund their requirements through loans from overseas. This meant that there were difficulties in respect of the balance of payments position. Not only that, there was a direct discouragement by the then Government, which is now in opposition, for people to own shares. We have introduced full dividend imputation. In other words, if a corporation chooses to frank its dividends, it pays the tax and the individual shareholder does not. In effect, one gets a fully franked dividend and one attracts a tax credit. It is possible for some older people,who are perhaps on pensions, to end up with tax credits if they are shareholders. This means that they would pay no tax at all if they earned any extra income.

We hear honourable members opposite whingeing and wailing about how difficult things are. But let us talk about this sort of substantial reform. We recognised the problem and so did the community. Incidentally, so too did the stock market, because there is now a two-tier arrangement for share prices in Australia. Fully franked dividends attract a premium share price. In other words, the share price is higher than that of shares of other corporations that are not paying fully franked dividends.

Honourable members might say, `Oh well, the honourable member for Stirling is part of the Government so we should not take any notice of what he says'. But let me quote what the Business Review Weekly of 19 August says. That publication quotes Rothschild Australia, which is hardly the sort of institution which sits with the Australian Labor Party in terms of the general debate. An article in that publication states:
`The advantages of tax minimisation-
this is the bad news for the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown) and others-
to companies are much reduced,' Rothschild says, adding that `tax losses will have virtually no value and tax avoidance schemes will become inconsequential'.

Is not that amazing? The old rule, the old scam that was the order of the day when honourable members opposite slouched around the national capital, has changed. There is now a positive benefit. The article goes on:
According to the guide, this is because companies will be able to pay fully franked dividends only by paying full tax. However-
there is a caution-
Rothschild says `Tax avoidance is so much part of the business psyche that it will be a long time before these truths are generally acknowledged.

In other words, it will take a long time for people to understand. I will just quote this article again because what is said is music to the ears of people in the Labor Party who have been saying this for a long time. The honourable member for Moore was involved in a couple of campaigns before he came into this place. So he went through, and saw from the outside, this tax scam. The article stated:
`The advantages of tax minimisation to companies are much reduced, ' . . . ` tax losses will have virtually no value and tax avoidance schemes will become inconsequential'.
Why? Because we have reformed the tax system. The article also stated:
`Tax avoidance is so much part of the business psyche . . . '

When did that psyche develop? This happened when those opposite were in government, when they slouched around the treasury bench and did nothing about tax rorts in this country. Honourable members opposite should not come in here and talk in a whingeing fashion about some technical changes. Let us talk about the substantial debate about tax in this country. Here we have the Business Review Weekly quoting the advice that Rothschild Australia gave to corporations that the arrangement of fully franked dividends now is the way to go. So the message is clear to a lot of people in Australia. That message is, `If you are a corporation be part of the tax system and we will treat you fairly'. The honourable member for Barker talked about individuals having to pay tax. If one had been one of the 250,000 people who lost their jobs in the last year that the lot opposite were in office, one would have loved to have paid tax but one could not do so because one did not have a job.

TALK.START.PARA: —And he talks about manufacturing industry.

—The manufacturing industry was crippled. So I say to honourable members opposite, `Do not try this on. Do not come in here and say that it is terrible that people are paying tax'. A lot of people in the community are very happy to have a job. Over a million more people now have jobs since we have been in office. In fact, 1,100,000 people have got jobs since we have been in office. Now they are paying tax, and we are using their tax revenue for good purposes. They can see the benefit in the community. But, what is more, we are not unmindful of how we need to continue the reform process. That is absolutely necessary. In this country, you either reform or get run over. The trouble with the Opposition is that it opposes all sorts of reform. It has a knee-jerk reaction to anything that might improve the lot of the ordinary person. We are happy to go about that reform process and we do, and we are on top of that reform process. We have set that process in train again. Just in case people opposite might think that all the reform has been done and there is nothing else on the agenda, I point out that there is more to do.

SPEECH.PARA: If one looks back 10 years, as the Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support (Mr Robert Brown) would know, when that famous speech was delivered to the Institute of Chartered Accountants in Australia by the honourable member for Goldstein on behalf of the then Treasurer, the present Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), when that famous speech about rants and rorts and tax avoidance was on-and the Opposition did nothing when in government as all that was happening-and when one looks at 1988 and we look at a tax system that now works, and works effectively, and people opposite are complaining about the level of tax collection, the fact is that we have a bigger work force and we are collecting money from that work force.

The other fact is that we also have a tax system in terms of the corporate area that is delivering. One cannot get up to the scams in the way one used to because we have given staff to the Commissioner of Taxation. We should remember how the previous tax commissioner must wish he was in office again because he was the one who said, `Give me the staff; give me the political will; and I can enforce the law'. He was treated with silence by the then government, by the honourable member for Bennelong and by the then Prime Minister, Mr Fraser. He was treated with silence because the then Government did not have the political will. It is not mythical. Those files that were in the bottom drawer of the Crown Solicitor's Office in Perth actually existed. They were not acted upon. I knew about them. I knew about all those arrangements and, interestingly, I knew about the Curran and Slutzkin schemes. I went to an institute of public accountants seminar the same year and they were selling Curran and Slutzkin schemes. As a matter of interest to the Minister at the table, I was giving a lecture on ethics in the accounting profession and, there they were, selling Curran and Slutzkin schemes around the Cottesloe Civic Centre. I said to myself, `What sort of arrangement is this? Where is the will in this country to be part of the social contract that says, `I belong to the best country in the world and I want to pay my membership fee but not under this Government?' What one did was to say, `I want to be part of it but I hope to duck all my responsibilities'.

We have changed that. We have said that this is the best country on earth; it is governed well. But we also want to make sure that the tax system works and that it works fairly and equitably; and we will introduce the necessary reforms. I have listed those reforms. It is important for people to understand that 10-year change from the time when the then Treasurer made that statement. I acknowledge that he was honest enough to say that there were problems. I have always acknowledged that. The then Treasurer, to be fair to people in this debate, in 1978 said:
There is a problem in terms of tax administration in this country and you, as professional accountants, have to play a part in that.

But they did not. Unfortunately, he did not have the political support in the then government to do something about it. But, to be absolutely fair to him, I note that he acknowledged it and was prepared to go on the public record about it. So, please do not come in here as members of the Opposition and talk about these matters because honourable members opposite have a very besmirched record. As I say, collective amnesia takes over. I have heard the Minister at the table give some great speeches, on matters of public importance, about their collective amnesia. They forget that they were in government when tax avoidance and evasion were the order of the day, but things have changed. Things have now changed because of the reforms.

I talked about capital gains, about fringe benefits and about tax averaging. In closing, what I say is that we should look down to where we are going. What we have said is that, because we have a prices and incomes policy, we want to talk to wage and salary earners in Australia and their representatives. We want to talk about how we can restrain wage increases in relation to tax cuts, and we are prepared to do that. The only question we now have to resolve in terms of those debates is the size of the tax cut.

We are not like the people opposite. We are not ideological clones of Margaret Thatcher. Margaret Thatcher brought about a tax cut-and what happened? The balance of payments went into a crisis because people spent the cuts on imports. That is why we did not cut taxes this year. We did not cut them this year because we wanted to make sure that we had import substitution restructure arrangements in place in Australia so that, when taxes are cut, people will spend money on Australian manufactured goods. SPEECH.PARA: There is this story about how apparently the Fraser Government allowed tax rorts to evolve and did not do anything about them. First, it legislated a great deal to deal with tax rorts. Some of that legislation was unpopular in the business community. Some of it led to people crossing the floor from the then government side of the House. Furthermore, some of those tax rorts did not start in the period of the Fraser Government. As a matter of fact, the bottom-of-the-harbour scheme started during the period of the Whitlam Government. So, if people want to make party political points about this, we are quite happy to take them on in that debate for I know that at the end of the day we will win the debate. The Government's view of a fair and equitable taxation system is apparently a tax system that not only taxes incomes very severely but also taxes almost everything else that exists in the community. The way the Government is going, it will soon be taxing the air we breathe. The Government is obsessed with tax, and that is apparently its definition of fair and equitable.

The points that I want to make relate to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4), not the rewriting of history. I particularly refer to the substantial changes to the business tax regime that this proposed legislation makes. These changes to the business tax regime have a very real effect on the cost of capital to businesses that want to go out, invest and build up not only the strength of their businesses but also the overall strength of our economy. It is particularly significant to small business for which I am shadow Minister, and it is in that context that I make these remarks.

Obviously any Australian who is concerned about the future of this country should be worried about the level of business investment that we are currently enduring. The latest Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) survey shows that there was a 2 per cent decline in the June quarter of 1988 in business investment. I think that is very worrying. Business investment is in real terms declining, not growing, at a time when living standards are also declining. Our only hope is to encourage investment so that living standards can rise; yet, in real terms, that business investment is declining.

The ABS predictions, on which I do not place a great deal of emphasis because one never knows really how accurate those predictions are going to be, are also now very encouraging, particularly for manufacturing and mining industries. Those predictions show that there could be a decline in investment of 2 per cent in the manufacturing industry and a decline in investment of 11 per cent in the mining industry. Now that may not happen. But it is a matter of concern to me that we do not have a buoyant investment climate in this country to help make a path for future prosperity for ordinary Australians.

The changes that the Government is bringing forward in the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) have to be measured against that climate. They have to be measured in the context whether these changes will help business investment or hinder business investment. The most significant change is to terminate the 3/5 depreciation concession introduced by the Fraser Government and to change depreciation provisions for primary industry and for some sections of the mining industry. The depreciation rate from now on will be determined, apparently, by the Commissioner of Taxation. That creates, no doubt, for many businesses a great deal of uncertainty, particularly as not all of them have been having a very happy relationship with the Commissioner of Taxation. This change to the depreciation provisions comes on top of a decision the Government made a year or, I think, two years ago, to abolish the investment allowance. So, naturally, these changes to the depreciation provisions and the investment allowance impose an additional cost on business of capital.

The Government's argument-let me put it before we get an interjection from the Minister-is that these increases in the cost of capital will be more than offset by changes to the company tax rate being reduced from 49 per cent to 39 per cent. Let me demonstrate to the House why this is simply not true. Let us take the Treasury's own estimates of the revenue effects of these changes. The Treasury estimates that there will be an increase in revenue from the business community brought about by the reduction in the level of company tax concurrent with the change to the depreciation provisions. The Government gets more money out of these changes, according to the Treasury, not less. That makes me just a little suspicious.

When we look at the situation for small business we see that the change in the depreciation provisions actually discriminates against them. This is the quick way the Treasurer (Mr Keating) puts more money into the pockets of the Government. Whilst small business loses the advantages of the 5:3 accelerated depreciation provisions, guess what? Unincorporated small businesses-about half of all the small businesses in this country-do not get the reduction in the company tax rate from 49 to 39 per cent because they are not incorporated. They have to be incorporated to pay company tax. They lose the advantages of the accelerated depreciation provisions and they maintain the same high rate of taxation. That is one way the Government manages to rake in a little additional revenue, this time from the small business sector.

It strikes me as very odd that a government would want to discriminate particularly against small unincorporated businesses in favour of big business. Why would a government want to do that? Small businesses have the greatest of difficulty surviving in unfortunate economic circumstances such as we have today. They do not have the capacity that big business has to pass on increased costs in the form of increased prices. They simply have to absorb the increased costs. As far as the business sector is concerned, the Government's tax policy discriminates against unincorporated small businesses. It beats me why it would want to do that.

Let us look at the bigger end of town. Let us look at those companies which are incorporated and analyse the Government's argument that by reducing the company tax rate and taking away the depreciation concessions that businesses used to have, somehow business will be better off. I have already mentioned the Treasury figures. I refer now to the only analysis that I have been able to discover of the effects of these changes to business taxes. That analysis has been done by the Business Council of Australia, which has produced a couple of indices that are very revealing. It has a capital cost index known as the Kopits measure, which is the only consistent measure we have of capital costs produced by the business sector in Australia. It shows that since the May mini-Budget, when these changes were announced and implemented, the level of company taxation in the form of the capital cost has actually increased slightly. The index is consistent with the Treasury's estimate that these changes are going to bring in more revenue. The change to the 5:3 depreciation provisions has increased the cost of capital for equipment to a much greater extent than the decrease in the company tax rate has offset it. That is not what I think. That is not what the Liberal Party or the National Party thinks. That is what the Business Council of Australia thinks. Let me add to that by quoting the Business Council. It has said:
The new system will effectively be more discouraging for investment in longer-life equipment.

That means that tax, in particular on machinery, will increase markedly. Why would the Government want to change the taxation system so that it discriminates against longer life equipment? Is there some peculiar reason why we should be encouraging every business in Australia to invest in short life equipment? It really strikes me as quite bizarre that it has made that sort of change, which increases the cost of capital to our businesses.

The Kopits index is not the only measure that the Business Council uses. It also uses the King and Fullerton methodology, which shows an even starker picture. Using this methodology, and depending on the assumptions that one makes about the cost of capital, the effective tax rate for businesses has risen by between 3 per cent and 7 per cent. That is a very substantial increase in the cost of capital, always bearing in mind that we have this very unfortunate investment climate today in Australia. When we talk of an unfortunate investment climate, increases in the cost of capital and effective tax rates for businesses, we cannot walk away from international comparisons. In an increasingly inter-dependent world, as a nation we always have to compete for capital with other parts of the world. Multinational companies, who constitute something like 50 per cent of all world trade, will make investment decisions on the basis of where they can get the best return. Obviously, if we want employment and economic growth we want those companies to make that decision here in Australia. We want their investment in Australia; we do not want them going offshore and investing in some other country.

Using the Kopits index that I referred to earlier, the Business Council of Australia compares Australia with 16 other countries. It shows that, of those 16 major economies, Australia has the second highest business tax rate. Only Labor New Zealand has a higher level of business taxation. No wonder the New Zealand Government is now so unpopular with its people. Countries that have lower business taxation-in other words, countries that have a lower cost of capital and provide a greater incentive to invest within their boundaries-include neighbouring nations such as Malaysia, Singapore, the Philippines and Thailand. It also includes other major Western economies such as the United States, Canada and the United Kingdom. The honourable member for Stirling referred earlier to how terrible he thought the Thatcher Government was-a government that has overseen one of the greatest economic revolutions certainly in Britain's history and perhaps the greatest in the Western world. Not surprisingly, that country has a much lower cost of capital than is imposed here in Australia.

One could use not just the Kopits methodology but also the King and Fullerton methodology. It shows exactly the same picture. King and Fullerton, depending on what assumptions one uses, estimate that the overall effective marginal tax rate for business in Australia is 48 per cent. In the United States it is 42 per cent: in the United Kingdom-Mrs Thatcher's country-it is 37.5 per cent: in West Germany it is 39.4 per cent; in Japan 48.8 per cent; in Sweden-that great model for the Labor Party-it is 37.3 per cent. Perhaps since Sweden is such a great model the Government might start getting taxation off the backs of businesses in this country and follow at least that one aspect of the way the Swedish economy works, if not a number of other aspects.

It is not surprising that we have enormous difficulty attracting investment in the business sector in Australia. We must do what we can to encourage investment in the business sector. Yet the comparative level of effective tax for businesses in Australia is higher than in most of our competing countries. New Zealand is the only exception that I have so far been able to discover but there may be one or two others. The fact is that we are right at the top of the league when it comes to high effective rates of tax on business and therefore the high cost of capital to our business community. No wonder we have something of an investment drought in Australia. We have a long way to go. We must do something to provide more stimulation for business investment in this country.

In conclusion, I wish to refer to one other aspect of this legislation, that is, the introduction of a tax on non-cash fringe benefits. This will have a very real effect on the small business sector-that sector against which the other section of the legislation, as I have demonstrated, clearly discriminates. The first point I would make, in concert with the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock), is that this tax on non-cash fringe benefits is retrospective and that the 3 1/2-year delay between the press release being put out and the legislation actually appearing in this House is nothing short of absolutely disgraceful.

I remind the House that this part of the legislation relates principally to individuals such as Tupperware salesmen and Avon ladies, as they are described-people who go out and make a bit of extra money by selling for big companies. How does the Government expect those individuals to have been making provision over the last 3 1/2 years-it will be four years by the time they have to pay up-for non-cash fringe benefits they received when they did not have any idea what the details of the legislation would be? All they will get is a bill from the Australian Commissioner of Taxation saying, `By the way, over the last four years you have received all of these non-cash fringe benefits and this is how much you will have to pay'. People will say to themselves, `Oh, we did not know what the legislation would contain until just the other day when it was introduced in the House of Representatives. Back in 1985 or 1986 we had no idea'.

We are not talking in this context about sophisticated big businesses; we are talking about many people working from home to supplement their incomes-people who have been given incentives and rewards for successful selling efforts. They may have received free jars of jam or something like that on which they have to pay tax. They may have received bigger things, such as a trip to the Gold Coast, a television set or, in extreme cases when they have had enormous success, even a car. Suddenly plopped through the letterbox will come another unexpected and gigantic bill from the Treasurer. It is a pernicious form of taxation. It is pernicious to delay this legislation for effectively nearly four years.

There is something intellectually inconsistent about this legislation. One could argue that non-cash fringe benefits are similar to other sorts of fringe benefits affected by the fringe benefits tax. We all remember that it is the company-the employer-that pays the fringe benefits tax; not the employee. I submit that this is a very curious concept of tax law, but there it is: that is what the Government has chosen to do. In this case, why is it that the company that provides the non-cash fringe benefit does not pay the tax? In this case it is the individual-the poor old housewife who is trying to supplement her family income at a time when interest rates are rising and real incomes are falling-who pays it. Why is it that she ends up paying the Treasurer the money rather than her employer, the company for whom she is doing a bit of additional selling? That is completely irrational and intellectually incoherent. One wonders what is the real motive behind it all. It is an intellectual fiasco.

TALK.START.PARA: —How can you say `intellectual'? You don't even understand the word.

—Talking of intellectual fiascos, I notice one sitting over there. How does the Government actually work out the taxable value of something that someone may not particularly want? Let us say that somebody manages to sell a certain number of handbags on behalf of a company and gets two jars of jam as a reward, apart from ordinary payment. How will the Australian Taxation Office calculate the value of something like that? Are people going to send the prize or the incentive back to the company? That creates a monstrous question. Heaven knows how the Government and the Tax Office will answer that. Much of this legislation simply underlies the Government's utter obsession with taxing everything that moves. How ever will we get this economy moving again and how ever will we inspire Australians to invest with such a tax regime?

SPEECH.PARA: Today I wish to speak about people in rural areas. Recently the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt) told the House that over the 5 1/2 years that this Government has been in power people in rural areas have lost about $1,000m in rural assistance. TALK.START.PARA: —They haven't got any sympathy for them.

—The Government does not have any sympathy. The honourable member for Gwydir listed some of the things that have been done to the rural sector this year alone. First of all, there has been a $90m loss due to increased inspection charges to primary producers; a $37m loss due to the abolition of the superphosphate subsidy; and a $31m cut in wool promotion over the next three years. We all know that the price of wool is high and thank God that it is. If it were not up at the moment our overseas earnings would be reduced drastically. —It is scandalous.

As a result of inflation they cannot do the things that they might have done 12 months earlier. The situation is serious. SPEECH.PARA: That the Acting Speaker no longer enjoys the confidence of the House.

As I said a moment ago, I move this motion with some regret because we know that Madam Speaker is absent from this chamber for reasons that are beyond her control. Mr Acting Speaker, you have assumed the mantle of responsibility which is properly hers and which is critical to the conduct of this parliamentary system. Over the days that she has been absent, which began on the last sitting day of last week, there has been a great deal of concern on this side of the House about what we see as a constant preference demonstrated by you in your rulings, particularly during Question Time and in the proceedings immediately thereafter. That concern culminated today in what we see as a failure to respond adequately to the behaviour in the House a little while ago of the Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support (Mr Robert Brown). We regarded his behaviour as absolutely reprehensible.

The nature and manner of name calling across this chamber, as my colleague the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) identified the other day, is something that Madam Speaker would not accept. Yet you, Mr Acting Speaker, have been prepared to condone on six occasions the name calling that the Minister pursued at Question Time today. On each sitting day there have been instances where members on this side of the House have felt that Ministers have not been responding to questions as the general purport of Standing Orders requires. Certainly nobody has changed the actual format of our Standing Orders to precisely define the nature of questions, the length of questions and the relevance of questions. But you know, Mr Acting Speaker, that there have been a succession of rulings by Speakers-I have a whole horde of them here-which have required Question Time to be conducted so that the public at large, the electors who puts us in this place, can properly feel that Ministers are under scrutiny. What we have seen-even accelerated this week-is a deliberate ploy by the Government, each day with a different barb. It wants to pick up a theme this way or a theme that way. Every day we have been three-quarters of the way through Question Time before we on this side of the House have had four questions at best processed through the system.

When there was an Acting Treasurer last week the Government decided that the only way it could get away with it was to provide very brief answers to questions. Suddenly we found we were getting 14, 15 or 16 questions a day-similar to the numbers that were regularly the case when the coalition was in government. Your responsibility, Mr Acting Speaker, is to ensure that Question Time is conducted in a fair and proper way. There is a capacity for you as Speaker, irrespective of the actual words within the Standing Orders, to determine whether Ministers are abusing the process of Question Time.

Mr Acting Speaker, the first complaint we have about you is your failure to address the Minister as soon as you should have to require a withdrawal of derogatory remarks about members on this side of the House. The second and more fundamental complaint we have is your failure to require Ministers to pursue properly the matter of Question Time. I find it quite interesting that all the Ministers who are responsible have now left the chamber. That is one of the problems in this place. No wonder the electors are moving away in droves. No wonder the voters of Oxley voted with their pens against a Government that so demonstrably has lost touch with ordinary Australians.

We have seen the arrogance of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe). Each one has pontificated about how difficult life is for ordinary Australians. They would not have a clue and they are not worried about finding out. They are not interested in the life education program. They are not interested in the absolutely deplorable disparity in the conditions of living of the two couples the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker) identified. What they are trying to do is to say, `Never mind, out there Australia, we are looking after you'. Mr Acting Speaker, you have a responsibility in this place to ensure that if answers are to be given to questions they are given as answers and that Ministers do not make policy statements, as they do consistently and persistently. The whole process of Question Time has degenerated. There is never a question from the Government side that is not a dorothy dixer. There is never a Question Time when Ministers do not act as though it is an opportunity to make a policy statement.

I put to you, Mr Acting Speaker, that you have powers under the Standing Orders. It is not a matter of looking to see whether there is a particular standing order that you can apply. The substance of our want of confidence motion in you is that you are not exercising the discretion which is yours by virtue of the office in which you now sit. The way in which you administer this place determines ultimately whether Ministers answer questions as they should, whether Ministers and members of the Government can misbehave and get away with it, and whether the Parliament treats you and therefore whether the community treats us as parliamentarians with respect. The sad product of today is that the processes of this place have degenerated beyond that which I can recall in my few years in this place.

As my colleague the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) has said, you were prepared to accept remarks by the Minister, who repeatedly slandered my colleague the Deputy Leader of the National Party, the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd), across the table, as though his remarks did not matter. He is a Minister and therefore he was not going to be sanctioned the way the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown) was five minutes after proceedings began. At the commencement of proceedings you obviously had decided that you were going to condemn us on this side of the House. We accept that there are times when the behaviour of members on both sides might stretch exactly what some would require of members of this place; but you have to understand, Mr Acting Speaker, that if we are pushed by Ministers abusing Question Time, if we are going to be slandered by Ministers standing at the despatch box, being told by them-as the Treasurer so frequently does-that we are sleazebags or a whole litany of offending names, and you, as Acting Speaker, do not sit them down, you cannot expect us to treat them seriously. What happened today-it has unfortunately happened now on successive sitting days-is that we have had Ministers giving inordinately long answers and abusing Question Time. There is no other responsible way by which we on this side of the House can show those Ministers that we are concerned that they are abusing the process of the Parliament.

What this comes back to, Mr Acting Speaker, is that you have an ability within the interpretation of Standing Orders to sit anybody in this place down at any time. You have an ability to require anybody-a Minister, the Prime Minister, the Leader of the Opposition and honourable members on both sides of the House-to sit in his place. The Standing Orders give you the ability, when you rise, to require anybody else to sit down. It is that power that we call on you to exercise and to do so impartially.

In the last few days there have been visits by members of other Parliaments. I have spoken to them. They said that they are concerned that the process of our democracy seems to be prejudiced because there is not the obvious impartiality in the chair that there is in their Houses; for example, in the House of Westminster. The other day we saw a number of visiting parliamentarians from the United Kingdom. Several expressed their amazement that the Speaker, and you as Acting Speaker, were not totally without party affiliation. They expressed concern that the Speaker still seems to have automatic affiliation with politics. We have come to accept that in this Parliament. But, Mr Acting Speaker, when you are in the chair you have to be above that. You cannot be a creature of the Government; you cannot be a member of the Australian Labor Party. You are the leader, the Speaker, of this House of Parliament. You are the person who sets the standard. If you do not call on a Minister to sit down and require him to act as you require us to act, it is not just you that suffers; it is the parliamentary system that suffers.

Mr Acting Speaker, I put to you quite sincerely that today, above all days, you have failed in that task. I think that today, in the way in which you have called on and repeatedly named members of the Opposition benches, the way in which you condoned repeated abuses of what are the accepted practices of questions without notice, and the way you were prepared to allow the Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support to abuse my colleague the Deputy Leader, without even requiring him to sit in his place, is not acceptable. You must understand that unless you are prepared to act impartially and are prepared to perform-

The second issue, which is the fundamental one, concerns the degree to which you, have an ability, within our Standing Orders, to require Ministers and others to sit down. It might be worth while referring to a few of your predecessors' decisions. On 19 February 1975 Mr Speaker Cope was prepared to act according to his conscience. For his bravery, being a member of the Labor Party-I suppose one could call it timidity considering the consequences of his action-and for being prepared to accept that his role was more important than being a member of the Labor Party, he was dismissed from the chair. TALK.START.PARA: —Assassinated.

—As my colleague says, he was assassinated. Prior to that instance, Mr Speaker Cope even required Prime Minister Whitlam to be seated. I ask the Minister not to make a point about the point of order and, in proceeding with his answer, to draw his answer to a conclusion.

The point I make to you, Mr Acting Speaker, is that unless you are prepared to require Ministers to treat questions without notice as they are intended to be treated within the purport of our Standing Orders, this place comes into disrepute. You failed to do so today. You failed to require the Minister to withdraw. You failed to take action when he did not withdraw. You allowed him to repeat various innuendos, slanders and inferences on six successive occasions before you finally got a withdrawal from him. On a number of occasions you have allowed Ministers to abuse totally the general intent of Question Time. Instead of requiring them to answer questions, you have allowed them to make policy statements. Standing order 144 outlines the ways in which Ministers are required to be relevant. That component of our Standing Orders states that questions may be put to Ministers relating to public affairs. They are able to be put in a certain defined way. There are certain requirements in standing order 144 which talks about general rules applying to questions. It is important that you understand that, although they apply to the questioner, there is a responsibility on the Minister in his response. Standing order 145 states:

I put it to you, Mr Acting Speaker, that this Government no longer treats the statements that we all made as Ministers in this place in the way it should. When Ministers make a policy comment it should not be in answer to a dorothy dixer. This Government abuses the process constantly. It never gets a question from its own side that is not a dorothy dixer. We cannot accept a practice, whether in the conduct of Question Time or in your action towards a Minister or all the collective members of the Opposition, when we find that consistently we on this side of the House are either required to withdraw our remarks or are told that we are to desist from whatever we are doing. However, the Ministers persist in what we regard as totally non-responsible behaviour in the conduct of their responsibilities in answering questions.

Mr Acting Speaker, we do not accept that you have been impartial today. We regard your actions today as being far more conducive to accepting your membership of the Australian Labor Party than accepting your responsibility as a dispassionate and independent chairman of this place. I mentioned to you, either yesterday or the day before, my concern at what I regarded as a tendency to slant your requirements of the Government in a more sympathetic way than your requirements of the Opposition. It is absolutely essential that if you are to sit in that chair, be it temporarily or not, that you act in a way which is above any suggestion of partiality. On this side of the House we feel very strongly that the quality, manner and tone of the Parliament depends ultimately on the way in which you chair these proceedings. We believe that you have failed in that task. We regard it as important that once again you exercise your responsibilities in a way which requires the Ministers and members of the Government to behave in a manner identical to that which you require of us on this side of the House. Unless you do so, it is not possible for us to regard you and the office you hold with the respect that our democratic system requires.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Speaker, I second the motion. I support this censure motion because we are now talking about the future of the parliamentary process. DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN NATIONAL RAILWAYS COMMISSION AMENDMENT BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Willis, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Australian National Railways Commission Act 1983 to implement the Government's reform package for the Australian National Railways Commission (AN). The major elements in the package of amendments proposed in the Australian National Railways Commission Amendment Bill are to widen AN's powers to expand the scope of its business activities, to extend the planning and accountability mechanisms which apply to AN and to remove most of the remaining day-to-day controls over AN's activities.

Reform of its business enterprises is an important element of the Government's third term agenda. The Government recognises that its transport and communications business enterprises must operate as efficiently and effectively as possible if Australia is to succeed in reshaping key sectors of the economy and in improving our international competitiveness. The Federal Government's railway, AN, provides an important element of both the east-west transport service linking our major manufacturing and export centres of Sydney and Melbourne to Adelaide and Perth, and of the north-south corridor through Alice Springs to Darwin. On the mainland, AN operates non-metropolitan freight and passenger services in South Australia, extending from South Australia to Kalgoorlie in the west, to Alice Springs in the north and to Broken Hill in the east. In Tasmania, AN operates freight services. AN's mainland business competes for freight traffic with the road operations of the major freight forwarders, independent `truckies' and with coastal shipping. It also competes with coach and bus passenger services. Interstate transport accounts for more than 75 per cent of AN's commercial freight business. Changes to AN's legislation in 1983 designed to promote AN's role as a business undertaking have already done much to put AN on a more commercial footing. Over the past five years, AN has greatly improved its performance-its call on the taxpayer has been reduced in real terms by 66 per cent, and it is expected to break even on its mainland freight operations this financial year.

In relation to AN's Tasmanian operations the Government announced in May 1988 that it would continue to support Tasrail for the next five years. AN expects to break even on Tasrail operations by 1993-94. The reform package is designed to consolidate the achievements to date and provide AN with an environment in which it can achieve the highest possible level of operational and financial efficiency while continuing its move to profitability. It will continue the process of commercialisation initiated in 1983 allowing AN greater freedom to manage and greater flexibility to compete in the market-place. The Government considers that AN should have a further opportunity to consolidate its position and improve its performance before more changes are made. Greater freedom to manage means that AN should be freed from most of the remaining day-to-day controls over its activities.

Thus the Bill amongst other things removes the requirement for AN to obtain ministerial approval to enter into contracts; removes the requirement to obtain the Treasurer's approval for the terms and conditions of individual borrowings, investments or banking arrangements; and empowers AN to recommend an auditor of its choice. AN will remain subject to Loan Council processes for its borrowings.

Removal of day-to-day controls will not, however, mean any lessening of accountability. AN will continue to be required to provide regularly to the Minister strategic corporate plans for consideration and response; and to work towards an overall financial target agreed in advance by the Minister.

In addition, this Bill will require AN to advise the Minister of any matter which significantly affects the outlook as established in the corporate plan as soon as possible after such matters become known. Any additional costs arising from government ownership for items such as superannuation and auditing requirements will be taken into account in determining AN's financial target. AN will continue to report on its financial performance through an annual report.

AN must be able to consider offering the same broad range of services as its competitors and have the ability to respond rapidly to changes in the market and to consider business opportunities as they arise. Accordingly, this Bill widens the scope of associated or supplementary business activities into which AN might consider expanding. Commissioners will now be subject to dismissal for ongoing underperformance-in addition to current grounds such as misbehaviour, mental illness et cetera-in line with the emphasis on accountability for results. The Managing Director will be appointed by the Minister after receiving a recommendation from the Commission. Terms and conditions of employment for the Managing Director will be a matter for the Commission. The Commission will consult with the Remuneration Tribunal about the remuneration package for the Managing Director in line with the amendment of the Remuneration Tribunals Act introduced in the Government Business Enterprise (Miscellaneous Reforms) Bill (Part V). The transition to the new arrangements is expected to be completed by July next year.

Finally, the legislation we are proposing will make no calls on the revenues of the Commonwealth. Improvements in the performance of AN that result from the implementation of the reform package, of which this Bill is a part, will benefit taxpayers by further reducing AN's call on the Budget. I commend the Bill to the House. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Willis, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Federal Airports Corporation Act 1986. The establishment of the Federal Airports Corporation has been one of the major aviation initiatives of the Hawke Government. The decision to establish the Corporation recognised a long overdue requirement to put the management of Australia's major airports on a proper commercial footing. Accordingly, the Federal Airports Corporation Act has provided for the Corporation to have a clear commercial charter and the ability to respond to the infrastructure needs of the aviation industry.

On 1 January 1988 the Federal Airports Corporation (FAC) assumed responsibility for the operation of 17 major airports throughout Australia. These included the primary and secondary airports in each of the State capital cities as well as Coolangatta and Launceston airports. The Government announced in the Budget that it had decided that the FAC should assume responsibility for a further group of airports. The FAC is to take over the operation of the Alice Springs, Mount Isa and Mackay airports. It will also assume responsibility for the civil aviation facilities at Darwin, Canberra and Townsville airports. The Darwin, Canberra and Townsville airports are joint user airports which serve both defence and civil aviation purposes. The Federal Airports Corporation Act currently provides for the Corporation to operate airports which are declared as Federal airports for purposes of the legislation. The Act does not specifically provide for the Corporation to enter into arrangements for the shared operation of joint user airports. Moreover, the Act requires that Federal airports be on land which is owned by the Corporation. The Bill before the House provides for the amendment of the Federal Airports Corporation Act in order to provide a framework within which the Government can determine arrangements for the operation, by the Corporation and the Department of Defence, of the Darwin, Canberra and Townsville airports.

The Bill also provides a basis on which any future transfers to the Corporation of civil facilities on joint user aerodromes may be undertaken. The Corporation will be able to enter into arrangements with the Commonwealth under which the Corporation will participate in the operation of jointly used areas and will be able to levy charges where it has financial involvement in these areas. This provision would have application in circumstances where the primary responsibility for areas such as runways and taxiways is not vested in the Corporation.

The Bill provides for the Minister to determine that ownership of the land on which a Federal airport is located need not be transferred to the Corporation. The Corporation could instead lease the area from the Commonwealth or enter into other arrangements for it to control that area. The Government considers that the arrangements for the operation of joint user aerodromes for which this Bill provides will enable both the commercial operation of designated areas by the Corporation as well as providing the necessary safeguards to ensure that the integrity of defence operations is maintained. I present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.
