The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Wheat Marketing Act 1984 to reflect the recommendations of the Royal Commission into Grain Storage, Handling and Transport. The Royal Commission was established in October 1986 by the Commonwealth and mainland States. Its charter was to identify the most efficient and cost effective integrated system for the provision of grain storage, handling, transport and port terminal services and to make recommendations on changes necessary to put such a system into effect. In its final report the Commission concluded that there were significant areas where the present system was not providing the best service to grain growers. It also found that significant savings of around $10 per tonne could be achieved from a more flexible and competitive distribution system. This translates to total resource cost savings across Australia annually of around $100m. To achieve these savings the Commission recommended that grain marketers and growers be given greater choice in selecting their least cost grain distribution paths and that greater competition be permitted in the provision of grain distribution services, including all elements of the grain distribution system-marketing boards, storage and handling, land transport, and ports and shipping.

The Royal Commission proposed that marketing boards take more responsibility for the efficiency of the grain distribution system, particularly the minimisation of storage, handling and transport costs, and the passing of actual costs of port services and sea transport back to growers to encourage competition between ports. It also recommended that marketing boards be given the capacity to exercise choice over licensed receivers. Similarly in the storage and handling area, the thrust of the Commission's report is toward greater competition and grower choice, with the main recommendations involving the removal of sole receival rights, commercialisation of bulk handling authorities, and bringing them under the Trade Practices Act.

In the land transport area, the recommendations are aimed to encourage greater competition between road and rail and allow growers wider choice. They include removing restrictions on the use of road for grain transport, the removal of the $2.50 surcharge charged by Australian National Railways in South Australia, greater commercialisation of rail services, and bringing railway services under the Trade Practices Act. In addition, the Commission recommended specific targeted funding for local roads in the short term and, in the longer term, the establishment of an efficient road user charge and funding allocation system. For ports and shipping there was support for the continuation of moves to commercialise port authorities and support for more competition in the provision of port services.

The Government strongly endorses the Commission's recommendations and is moving to implement them as quickly as possible. It is continuing to build on reforms to improve the efficiency of the road transport industry. Agreement has been reached with State and Territory governments on a single set of rules for the country's trucking industry. The Government has also introduced a new five-year road funding program which provides for specific assistance to national arterial roads. The Commission's recommendations in regard to rail services are also well in hand as they apply to Australian National Railways.

The amendments currently before the Parliament flow from the Commission's recommendations for the operation of marketing boards. In amending the Wheat Marketing Act in advance of the broader reforms being proposed for wheat marketing generally, the Government is clearly signalling its concern that the grains industry benefit as early as possible from the advantages of a system which offers greater flexibility and choice. Both the Australian Wheat Board (AWB) and the Grains Council of Australia endorse this approach. Improved efficiency and effectiveness in the grain distribution sector will of course have important flow-on effects for the competitive marketing of grain generally, both in Australia and overseas. The proposed amendments therefore represent an important step in achieving a framework within which the Australian wheat industry can effectively meet the challenges of the future.

Specifically the Bill provides for the AWB to enter into contract for services relating to grain distribution and broadens the scope of the term `authorised receiver' to encompass all bodies corporate with whom the Australian Wheat Board has a contract for wheat receival. This means that no longer will the Wheat Board be constrained from dealing with bodies other than the sole receiver authorised in each State as at present. Rather, the Board will be able to contract with whomever will provide the best returns for growers. On the subject of returns to growers, the Bill provides a clear statement that the principal object of the Board shall be to maximise net returns to growers from the marketing of wheat and that this should be the overriding principle in the performance of its other functions.

The Board will also be required to provide disaggregated charges for these services in its accounts to growers to the extent that this is possible and does not incur significant net additional costs. Growers will therefore be more aware of the costs associated with the individual services employed to receive, handle and transport their grain and will be in a better position to make choices as to their least cost grain path. This being said, I do not anticipate, and neither did the Royal Commission, that there will be dramatic changes in the short term. The current bulk handling authorities will remain the dominant providers of storage and handling services and road and rail transport will largely retain their existing tonnages. However, they will be exposed to competition and face pressure to contain their costs.

What is envisaged is a progressive redirection of grain flows through the most efficient storage and handling facilities, and a reallocation of the grain transportation task between road and rail so that each undertakes that part of the task for which it is best suited. These and other changes announced by the Government are significant in opening the door to competitive pressures. Nevertheless, I acknowledge that the bulk of the Commission's recommendations fall within the ambit of the States. I am therefore hopeful that the States will follow suit, as I have urged them to do. In this respect I am encouraged by recent announcements that the New South Wales Government has adopted the Royal Commission's recommendations and will also be introducing changes to its system.

The passage of the Bill will involve no costs to the Commonwealth. On the contrary, it will facilitate the development of a more cost effective grain distribution system, with increased industry efficiencies and benefits to the community generally. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill and commend the Bill to honourable members.

I would like to take this opportunity briefly to mention the present position in relation to the possible use of the Child Support Agency for collection of maintenance for State wards. PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Howe, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill contains amendments to the Social Security Act 1947 and minor consequential amendments to other Acts. The amendments are to implement decisions announced in the 1988 May Statement and the 1988-89 Budget Speech, and to introduce certain other minor amendments. The amendments to the Social Security Act include further, major steps in the implementation of policy changes flowing from the Social Security Review established in 1985. These steps, relating to payments for children, sole parent programs and the long term unemployed are further tangible evidence of the Government's commitment to a fairer distribution of income in Australia.

It was the Hawke Labor Government which placed the abolition of child poverty on the political agenda of this country-no other political grouping was pressing it as a priority. This Government deliberately chose not simply to make the attack on child poverty a priority; we invited the Australian people to judge us on our performance in delivering on that priority. This Bill contains a range of further measures in the progressive implementation of the centrepiece of our attack on child poverty-the families package. That package draws on the work of the Social Security Review in its first issues paper Assistance to Families with Children. Rates of family allowance supplement (FAS) and child payments to pensioners and beneficiaries will rise in December 1988. For each child younger than 13, families will receive $24 a week, an increase of $2. For each child aged 13 to 15, a payment of $31 a week will be made, up by $3. Six hundred thousand families with 1,200,000 children will be better off as a result.

The Bill will implement the first steps to achieving an integrated child payment. Family allowance, child disability allowance, double orphan's pension and family allowance supplement, including rent assistance, are to be integrated to achieve the one fortnightly payment for children. Next year we will take the further step of integrating the additional benefit paid for children with this fortnightly payment. The integration of family allowance, child disability allowance, double orphan's pension and family allowance supplement will avoid the possibility of FAS becoming a marginal welfare payment-as occurred with the old family income supplement. There will be the one payment, payable in respect of 80 per cent of Australian children, the rate of which will vary depending on factors such as: the number of children in the family; the income of the parents; the special difficulties faced by families caring for children with disabilities, or those whose natural parents are not able to care for them; and the costs faced by families who have young children from a multiple birth.

The basis for income testing of FAS will be changed. Currently the income test, which operates on income received in the previous four weeks, encourages perceptions of the payment as a welfare measure. It is difficult to administer and creates anomalies for many low paid workers whose income fluctuates. The Bill will implement an income test based on the taxable income of the claimant and her or his spouse. This change will substantially simplify understanding of the payment and enable simpler administration. The change highlights the importance of FAS in our tax transfer system-making FAS, in every sense, as good as a tax cut for low income families. The move to taxable income as the basis of income testing from 29 December 1988 effectively indexes the income test threshold for FAS. Payments in 1989 will generally be based on taxable income for the year ended 30 June 1988. As from 1 January 1990, the threshold for this income test is to be indexed in line with the consumer price index (CPI) increase in the previous financial year. This will ensure that income increases that match price increases will not erode child payments or contribute to work disincentives and poverty traps. One hundred and seventy-nine thousand families, including 430,000 children, will benefit from this constructive measure.

The Bill contains three measures to ensure that child payments are directed to those families in most need by improving targeting and reducing the scope for abuse of the system. First, an assets test is to be introduced in establishing entitlement to the family allowance supplement. Like the income test, the assets test will take CPI increases into account. From the last payday in 1988 FAS will not be payable to a person when the value of the assets of the person and her or his spouse exceeds $300,000. Property excluded from the pensions assets test, such as the family home, will also be excluded from the FAS assets test.

Second, family allowance supplement will not be payable in respect of any child who has unearned taxable income in excess of the tax free threshold which is currently $416 per annum. This will prevent parents from qualifying for FAS by divesting themselves of income in favour of their children and ensure proper targeting of the payment. Third, payment of additional benefit and mother's-guardian's allowance to an unemployment or sickness beneficiary who is contributing to the maintenance of a child who is not in his or her care will cease. It is both more efficient and more equitable that such payments be made directly to the custodian through the pensions, benefits or child allowance systems. In its third issues paper, Bringing Up Children Alone, the Social Security Review highlighted the difficulties faced by sole parent families-difficulties of unfair and inaccurate stigmatisation, of inadequate income and labour market barriers. The Government has addressed these problems in a systematic way. We have introduced the child support scheme and will proceed, next year, with Stage 2 of that scheme. The families package has delivered major increases in payments for sole parents.

In the Budget the Government announced the introduction of the JET scheme-jobs, education and training-for sole parents. JET will provide comprehensive advice, assistance, labour market training, education and child care. The JET scheme is designed on the basis that sole parents usually receive pensions for relatively short periods-until they find work or repartner. It will be targeted to those sole parents most at risk of long term dependence on pension or benefit: teenagers, those whose youngest child has just commenced school and those whose youngest child is 14 or over.

This Bill contains changes to complement the introduction of JET. The supporting parent's benefit and widow's pension class A will be replaced by a uniform sole parent's pension. This change rids the social security system of categories of benefit based on moral judgments of the worth of individuals and provides a pension which acknowledges the present need for support of sole parents, regardless of the cause of the sole parenthood. The sole parent's pension will be available to all those to whom widow's pension class A or supporting parent's benefit would have been available.

The new pension will also extend support to a small number of people who had previously been ineligible for benefit because of the requirement for them to have legal custody, such as some grandmothers. However, this extension will be limited to those who have cared for a particular child for 12 months or more-in order to ensure that the availability of sole parent's pension does not distort established patterns of foster care or otherwise unduly encourage single people to take on the care of children for whom they have no formal responsibility.

In Issues Paper No 4, Income Support for the Unemployed in Australia-Towards a More Active System, the Social Security Review dealt with the unemployed. Flowing from that paper, in the Budget the Government announced the implementation of New-Start, a comprehensive program to assist unemployment beneficiaries who have been receiving benefit for 12 months or more. New-Start will consist of a number of policy and legislative elements which together recognise the need to overcome the self-perpetuating situation of joblessness, poverty and dependence often encountered by people who remain out of work for long periods. Their job skills become eroded or irrelevant, employers are increasingly reluctant to take them on, their self-confidence and motivation evaporate and they become enmeshed in a cycle of financial hardship and dependence on social security payments. New-Start introduces through this Bill an employment entry payment of $100 which will be payable to people in this category when they return to full time employment. It is to help them meet the short term costs of moving into and retaining full time work, such as clothing and transport costs and union membership, and is payable only once within a 12 month period.

This group of people will also benefit from a waiver of the waiting period which currently applies should they need to claim unemployment benefit again within three months of the cancellation of their last benefit. This reduces the disincentive of moving from benefit to short term full time work or work of uncertain duration. Unemployment beneficiaries will also be able to undertake a wider range of activities which promote employability while still retaining eligibility for benefit. By allowing them to participate up to certain limits and with CES approval in full time training courses or voluntary work, the barrier to people attempting to improve and maintain their job skills will be reduced. New-Start is an imaginative strategy for improving the prospects for the long term unemployed to reintegrate into the work force. It will deliver real opportunities to a group of people who have been excluded from the benefits of the massive job growth we have seen in Australia over the last five years.

Job search allowance is paid to unemployed young people aged 16 and 17 years subject to an income test on both their own and their parents' income. This Bill increases the threshold for that parental income test by $950 to $16,950 a year and introduces indexation of the threshold in line with increases in average weekly earnings. This action prevents the undermining of the entitlement through routine income increases while still maintaining the intention of the income test. Children in authorised foster care will be exempted altogether from the application of the parental income test on job search allowance entitlement.

The young homeless allowance which is payable to young unemployed job search allowance recipients is to be increased in this Bill to $27.85 a week so that the two allowances combined will be the same rate as that paid under Austudy to 16- and 17-year-old students who are independent and living away from home. Certain student children who attract the payment of defined allowances will be deemed to be covered by the family allowance provisions in 1988 so as to retain family allowance supplement entitlement.

This Bill introduces a measure to provide special support to newly released prisoners on their reintegration into society. To meet the special adjustment problems of newly released prisoners, especially urgent housing, food, clothing and transport costs and the like, a double payment of benefit will be made in respect of their first week after claiming. Compassionate considerations aside, it is simply not in society's interests to have released prisoners reoffending because of lack of immediate support. In conjunction with this measure the Government is consulting the States to achieve effective coordination between prisons and my Department to ensure released prisoners obtain the income support they need when they need it.

An important segment of the Bill in terms of the Government's high priority for protecting the rights of the individual in the social security process is the one dealing with the gathering and disclosure of information. This segment introduces a clearer statement of how the Department of Social Security's information gathering and disclosing powers are to operate. The measure is in response to a perception by some in the community that the current powers can trespass upon the privacy of individuals, especially those who are no longer clients of the Department. The powers to compulsorily obtain information will be limited by provisions of the Bill. These limitations will be additional to those already contained in the legislation. Further, the powers conferred by the Social Security Act in this respect will be exercised in accordance with the principles of the Privacy Bill. Compliance by the Department with the limitations inserted by this Bill and with information privacy principles will be subject to audit by the Privacy Commissioner.

The circumstances in which the Secretary to the Department of Social Security may authorise the disclosure of information held by the Department to third parties on public interest grounds are to be clarified in guidelines to be issued by the Minister and tabled in both Houses.

The Bill will end the sexist distinction currently embodied in the Class C category of widow's pension. That pension will be replaced in March 1989 with a widowed person's allowance. This will remove anomalies in the coverage of income support to people without dependent children who have been recently widowed, including inconsistencies in the treatment of widowed males and females.
The remainder of the Bill deals with administrative reforms and minor amendments which will improve the quality and consistency of service provided to social security clients.

Directions to be issued by the Minister and tabled in Parliament will make clearer and more consistent the exercise of the power to waive or write off debts owed to the Commonwealth under the Social Security Act. Debts owed to the Commonwealth under the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs' assurances of support scheme are to be brought into line in their handling with debts arising under the Social Security Act. This will be done by providing a mechanism to recover from an assuror who has, for whatever reason, failed to adequately support a migrant under the assurances of support provisions any special benefit paid to the migrant under the Social Security Act. Overpayments of formal training allowance will be made recoverable from continuing social security payments.

Refinements are to be made to the provisions governing the portability of Australian social security payments overseas. From May 1989, payment of family allowance will cease where the recipient has been overseas for three years or longer. From February 1989, pre-departure certificates will be required for all pensioners who leave Australia to enable continuation of payment of pension overseas after six months' absence. And recipients of the existing supporting parent's benefit or Class A widow's pension, or the new sole parent's pension-other than de jure widows-will have their overseas payments limited to 12 months from their departure from Australia if this was on or after 1 July 1988, or ceased on 1 July 1989 if they were already overseas as at 1 July 1988.

The Bill removes anomalies in the provisions covering the payment of entitlements to people who are treated as unmarried and paid at the single rate because they are separated while still living under one roof, or where child disability allowance is paid to only one of the people in respect of a child formerly dependent upon them both.

The reciprocal social security agreement with Canada will come into effect and be incorporated as a schedule in the Social Security Act. Certain New Zealand and United Kingdom payments, which are similar in nature to Australian payments that are exempt from the definition of `income', will also be treated as exempt income.

Fortnightly reporting requirements for benefit will be relaxed for people living in remote communities, and married people separated owing to ill health will be entitled to twice the unmarried rate of remote area allowance where one spouse is dependent on the other.
Members of the Defence Force Reserve will be exempted from the application of the work test on unemployment benefit while attending annual camp.

A beneficiary who has not yet completed the 26 week waiting period for rent assistance and who has a short break in entitlement due to short term employment will not have to serve another full waiting period for rent assistance.

In presenting this Bill I record the Government's appreciation to Professor Cass and those who have worked with her on the Social Security Review. The process of reform in social security is by no means complete. The Social Security Review has recently released a paper on disability issues which will form the basis of policy development for assistance to people with disabilities. Consultations on disability issues are indicating a fundamental shift in attitude about the range of activities that should be available for people with disabilities so they too can have a greater choice in their lives, including greater access to employment and training opportunities.

Soon to be released is a paper titled Towards a National Retirement Incomes Policy which will assess the overall adequacy, equity and incentive effects of the current system of retirement incomes. This paper will propose longer-term directions for reform and is due for release within a few weeks.

As a result of the work of the review, we can look forward to developing more flexible approaches to retirement, including opportunities for part time work in addition to retirement income and long-term care and social support systems for the elderly which encourage them to remain within the community. The culmination of the immensely valuable work of the Social Security Review will be the final report due for release early next year. Professor Cass' final report will address future directions in social security policy including how to simplify the system as well as options for a payment structure which is more tailored to the specific needs of disadvantaged people according to their stage in the life cycle and their capacity to participate in economic activity.

Further reform in the social security area will be dominated by the need to achieve a more active labour market orientation of income support programs, not just for those who we may expect to be in employment but also for sole parents, for some older people and people with disabilities. Taken together, these measures will provide a significant impetus ensuring that all Australians have an opportunity to participate in this country's economic and social life.

The major achievement of this Government in the social security area has been to align social policy objectives more closely with economic policy objectives, to support the broader process of structural change, and to ensure that Australians have adequate opportunities to participate in economic and social activities by equipping them with the necessary skills and training and by providing opportunities to all Australians to participate in economic recovery. This Bill is a significant step in that process. I commend the Bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum.

DEBATE.TITLE: INTERNATIONAL BANK FOR RECONSTRUCTION AND DEVELOPMENT (GENERAL CAPITAL INCREASE) BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Peter Morris, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALKER.NAME: Mr PETER MORRIS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to obtain parliamentary approval for Australia to take up part of its allocated subscription to the third general capital increase of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (IBRD). Honourable members will be aware that the main activity of the bank, which was established in 1947, is lending to developing countries. Up to the end of June 1988, the bank had lent about $US128 billion to its member countries. This money was largely borrowed from international financial markets. The cost to taxpayers in member countries in terms of paid-in capital subscriptions was only $US7.7 billion. Projects financed covered all the major sectors of economic development with an emphasis on infrastructure facilities in the transport and communication, industry and energy sectors, as well as projects for agriculture, education and water supply. An increasing proportion of bank loans-27 per cent of funds committed in 1987-88-finance imports in support of structural adjustment programs.

In April 1988 IBRD governors approved a resolution authorising a $US74.8 billion general capital increase. Capital increases allow the bank to expand its borrowing on world capital markets and it is these borrowings which largely finance the bank's activities. The general capital increase will underpin the bank's operations well into the 1990's and allow the bank to carry through its programs aimed particularly at the most heavily indebted countries. In 1987-88 the bank made lending commitments of $US14.8 billion. The general capital increase will allow it to increase its lending to more than $US20 billion per annum by 1992-93.

Under the general capital increase, Australia is entitled to subscribe to an additional 10,734 shares. The bank does not require full subscription from members immediately and members have until 1993 to subscribe, if they so desire, to the total number of shares allocated to them. The Government has decided that Australia will subscribe to 7,880 shares at an estimated cost over the five years 1988-89 to 1992-93 of $A35.65m. This is a very small proportion of expected Australian aid expenditure over this period. The Government has not decided whether Australia will subscribe to its remaining entitlement of 2,854 general capital increase shares or relinquish them for allocation to other members of the bank. The bank's projected higher lending levels are to be achieved progressively over a period of time, a gradual process which should be consistent with maintaining the quality of bank lending.

Australia is a strong, but not uncritical, supporter of the IBRD. We are concerned that the bank maintains the high quality of its lending and continues to be cost effective. Australia has criticised the bank when appropriate with the aim of improving its overall efficiency. In particular, Australia has expressed concerns about the very fast rate of growth of large scale fast disbursing structural adjustment loans, the growing incidence of arrears on bank loans, and the need to further enhance the bank's work on environmental matters. The bank does have an important role to play in lending to support the adjustment process in developing countries. However, the bank should not be lending to any country for long term structural adjustment purposes in the absence of a suitable framework of macro-economic policies for that country. We must avoid a situation in which a country is able to obtain balance of payments financing from the bank when it has not been able to agree on an economic policy program with the International Monetary Fund. Clearly this would subvert the adjustment process.

Furthermore the Bank must encourage effective adjustment and not replace private debt with public debt. The commercial banks must play their full part in the adjustment process. It is essential for the Bank to maintain its preferred creditor status. Without this the confidence of financial markets in the bank may be jeopardised with consequent adverse effects on the volume and terms of bank lending. The bank needs to pursue poverty alleviation and environmental aspects of its work, but it cannot compensate for all the shortcomings which might exist in national policies affecting the environment, poverty or anything else for that matter. Key issues such as population growth, natural resources, land ownership and government expenditure are sensitive matters of national policy. The bank can assist in these areas but cannot dictate solutions.

Australia gains substantial benefits from its contributions to the IBRD. Benefits from our aid, including political benefits, depend on developmental effectiveness. The World Bank group, including the IBRD and its soft loan arm, the International Development Association (IDA), have a comprehensive and systematic project evaluation system which shows that most IBRD and IDA projects-72 per cent of those evaluated in 1987, for instance-achieve all or most of their objectives. The estimated average return on projects evaluated in calendar years 1986 and 1987, measured by the flow of net economic benefits over time, was 14.5 per cent. These are good results bearing in mind the difficult environment in which the World Bank operates. Developing countries are particularly vulnerable to external shocks, their social and political environment is subject to rapid shifts and they are often short of expertise and skills. Contributions to the IBRD allow us to participate in large development projects and widen the focus of our aid at a relatively low administrative cost. The World Bank group has an important catalytic role in tackling major international economic problems such as protection and debt. The bank provides a significant forum in which Australian initiatives can be pursued.

Australia's membership of the IBRD also brings substantial commercial benefits. On a cumulative basis, Australia has received almost four times more from procurement by the IBRD than it has given in contributions to the IBRD. Australian co-financing of IBRD projects can result in significant procurement benefits. The benefits of IBRD membership have been recognised by Australian governments over the years since the bank's establishment. The report of the Committee to Review the Australian Overseas Aid Program-the Jackson Committee-in 1984 recommended that support for development banks in general and for the World Bank and the Asian Development Bank in particular should be increased in relation to other multilateral funding.

I believe it to be in Australia's interest to continue its policy of support of the IBRD by taking up the 7,880 shares of the IBRD's general capital increase. I commend the Bill to honourable members and I present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Holding, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HOLDING
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

For 58 years self-government for the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) has been an issue which has inspired considerable debate. The Australian Capital Territory (Self-Government) Bill 1988 now before the House will establish the ACT as a body politic, with the legislative and executive powers and responsibilities of the States and the Northern Territory. This Bill represents the most significant transfer of power, on a population basis, since Papua New Guinea became independent. It will allow 270,000 people the same democratic rights and social responsibilities as their fellow Australians. The ACT and the city of Canberra have well and truly come of age. Canberra is the nation's capital. It is the home of many of the symbols of our nationhood such as the National Gallery, the High Court of Australia, the National Library and of course this magnificent building, the home of the nation's Parliament. But, and this is often overlooked, it is also home for 270,000 people who live in the Australian Capital Territory. They go about the day to day business of their lives, working at their jobs, paying their taxes, making decisions about which schools their children will go to, which doctor or hospital will care for them when they are ill, just like every other Australian. However, unlike every other person in this country, where a fair go is the creed by which we live, they cannot elect a member of their own community to their own government. They have no say in the decisions which affect their everday lives. What an extraordinary admission in a country so committed to democratic ideals, and why? Are these people somehow different from other Australians? Are they second-class citizens in some way? Do they not understand, or have options on, the issues that confront them daily? Can they not be trusted with their own destiny? The answer to all these question is very simple. The only difference between these people and the rest of Australia is that they live in the Australian Capital Territory.

Is it not something of an irony, that because this is the national capital, the symbol of Australian democracy, it has proven too hard for us to grant its citizens that most fundamental of democratic rights, the right to look after their own affairs? Canberra has long been regarded as a company town, with its economy inextricably tied to the public sector. Times have changed and the Territory has grown. It is now a mature City-State which can no longer look to the Commonwealth alone for the economic security of its citizens. The development of Canberra as the national capital is now virtually complete. The development of a diversified economy, incorporating a vibrant private sector is this community's right and need. The basis is there. Canberra already has a burgeoning tourism industry with the potential for bigger and better things. There is in place a tertiary education sector ready to make Canberra a centre of intellectual excellence and to support the development of modern, high technology industries. The ideas and the drive for Canberra's future should come from the people of this Territory. They need their own elected government to make the laws, establish the framework, and provide the creative spark that will change the focus of Canberra's development to make sure that the future needs of the community are best met.

This Bill is the logical and inevitable political conclusion to the process of economic and administrative evolution which has taken place. The administration of the Territory has been radically altered since the first serious attempts to achieve self-government a few years ago. There are no longer 12 Commonwealth departments involved in territorial matters. Functions have been consolidated in a single administration complete with a stand-alone ACT Budget. These changes were introduced to ensure the smooth and orderly transition to self-government. The management of the Territory has now been arranged into a system that can and should be handed over to local political representatives. The Territory is unique. Virtually all its residents live in the one city-Canberra. It needs a form of government that acknowledges its unique nature and this is what is being proposed: one level of government appropriate to the City-State of the ACT. It needs a form of government that also recognises its situation as the nation's capital. This proposal has been designed to ensure that the Commonwealth will look after the national aspects and the ACT, the territorial and local aspects, in a manner that protects the interests of both.

In establishing an ACT government, the Australian Capital Territory will be a body politic under the Crown. It will consist of a legislative arm and an executive arm to exercise powers as set out in the Bill. The dual nature of the Territory-home to both its residents and the nation's capital-will be reflected in the financial arrangements put in place by this Bill. The ACT will have the same legislative and executive powers and responsibility over finances as the States and the Northern Territory. The ACT will be treated by the Commonwealth on the same financial basis as the States and the Northern Territory. Fairness and equity will be assured. The ACT will be given protections consistent with those given the States and the Northern Territory, whilst the impact of the location of the nation's capital within its boundaries will be recognised. The Commonwealth Grants Commission Act 1973 will be amended to recognise the ACT's financial autonomy and national capital aspects, as well as to allow for direct access by the ACT to the Grants Commission, at the ACT's request. Commonwealth funding to the ACT will fully recognise the effects of Canberra's role as the national capital and seat of Commonwealth government on such things as the standards and costs of works and services. This Bill explicitly provides that these circumstances be taken into account.

The Commonwealth will retain responsibility for financing its functions within the Territory. The Bill provides that the ACT will not be liable for the cost of administering any function retained by the Commonwealth. The Commonwealth will provide additional assistance to the ACT for any further functions transferred from the Commonwealth in future years. The Government is concerned to see that the transfer of financial powers from the Commonwealth to the ACT, and the transition to Commonwealth, State and local government financial arrangements, is smooth, non-disruptive and fair. Commonwealth funding to the ACT will be guaranteed in real terms for the first two years of self-government. This guarantee also applied to the 1988-89 ACT Budget to protect the ACT from the funding reductions felt by the States and the Northern Territory and to maintain the base level of funding in the lead up to self-government. Funding has also been provided in this year's Budget to cover the additional recurrent costs to run the ACT Government, as well as the first Assembly election. As was done in the Northern Territory, the Government will also consider a grant to cover necessary establishment costs, such as those needed for a parliamentary library, a Treasury computer system and a building to house the Assembly and Executive. After the guarantee period, funding will be the subject of negotiations with the Executive to smooth the transition to processes consistent with Commonwealth, State and local government financial arrangements. These arrangements will complete the ongoing process of bringing ACT finances into line with the rest of Australia-a process which began in 1985-86. Throughout, the Government has taken into account the reports of the Commonwealth Grants Commission into ACT finances. In terms of the financial impact on the Commonwealth, the Bill will not involve additional Commonwealth expenditures other than the one-off establishment assistance. Savings will accrue to the Commonwealth through separation of responsibilities of ACT administration from the Commonwealth system. In the longer term, the arrangements will allow Commonwealth funding to the ACT on a basis more directly comparable to that to the States.

I will now address individual parts of the Bill. Part I provides for the usual preliminary matters of commencement and interpretation. Jervis Bay Territory is a separate Commonwealth Territory and is not affected by this Bill. Part II establishes the Legislative Assembly and covers the range of procedural matters necessary for the conduct of the Assembly's business. The Assembly will consist of 17 members elected at large for a fixed term of four years. The number of members may be varied by regulation at the request of the Assembly. At its first meeting, the Assembly will elect a Presiding Officer and a Chief Minister. The Chief Minister will appoint three other Ministers and these four people will form the Australian Capital Territory Executive. The function of the Executive will be to govern the Territory with respect to the matters outlined in schedule 4 of the Bill.

Schedule 4 gives the Executive power over virtually all matters affecting the Territory. The Commonwealth will, until 1 July 1990, retain within the Attorney-General's portfolio the establishment of courts, the provision of police services and the control of legal practitioners, companies and securities. This arrangement will allow the ACT a settling-in period before assuming responsibilities which are currently outside the province of the ACT Administration. The Government is disposed to have the Executive enter into an agency arrangement with the Australian Federal Police to provide police services to the Territory. The Government will decide by 1 July 1990 whether courts will transfer to the ACT. The national function of classifying materials for censorship purposes will be retained by the Commonwealth.

As I have said before, the Territory is home to the nation's capital-this fact cannot be ignored. The Commonwealth will continue to have the ultimate responsibility for ensuring the Territory's good government. Consequently, this part includes a provision for the Governor-General to dissolve the Assembly and appoint a Commissioner if the Assembly is incapable of performing its functions, or is conducting its affairs in a grossly improper manner. In this eventuality, a general election must be held within 90 days.

Part III details the powers of the Assembly. The Assembly will have the power to make laws for the peace, order and good government of the Territory. Most ordinance law in place in the Territory will become Assembly law on the commencing day. The Governor-General will, as occurs in the Northern Territory, have the power to disallow any Assembly law within six months of the law being made. Commonwealth law will prevail over Assembly law. Protections such as these are essential in the national capital. They are, of course, instruments of last resort and it is the Government's intention to resolve any potential conflict with the ACT by consultation and negotiation. In addition to the powers and functions I described previously, the Assembly will have the power to entrench the manner and form of making particular laws by submitting an entrenching law to a referendum. Its purpose is to extend to the people of the Territory, who are not party to the Australia Act, the general provisions of that Act, which allow the States to entrench laws relating to the Constitution, powers and procedures of their parliaments.

Part IV details the role and functions of the Executive. As I indicated earlier, the Chief Minister will appoint three Ministers. As with the number of members, the number of Ministers may be varied by regulation at the request of the Assembly. Part IV also provides for a general election if a resolution of no confidence in the Chief Minister is passed and a new Chief Minister is not elected within 30 days.

Part V will permit the ACT to implement its own administration, management and staffing arrangements. The Chief Minister will appoint a Head of Administration, who will be the principal adviser to the Executive and generally have prime responsibility, under the Chief Minister, for the administrative functions of the body politic. The Chief Minister may also appoint Associate Heads of Administration as necessary to support the other Ministers in the exercise of their responsibilities. The Assembly will have the power to enact its own staffing laws and the Head of Administration may employ staff in accordance with such legislation.

Financial provisions are covered in part VI. The ACT will have an autonomous Treasury. As I explained earlier, the ACT will be treated on the same basis as the States and the Northern Territory in terms of its financial relationship with the Commonwealth. However, the special circumstances arising from the existence within the Territory of the national capital and the seat of government of the Commonwealth will be taken into account. The Commonwealth may lend money to the ACT or to a Territory authority. The ACT may, with the approval of the Commonwealth Treasurer, borrow money from agencies other than the Commonwealth. Any such borrowings may be guaranteed by the Commonwealth and the ACT may use its assets as security.

Part VII allows for members of the Assembly to be elected under the provisions of the Australian Capital Territory (Electoral) Bill 1988. Part VII also sets out the necessary qualifications of candidates and the processes for filling casual vacancies. Part VIII attends to miscellaneous provisions and constitutional guarantees. The ACT will be brought into line with the States and the Northern Territory by applying provisions similar to section 92 of the Constitution, guaranteeing free trade. This will not bind the Commonwealth.

Transitional provisions will be included in consequential legislation to ensure the smooth transfer of powers and functions to the incoming government. Until the ACT enacts its own staffing law, the consequential legislation will provide for staff of the ACT Administration to be employed under the Public Service Act 1922 and other relevant Commonwealth legislation and awards. It will also provide for consultation to take place between the Executive, the Commonwealth and peak union councils before the terms and conditions of employment of staff who are to be employed under the ACT's own staffing law are determined.

In addition to the consultative processes to be provided for in the consequential legislation, part VIII of the Australian Capital Territory (Self-Government) Bill provides for consultations to occur on an ongoing basis between the Commonwealth and the ACT on public sector industrial and staffing matters. These provisions are designed to protect the rights and entitlements of Administration staff and also to ensure that the ACT will take account of the effect of its decisions on the Commonwealth's interests as the major employer in the Territory. Part VIII also allows for the Remuneration Tribunal to determine the salaries and allowances of Assembly members, Ministers, the Presiding Officer, the Head of Administration and any Associate Heads of Administration.

The consequential legislation which will address the technical aspects necessary to give effect to ACT self-government, is not yet ready for introduction to the House. It will therefore be introduced to the Senate co-incidentally with the transmission of these three Bills to the Senate.

It will be clear that this legislation is both comprehensive and well-conceived. It provides for fully responsible government for the people of the Territory, in its most democratic, practical and economic form. It safeguards the Commonwealth's interests in the national capital. It provides for an efficient and effective administration. It puts the ACT on a proper financial basis. It ensures that the residents of the Territory will be properly and effectively represented in the management of their affairs. It is a milestone in the democratic processes of this country. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill and commend the Bill to the House.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Holding, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HOLDING
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill provides for a system to elect the Legislative Assembly for the Australian Capital Territory. This is the Government's third attempt at introducing an electoral system for the Territory. In 1986 this Government first moved to introduce self-government for the Territory. The proposal then, as now, allowed for a government comprising a single House of legislature-a people's House. The electoral system proposed-single member electorates-was the same as that used to elect members to every people's House in all English speaking democracies-including, of course, Australia. To propose that this Territory also elect its representatives from single electorates in the same way as other mainland Australians was therefore not novel or controversial, yet this proposition was not supported.

The Government, committed then as now to self-government for the Territory, compromised. It proposed an amalgam of Australian electoral systems-around half of the members to be elected from single member electorates using House of Representative rules, with the balance elected at large using Senate rules. This, of course, represented a significant shift from the principle that the people of the Territory should be treated just like other Australians when it comes to electing their representatives. However, this proposal too was not acceptable. The Australian Capital Territory (Self-Government) Bill 1988 is already before the House. In proposing self-government for the Territory, the Government has once again demonstrated its commitment to democracy for all.

Facing the rejection of existing Australian electoral systems, the Government has turned to an electoral system used commonly throughout the non-English speaking Western democracies to elect people's Houses. This system, known as the d'Hondt system, provides for direct proportional representation. The hallmark of this system is a concern for both democracy and stable government. It is once again a compromise, but it is a compromise we are prepared to make in an effort to give the people of the Territory the same democratic rights as their fellow Australians. It will be unique to Australia, but this Territory-a city-State-is also unique to Australia. The objective of any electoral system for a people's House is twofold-to accurately reflect the electoral wishes of the people in the composition of their government and, of great importance, to provide for stable government.

Some with vested interests have advocated that the Hare-Clark system of proportional representation be used to elect the Assembly. This Government makes no apology for rejecting a system that is specifically designed for a House of review. Under its rules, seats may be literally decided by chance on the preferences of voters who may well have had no idea-or wish-that their vote would elect particular candidates. For example, to decide some seats in the last ACT House of Assembly elections using these rules, votes had to be distributed more than 20 times. In the last Senate election, a candidate with less than 1.5 per cent of the primary vote was elected. Yet others with more than double this primary vote were not. This may be acceptable in a House of review, but it could create instability in a people's House where such members may hold the balance of power.

The d'Hondt system is a people's House system. It is very familiar to and respected by the democracies of Europe. It has been used for many years in countries such as Austria, Belgium, Finland, West Germany and the Netherlands, all of which enjoy the reputation of being democratic, stable and prosperous states. Under this system, all contestants are elected as accurately as possible in accordance with the proportion of votes received. The system is completely neutral between contestants and satisfied the stability side of the equation by ensuring that the party or parties with a majority of votes will command a majority of the seats.

There is nothing mystical or complex about this system. A very simple mathematical calculation ensures the direct and accurate reflection of the voters' intention in the composition of the House. It does no more or less than make sure that, as closely as mathematically possible, each and every member in the House is supported by the same number of voters. It is immune from gerrymander. Every vote has equal value and, in fact, it is the most direct system of proportional representation that one can get. In terms of the financial impact on the Commonwealth, the Bill will not involve additional Commonwealth expenditure other than that already provided for the first Assembly election, the estimated cost of which is $620,000.

I will now turn my attention to a brief description of the main features of the Bill. The cornerstone of the Bill is the application of the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918, suitably modified, to Assembly elections. The Bill divides the Commonwealth Electoral Act into three categories. The first category consists of those provisions which are modified by schedule 1 to the Bill and provide the detailed nuts and bolts for the conduct of Assembly elections; the second category consists of those provisions which provide the overall framework for Assembly elections and are applied generally; and the third category consists of disapplied provisions which have no relevance to Assembly elections.

Most of the modifications to the Commonwealth Electoral Act rise because of the introduction of the d'Hondt electoral system. The d'Hondt system enables electors to vote for an independent candidate, to vote for a pre-determined list of party candidates or indicate the order in which they wish candidates of the party of their choice to be elected. Once seats have been distributed among parties and independents using the d'Hondt mathematical calculation, seats won by a party are allocated to its candidates by distributing votes in the same way as in Senate elections. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table which illustrates how the d'Hondt distribution works.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY (PLANNING AND LAND MANAGEMENT) BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Holding, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HOLDING
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

Mr Deputy Speaker, the Australian Capital Territory (Planning and Land Management Bill) 1988 heralds a new era in the planning and development of the Australian Capital Territory (ACT). This Bill reflects the findings of Mr Block's report on the ongoing role of the National Capital Development Commission (NCDC) in the context of moves to self-government. It, together with the Australian Capital Territory (Self-Government) Bill 1988, establishes a framework for funding and administering national capital concerns separately from municipal and territorial concerns.

Canberra is a magnificent place. We all acknowledge the expertise and creativity that has gone into making Canberra what it is today-a national capital unequalled in the world for its natural and man-made beauty. Since 1957, the architect of this city has been the National Capital Development Commission. The Commission was created at a time when it appeared that Walter Burley Griffin's vision for Canberra may not be fulfilled. The Commission took up the challenge and today Canberra is a vibrant reflection of our nation-a city-State in which the whole nation can take pride. The Commission can be proud of the fact that it has taken Canberra from the bush capital of the 1950s to the national capital of the 1980s. Its efforts mean that the development of Canberra as the nation's capital is virtually complete.

There are a few national projects yet to be built, such as the Museum of Australia. However, the important and exciting task ahead is for Canberra to develop and grow as a community. The task is to see that it provides in a balanced way for all the diversified economic and social needs of its citizens. With maturity comes responsibility. Under new financial arrangements that are already in place, ACT citizens will pay for territorial planning and development activities like the rest of us. Fairness and equity requires that there now be an accompanying and unambiguous division between national and local responsibilities. This Bill achieves this.

The Commonwealth will accept administrative and financial responsibility to maintain and enhance the character of the Territory as the national capital. The Australian Capital Territory will accept the normal State-type administrative and financial responsibility to plan and develop the Territory. The Government will abolish the NCDC and set up a new national planning body, the National Capital Planning Authority, directly responsible to the Commonwealth Minister. This new Authority will prepare a National Capital Plan which will define the policies, aesthetic principles and any development requirements required to maintain and enhance the character of the national capital.

The ACT will be responsible for the normal range of State-type planning and development matters. A territorial planning authority will be set up. It will be responsible for developing and managing a Territory plan not inconsistent with the National Capital Plan. It will also be able to set out the detailed planning, design and development conditions for all land in the Territory except designated national capital areas. The Bill requires of both governments parliamentary scrutiny, public consultation and review processes to ensure openness. There will be no scope for corruption.

Ownership of the land will remain with the Commonwealth. The ACT will be responsible for the orderly development of land to meet the needs of the community. Therefore, land other than that reserved by the Commonwealth for its purposes will be managed by the ACT on behalf of the Commonwealth.

These new arrangements will take time to put in place. Any hiatus in ACT planning and development must be avoided. This Bill therefore introduces appropriate interim measures to allow for the smooth and orderly introduction of the new arrangements.

The financial impact of these changes on the Commonwealth will be positive. The integration of NCDC functions into the ACT Administration and the Department of Administrative Services, together with the creation of the National Capital Planning Authority, will result in savings. These savings are estimated at some 120 staff yielding $6.6m per year. Initial integration of NCDC functions has provided a saving of about 80 positions this year. A further saving of about 40 positions is expected to be brought to account in 1989. In undertaking these changes, the Government has been and will continue to be concerned to fully protect the interests of NCDC staff.

I will now address the various parts of the Bill. Part I provides for the usual preliminary matters of commencement and interpretation. Part II establishes the National Capital Planning Authority, prescribes its powers and functions and makes it subject to general ministerial direction.

Part III prescribes the object of the National Capital Plan and outlines what matters the Authority may include when preparing a draft plan. The purpose of the plan is to ensure that the Commonwealth's national capital interests in the Territory are fully protected, without otherwise involving the Commonwealth in matters that should be the prerogative of the Canberra community.

The legislation requires public notification, consideration of representations, and consultations between the Commonwealth and ACT governments before the plan is brought into effect. The Minister's approval to the plan is subject to parliamentary disallowance provisions. A process of ministerial certification will be used to protect the draft plan where this is required before normal approval processes have been completed.

Part IV requires the Assembly to establish a Territory planning authority to prepare and administer a Territory plan. This plan will provide the people of the Territory with an attractive, safe and efficient environment in which to live, work and have their recreation. The Bill outlines the parameters of the plan and ensures that it cannot operate inconsistently with the National Capital Plan.

Importantly, this part requires the Assembly to make laws for the procedure to make the plan, as well as requirements for public notification, consideration of representations, and consultations between the Commonwealth and ACT governments before the plan is brought into effect. The Assembly is also required to ensure by law that there are just and timely processes in place to review appropriate planning, design and development decisions. These reviews will be conducted without unnecessary formality.

Part V provides for the management of land in the ACT. It confers on the Commonwealth the right to specify at any time which areas of land it requires for its use or intended use. This land will be called national land. All other land will be called Territory land and will be managed by the ACT Executive on the Commonwealth's behalf. The existing leasehold system will be retained and only the Commonwealth will be able to vary it. The ACT will be liable for any acts or omissions in its management of Territory land, as will the Commonwealth in respect of national land. Provisions are included to define the relationship which will exist between the two governments in respect of financial aspects of land management. These are required to allow Commonwealth-State financial arrangements to be introduced.

Part VI sets out the constitution of the National Planning Authority. It confers the responsibility to determine remuneration for Authority members on the Remuneration Tribunal and covers appointments to the Authority and obligations imposed on Authority members. It also sets out requirements for meetings of the Authority and permits the appointment of advisory committees.

Part VII sets out that a chief executive will manage the affairs of the Authority under its general directions and that its staff will be employed under the Public Service Act. The Authority may engage consultants and is required to present to the Minister a report annually on its operations, which will be tabled in both Houses of this Parliament. Part VIII provides that the ACT will be indemnified by the Commonwealth for any claims made against it in respect of any matter arising from the Commonwealth's management, actions or inactions before self-government or concerning national land.

Part IX repeals existing National Capital Development Commission legislation. Part X sets out transitional provisions that are necessary for the first 12 months after self-government. They will cover the period before the ACT Executive and the ACT planning authority have been established, as well as allow the first National Capital Plan to be brought into effect. During this period relevant National Capital Development Commission policies will continue in effect. The provisions of this Act regarding the respective roles of the Commonwealth and the ACT to manage and vary planning policies will generally apply.

This Bill is further evidence of the Government's commitment to give the people of the Territory the same rights and responsibilities as their fellow Australians. The new arrangements will create an unambiguous separation of responsibility for National Capital planning from Territory planning and development. They ensure that the interests of the Commonwealth in, and the character of, the Territory as the nation's capital are protected. They guarantee that the Commonwealth will not be required to take financial responsibility for other than its national capital interests. They allow the people of the Territory to control the day to day planning and development of their home. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill and commend the Bill to the House.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Holding, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HOLDING
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Territories and Minister Assisting the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The main purpose of this Bill is to permit faster migration clearance of overseas passengers at airports. It flows from the Government's master plan for passenger processing at Australia's airports. It is the Government's objective to provide visitors to Australia and Australian travellers fast and efficient service at our international airports.

The amendments contained in this Bill will provide that visas issued overseas will become an entry permit on entering Australia at an international airport; pre-cleared flights to operate to Australia; and safeguards of records and data bases which impact on immigration processing of passengers. In addition, the opportunity was taken to make some consequential amendments to the Migration Act, flowing from the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters (Consequential Amendments) Act 1987. This amendment relates essentially to the redefinition of `entry permit' to clarify the status of statutory visitors.

The Government has been concerned for some time to ensure that legislative and administrative requirements for entry to and departure from Australia keep pace with the demands of our burgeoning tourism industry. At the same time, we are concerned to maintain the necessary safeguards as to who enters Australia. The Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs has embarked on a comprehensive program of computerising many of the manual processes associated with visa issue and entry permit issue. The Department has also put in place systems whereby data obtained at visa issue is brought to Australia and used to facilitate entry processes.

The progressive computerisation of visa issue at major overseas posts in the past 18 months has enabled dramatic improvements to be made in the levels of service provided. Typically at our major tourist source posts we now offer an across the counter service where that is sought and a 24 hour service in all other cases. Computerisation has produced significant productivity gains and reduced demands for extra staff to meet the dramatic growth we have seen in tourism to Australia.

Officials in the Department have recently demonstrated the Australian visa system at the International Civil Aviation Organisation Facilitation meeting in Montreal where the Australian visa format was adopted as the world standard. More recently, the Government has addressed the issue of movements of people through our international airports. That review, jointly chaired by the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs and the Australian Customs Service and involving all agencies associated with movements through our airports as well as representatives of the airlines and the tourism industry, culminated in endorsement by government of a master plan for passenger processing at Australian airports. My colleagues, the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business and the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs jointly gave some details of the Government's decisions on 8 September.

The master plan will result in a wide range of adjustments to processes and procedures applied by the range of agencies impacting on movements through airports. As far as the immigration portfolio is concerned, we have sought to reduce the range of formalities associated with the entry/departure processes. We have sought to simplify decision processes without jeopardising the controls necessary in Australia's wider national interests. The most significant step is to put in place a system whereby a visa obtained for travel to Australia will, on entering Australia, unless cancelled, operate as an entry permit.

Under current arrangements persons wishing to enter Australia must first obtain a visa. Upon arrival in Australia the holder of that visa may or may not be granted an entry permit pursuant to the provisions of the Migration Act. If granted an entry permit the person then enters Australia. The new arrangements flowing from this Bill will provide for a system whereby a person will hold only one document which will serve a double purpose, that is, it will be a visa for the purpose of travel to Australia and an entry permit after entry to Australia at a proclaimed airport.

The present Act provides for entry permits to be in a form and specifying conditions as determined by the Minister. No similar discretions exist in terms of the visa. The Bill seeks to inject the necessary discretion to enable the determination of visa conditions. There will be a need to fix the date and place of entry into Australia. Such a provision is necessary from the viewpoint of both the holder of the visa and the department; for example, as proof of entitlement to remain in Australia within the currency of the visa/entry permit or as proof of entry at a proclaimed airport. The Bill proposes the use of the current port and date stamp and departmental computer records as a prima facie evidence of arrival.

The present stand alone entry permit provisions will need to continue for several reasons. First, the new arrangements are only to operate in respect of entries at proclaimed airports which handle the bulk of travellers. Secondly, to take account of persons who apply for change of status, that is permanent entry status after arrival as a temporary entrant. The third reason is that there will have to be transitional provisions to take account of the fact that not all persons travelling to, and entering, Australia will be holders of a visa in the new form. Additionally, present arrangements regarding fee collection for permit renewal and for issue of resident return visas will remain.

The concept of pre-clearance or the performance of immigration entry procedures offshore has been under consideration for some time. The concept involves the disembarkation of flights at other than international airports subject to satisfaction of health, quarantine and customs considerations. The concept provided for in the Bill is for individual designated flights flying non-stop from a place of departure to Australia. Passengers on these flights would be examined and immigration cleared for entry prior to departure for Australia. Upon disembarkation, they would enter Australia without further immigration formalities.

It is proposed to provide that a stamp in the form indicating the date, airport and country of departure for Australia will be placed in the passport of a traveller embarking on a pre-cleared flight. If a pre-cleared flight lands at any other country prior to arrival in Australia the pre-clearance has no effect. Passengers would then be processed in the usual way. The amendments empower the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs to proclaim flights for the purposes of pre-clearance.

Given the pivotal role of electronic records and systems in the department's task in processing passengers, it is necessary to guarantee the integrity of such records and systems. This is essential in securing the general confidence in the new system. The Bill therefore provides that perusal or alteration of records and systems associated with passenger processing be limited to authorised officers in the performance of their duty and provides penalties for breach of these provisions.

The further consequential amendments flowing from the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters (Consequential Amendments) Act 1987 seeks to place a statutory visitor who might be granted an entry permit on an equal footing with other entry permit holders. The adjustments contained in the present Bill essentially correct oversights in the initial consequential legislation. The package of provisions in this Bill, as they relate to the important task of passenger processing at Australia's international airports, provide the legislative base for the progressive introduction of a system of passenger processing which is arguably the most advanced in the world. I commend the Bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Holding, for Mr Dawkins, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HOLDING
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Territories (5.57)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Superannuation Act 1976 to provide a new supervisory mechanism for the provision of superannuation benefits to Commonwealth sector employees, in addition to that already available. These changes constitute an integral part of this Government's reforms of Government business enterprises. They will allow certain enterprises to determine their own future superannuation arrangements within guidelines issued by the Minister for Finance. This contrasts with the current provisions of the Act. At present, in all instances, the detailed written approval of the Minister for Finance must be obtained before superannuation benefits can be provided to statutory office-holders, employees of statutory authorities and certain Commonwealth-owned companies or Commonwealth-funded bodies.

Initially the guidelines approach will apply to Qantas, Australian Airlines, the Australian National Line and Aussat. It will enable these enterprises to play a key role in the further development of this nation guided in their actions in relation to superannuation by commercial considerations. It is envisaged that in the future enterprises such as Telecom, Australia Post, the Overseas Telecommunications Commission and the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation shall also be able to make their own superannuation arrangements within appropriate guidelines. These changes are an important component of the reform packages, announced in the May economic statement, that will make Government enterprises more accountable for their own performance. Managers of these enterprises will be forced to measure up. At the same time, this Government has not overlooked the public interest in these changes and honourable members will note how the provisions of the Bill relating to contraventions provide a sufficient deterrent to managers who might seek to exploit unduly their new freedoms.

Further, it is intended that enterprises operating under guidelines will be required to publicly report their actions in relation to superannuations as part of their annual reports. This requirement will further enhance the public accountability of the management of Government business enterprises. This Bill also seeks to correct a deficiency in the former provisions. The Act will now fully implement the decision of both this Government, and its predecessor, that the Superannuation Act 1976 should be the exclusive source of legal authority on superannuation for Commonwealth sector employees. This approach needs to be modified when the Minister relaxes his control under the guidelines approach. The Bill allows the Industrial Relations Commission to conciliate and arbitrate on their superannuation arrangements. This is consistent with the commercial environment in which the authorities subject to the guidelines are expected to operate.

There will be no direct financial effects resulting from this Bill. However, to the extent that these amendments facilitate improvements in the rate of return of Government business enterprises, there should be increases in revenue to the Government in the form of increased dividends from these enterprises. I present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill and I commend the Bill to the House.
