DEBATE.TITLE: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 4) 1988[COGNATE BILLS:INCOME TAX AMENDMENT BILL 1988MEDICARE LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1988]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the debate is resumed on this Bill, I remind the House that it has been agreed that a general debate be allowed covering this Bill and orders of the day Nos 2 and 3.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —At a time when so many individuals, business groups and professionals in tax practice are voicing concerns about taxation law and the administration of it, we again have to consider another omnibus tax Bill. The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) is the fourth such Bill for 1988. It is an understatement to say that it is a little disappointing to note that some of those concerns being expressed are again not to be sympathetically addressed. No such luck! Whatever happened to consensus? We do not hear much about that these days-not that consensus was anything more than an early slogan used by what is becoming little more than a sloganeering government. Even the Commissioner of Taxation has been infected by the slogan bug. His public relations machine is churning out gems like `Taxes-building a better Australia', and his latest: `Collecting for kids'. We await with breathless anticipation the next little beauty to be dreamed up by the back room propagandists of the Australian Taxation Office (ATO).

SPEECH.PARA: In the meantime, the penny, along with the value of our dollar, has dropped out there in the real world. Suddenly, it seems that the realisation has set in and the increasing waywardness of the Commissioner is being questioned. His many departures from what is actually prescribed by law to what the Commissioner apparently believes the law should say when applied to selected taxpayers are becoming legion. This was almost inevitable.

Since the heady days of consensus and the largely forgotten economic and tax summits, abuse of the tax laws is as much the province of some in the Australian Taxation Office as it is of those who still seek to evade their obligations to pay lawful taxes. Despite recent interest, publicly stated, it was all predictable. Discretionary power has been heaped on the Commissioner's already hefty discretion in practically every piece of a veritable avalanche of tax legislation over the past 5 1/2 years. Along with the Commissioner's discretion, which has been deliberately included in laws, has developed the mentality that, by queer twists of logic, enables even the letter of our tax laws to be administered as if the Commissioner had carte blanche.

As I have said on other occasions, history is littered with examples of tax collectors being hanged or otherwise executed for overzealous policing of tax laws. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) and his Government merit the political equivalent of hanging for aiding and abetting, as well as hiding behind, the present Commissioner. Willing horse that he is apparently infatuated with the sight of his own name in print and getting a real buzz out of the whirr of television cameras in his ears, the Commissioner seems to be happy to run interference for his Treasurer. The recent publicly stated concerns of the Confederation of Australian Industry and others about the heavy-handed tactics of the Commissioner should have been levelled at the Government in general and the Treasurer in particular. Were they? Of course they were not. Apart from one press release from the Treasurer between overseas trips, there has been virtual silence from the Government. The ploy seems to be to let the Commissioner take the heat, and he has shown himself to be more than willing. In more ways than one the buck stops at the ATO these days.

Perhaps even more telling in condemnation of the Treasurer and the Commissioner are the views of the President of the Law Council of Australia, Mr D. M. Byrne. That strictly apolitical organisation has deemed both the Treasurer's and Mr Boucher's excesses worthy of critical comment in recent times on at least three important scores. In short, those issues are raids on, followed by searches of, solicitors' and accountants' offices; legislation by press release; and the primacy of law as enacted over the rhetorical preferences of the Commissioner and the Government. It is the second and third of those concerns expressed by the Council that are of immediate interest, the first being sub judice.

It is not the Treasurer, nor anyone in the Government, who accepts responsibility for departure from the principle of rule of law in tax matters. It is not the Treasurer, that well known defender of the requirement to file personal tax returns within lawful period, who says, `Ease up, Mr Boucher; if the law says one thing and you want to use your already enormous powers to intimidate taxpayers into doing something else it is just not on'. Nothing of the like has been heard from this man, who poses as a paragon of virtue in matters which are plainly his responsibility. He ducks off overseas. He goes into seminarian retreat. He does not want to know. The Treasurer has shown that he can absorb a brief and the jargon that goes with it, but when it comes to administration of tax laws, for which he is also directly responsible, he has shown time and again in this House that he does not even understand the effect of his own legislation, either when it is in Bill form or afterwards. He obediently reads the second reading speeches prepared for him but there is no real comprehension on the Treasurer's part.

Part of what can be described only as a concerted assault on the senses and sensibilities of the public is the technique adopted by the Commissioner, with the support of his captive Treasurer, to accuse certain groups and those in particular categories of taxpayers of usually nefarious conduct. That particular technique is primarily intended to intimidate but, equally seriously, it denigrates and brings into disrepute whole classes of professionals, tradesmen and business proprietors. What we now are witnessing are the first signs of an overzealous Commissioner, with the usually tacit support of the highest taxing Treasurer in 43 years, employing methods adopted by Senator Eugene McCarthy. Backed by a public relations unit at the ATO, which in itself is a scandalous waste of taxpayers' money, we now see a campaign emanating from the Commissioner that is blatantly intended to soften up public opinion. This is being done by publicly targeting groups, not individuals, implying that doubtful tax practices are rife amongst those in the groups named.

We see barristers, solicitors, dentists, tradesmen and others named as distinctive breeds deserving of the wrath of the Australian people because of some unidentified malfeasance. We get the edict delivered from the mount, as it were, by way of press release or speeches from the Commissioner of Taxation. It continues as a great surprise to me that there are still many people naive or foolish enough to believe that if the Commissioner or his Treasurer make some sweeping accusation there must be something in it. There are such people. There are a great many more who are intimidated by the real and perceived power wielded by the ATO, to the extent that they will not publicly question or criticise the propaganda which is intended to manipulate public opinion against certain named categories and in favour of the excesses of the Commissioner and his captive Treasurer. That strikes me as classic McCarthyism.

Of course, some barristers and solicitors, along with commensurate numbers in any segment of our community, minimise and perhaps even evade payment of their lawful taxes. But why is it necessary to name them all in a way that, without offering any evidence whatsoever, brings all barristers and solicitors under suspicion in the minds of the public? The same can be said of dentists and the same question should follow. Is it because those professionals are made up of what might be said to be soft targets? It is one thing for those of us who have had to pay an account from a solicitor or a dentist, without any knowledge of the cost structure of an office or clinic, to comment casually on the charges for those services. It is entirely another for the Commissioner and his Treasurer to bludge on latent resentment and to suggest, in speeches and press releases, that tax evasion abounds in these professions. The same deplorable device has been employed with some success by this Government against doctors in the context of the health care cum Medicare debate.

The naming, once again, of tradesmen in relation to this Bill involves another and different deceit. The genesis of the deceit is to be found in the rhetoric of the justification offered in 1983 by this Keating-Hawke Government-when it was the Hawke-Keating Government-for its prescribed payments system (PPS). Do honourable members opposite not remember-that is a problem because no-one is here-that the prescribed payments system was to be the answer to the then maiden Treasurer's prayers? All those terrible brickies and chippies out there were to be caught in the net to be woven and cash in the hand was to be taxed, almost without exception. Apparently, and not surprisingly, they were not caught because the Commissioner says, once again, that he will target them. This new onslaught has been paraded as part of a wonderful new initiative. This will be despite the equally wonderful words parroted in this place often enough by honourable members opposite that the PPS was a great success.

The outcome of that grand plan was, according to the Commissioner, his Treasurer and apologists of all kinds, another 40,000 taxpayers on the books paying their lawful taxes. That was an enormous lie. I will tell you why, Mr Deputy Speaker. If 40,000 individuals who should have been paying tax previously but were not suddenly were identified, prosecutions for tax evasion would or should have ensued automatically. I challenge anyone opposite to ask the Commissioner how many of those alleged 40,000 taxpayers were prosecuted. Was it a couple of thousand or was it merely a couple of hundred? Whatever the actual number, it was infinitesimal against the 40,000 cited in the big lie.

For all that, the Commissioner and his Treasurer exploit the fact that they can, it seems, fool some of the people some of the time. If further evidence of that is needed, we need only refer to the well-practised device of tax legislation by media release. Although it needs detailed examination, discussion of that increasingly vexatious problem is probably best left to an amendment to be moved by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition at the committee stage. Of great immediate importance is the attitude of the Commissioner and his captive Treasurer to the rule of law in tax matters. To set a framework for my concerns, I refer to a classical exposition on the British Constitution by A. V. Dicey in a tome entitled The Law of the Constitution-the eighth edition-according to which the rule of law:

. . . means, in the first place, the absolute supremacy or predominance of regular law as opposed to the influence of arbitrary power, and excludes the existence of arbitrariness, of prerogative, or even of wide discretionary authority on the part of government.

Taking that as a starting point, it gives me no satisfaction to note that large sections of our tax law fail on all counts as expressed by Dicey. I will not entertain any interjections about Dicey's assumptions. Most of us believe in the supremacy or predominance of regular law for taxes, as much as for any branch of the law. I venture to suggest that most people thought that that was and is the case. Despite perceptions, it is patently not so. Let us take the first test applied by Dicey in his definition. It stipulates the absolute supremacy or predominance of regular law over arbitrary power. In Australia, arbitrary power accrues to the Commissioner and his captive Treasurer in several ways, not the least because the Government both legislates and assumes power not explicitly spelled out in statutes. On the score of arbitrary power and tax laws, the Government fails miserably.

So does it score pathetically on the second test. Tax laws as written do not exclude the existence of arbitrariness. The opposite is true. Arbitrariness figures prominently in, first, the letter of the law and, second, in the spirit of tax laws as both practised and interpreted by the Commissioner and his now well and truly captive Treasurer. The same can be said on the count of prerogative. To the extent that prerogative in this context may differ from arbitrariness, the end result is that as far as the observance of the criterion applies, the Government once again plumbs the depths.

Overwhelmingly, the worst aspect of tax laws in Australia today is the wide discretionary powers and authority conferred by the Keating-Hawke Government on the Commissioner of Taxation who, in true Yes, Minister tradition, has abrogated his power and responsibility to the Treasurer.

The Treasurer has never, in fairness to him, claimed to know much about the detail of the tax Bills given to him by the Commissioner; nor has he cared much about how those laws are being administered. As the member for Manhattan, the Treasurer is more likely to be away in space, more concerned with jargon and mesmerising talk about macro-economics and the price of Italian suit cloth than with the tedious detail of tax laws for which he accepts only nominal responsibility. If it were possible to hand out minus scores the Keating-Hawke Government would qualify for one on the test of the absolute supremacy of regular law, which must logically exclude the existence of wide discretionary power exercised as it is by this Government.

In summary, the government's commitment to rule of law in tax matters is dismal. It does not even pay lip service to the principle of supremacy or predominance of regular law. The essence of this fundamental abrogation of duty is to be found in the discretionary power of the Commissioner, the power he insists upon having and is given, as well as in the Nelson of Trafalgar treatment whereby the Government turns a blind eye to the day to day administration of tax matters by the Commissioner.

The Institute of Chartered Accountants in Australia, the Confederation of Australian Industry and the Law Council of Australia are numbered among those representative bodies which felt the need to criticise, publicly, the administration and oversight of laws by the Australian Taxation Office in recent times. One matter stands out like a lighthouse in the debate on the administration of tax law in Australia. It is that very few individuals will make their criticisms in public. I suspect that that may encourage the Commissioner and his captive Treasurer, given the superior propaganda apparatus at their disposal. Even members of this Parliament, who are usually fearless in representing their constituencies and constituents, are loath to express concerns. It is not as if they are unaware of abuses by the ATO of the principles of the rule of law or of intimidation of taxpayers by some ATO staff, because many have indicated to me in private that they know of many such examples. Therefore, it is possible to conclude that even individual members of Parliament can be intimidated, because they know only too well that they could be subjected to the same pressures that individual taxpayers now have to endure.

The Treasurer does not have to worry, nor does the honourable member for Fremantle (Mr Dawkins); their tax problems have been settled favourably and amicably enough. But that is not true for far too many Australian taxpayers who cannot expect privileged treatment as can those two gentlemen. Until laws meet the stipulations of Dicey and there is absolute primacy of regular law, the potential for corruption of the principle of law in both administration and the statutes themselves will be realised. It is about time the Treasurer accepted his responsibility and stopped hiding behind the Commissioner of Taxation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hewson Dr J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pleasure for me to have the opportunity today to speak on the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) and cognate Bills. I would like to begin by congratulating the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) on what I thought was an excellent speech. Some of the points he made about the extended discretion under the Income Tax Assessment Act and the abuse and use of that discretion, I think will probably turn out to be a major issue in this country in the course of the next 12 months, if not, indeed, an election issue.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to preface my remarks today by commenting on what the Treasurer (Mr Keating) said on the subject of tax last Monday when he was attempting to bucket Terry McCrann for his article in the Melbourne Herald of that day entitled `The great tax grab'. For some reason I was reminded of Richard Nixon and Watergate as I listened to the Treasurer respond to the McCrann allegations. Honourable members might recall the classic account of the Watergate saga by Carl Bernstein and Bob Woodward of the Washington Post in a book entitled All the President's Men. Honourable members might also remember what kept Bernstein and Woodward going in their hot pursuit of the Watergate truths. It was the realisation of the phenomenon called `non-denial denials'. They soon realised in their search for circumstances that many people who commented on events in the White House or in relation to the Watergate break-in never actually denied key facts or developments; they always appeared to deny key facts or developments. It was always that non-denial denial phenomenon that kept them going.

So it was with the Treasurer and his attack on Terry McCrann. His attack was singularly distinguished by that non-denial denial-as it always is with this treasurer when he answers allegations in the area of tax. For example, if we suggest to him that the Hawke Government is the biggest taxing Government in our history, we will get a non-denial denial. If we say that he and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke)-as McCrann did-have been cheating the nation of income, we will get a non-denial denial. If we suggest that when it comes to tax he and the Prime Minister have been mugging Middle Australia, we will get another non-denial denial.

The simple fact is that the Treasurer shows an acute sensitivity when it comes to his own record on taxation. And so he should. He clearly showed an acute sensitivity to Terry McCrann. One might readily conclude from his remarks that he does not particularly like Mr McCrann. The simple fact is that Terry McCrann is one of the few journalists in this country who have failed to succumb to the incredible bullying tactics that this Treasurer is noted for using in relation to the media.

The full extent of the Treasurer's own paranoia and dementia in relation to Terry McCrann was evidenced by his boast in the House last Monday when he referred to a luncheon conversation he had earlier this year with McCrann when he claims to have said:
Listen, Terry, before you open your mouth, let me make this point: you are a marked man; you are a Liberal; you support the Liberal Party.

Thank God that Terry McCrann was not from the Left or, in fact, with the Prime Minister; because we can imagine what the Treasurer might have said in those circumstances. Having been on the receiving end myself of some of the Treasurer's pressure on the media in my days as a columnist, I can vouch for the fact that if the Treasurer decides to bucket someone then that person is probably doing a very good job, probably scoring a lot of very good points and being very successful. The Treasurer sets out to even the score.

What did McCrann say that offended the Treasurer? He really stated a whole lot of facts. I will put a few of them on the record. Firstly, he said that fiscal drag or bracket creep is now pumping-in McCrann's estimate-about an extra $8 billion per annum into the Canberra coffers compared with 1982-83. Secondly, he said that there were more than two million taxpayers who have been pushed into the two top tax brackets since 1982-83. He said that by the close of this financial year, one million more taxpayers will be in the top tax bracket. Thirdly, he said that even some taxpayers who are below average weekly earnings are now in the second highest tax bracket, facing 41 1/4 per cent tax on every extra dollar that they earn. It is no wonder that Terry McCrann called his article `The great tax grab'. These points are made quite clearly by McCrann recognising that this ever-rising tax grab has happened despite two rounds of so-called tax cuts by this Government.

The facts are really simple. While the Treasurer set out to try to destroy and demolish McCrann and his arguments and to create the impression in this House that he was indeed answering the thrust of McCrann's arguments, the reality was very different. The Treasurer really only attacked the periphery. His statement, as I have said is so often the case in relation to taxation, was simply a non-denial. The fact is that while some technocrats might debate the elements of McCrann's calculations, he was substantially right. The Treasurer has clearly been stung. The world's greatest tax reformer has been unmasked.

I will put four fundamental questions in relation to tax and deal with each of those. First, how can the Treasurer deny that tax burdens have increased under the Hawke Government? His usual non-denial-on this it takes a particular form-is to the effect that total revenue has fallen as a percentage of gross domestic product (GDP) from its peak of 28 per cent in 1986-87 to an estimated 27.3 per cent in 1988-89. It sounds good, does it not? However, it is a fudge. It is a fudging of an argument. I ask honourable members to ask themselves why the Treasurer took total revenue and not tax revenue in that sort of calculation. The answer is that non-tax revenue has declined dramatically, particularly because of the profit take of the Reserve Bank of Australia. The simple fact is that tax revenue, as a proportion of GDP, in 1988-89 is still projected to be 25.7 per cent, the same as last year. This is the second year in a row in which we have had a peacetime tax record. I suggest that the Treasurer's sensitivity reveals the fact that he has been hoist with his own petard.

The second proposition I put to the House is: How can the Treasurer deny that bracket creep has been significant? His usual non-denial denial here is as follows. As he has said on one occasion in 1988-89 bracket creep is only about $1.5 billion, which will be more than offset by cuts in indirect tax, reduced company tax, lower tariffs reductions and lower Reserve Bank of Australia profits worth about $3 billion. I make several comments on that non-denial denial. The first is that the Treasurer's estimate of bracket creep is probably an understatement of the cost of indexing the tax scales for one year only. But as McCrann correctly points out, fiscal drag cumulates too. As I have sought to emphasise on a number of occasions, using some estimates provided by Access Economics, bracket creep in 1988-89 has cumulated to about $7 billion. It will rise to about $10 billion next year. These estimates are being particularly generous to the Treasurer because scales have been indexed only from 1986-87 onwards so as to preserve the 1985-86 tax cuts that the Treasurer announced at that time.

The second point that I would make about this non-denial denial is that the cuts in company taxation and Reserve Bank profits to which the Treasurer refers have nothing to do with take-home pay. This is clearly just a furphy to distract attention from true argument underlying bracket creep. Similarly, the reference to tariff cuts in the same vein is misdirected. Tariff cuts have hardly flowed through to the consumer at all, if indeed they ever will given the uncompetitive nature of many of our import competing industries. Clearly, this is just another non-denial denial. There is absolutely no substance to the Treasurer's argument usually raised in response to the second proposition that I have identified.

My third proposition is: How can the Treasurer deny that his Budget surplus, the one he has lauded all over the world, stands as monument to bracket creep and to the mugging of Middle Australia? His usual non-denial denial in regard to this particular proposition is generally in the following terms. I quote an oft-repeated example, most recently used in this speech to the British-Australian Chamber of Commerce in London on 11 October when he said:
. . . move into surplus was not achieved as a result of revenue increases. It has come entirely from outlays reduction.

That statement is blatantly false. It is blatantly dishonest. The Treasurer works on the Goebbels propaganda principle that even if something is completely wrong, if one repeats it often enough most of the media and everybody else will pick it up and ultimately become quite familiar with the idea and accept it. That is backed up, of course, in the case of the media, with the usual dose of Keating influence.

My final proposition is: How can the Treasurer deny that the average Australian is really hurting under the increased tax burdens of the Hawke Government? The truth is that he does not try to deny this; he simply never addresses it. He simply never deals with the sorts of sums and figures that we have released on the impact of increased taxation on the average Australian. For example, a single person on average weekly earnings in March 1983 had an average tax rate of 22.9 per cent, faced a marginal tax rate of 30 per cent and paid $85 a week in tax. Today the same person would face a 25.1 per cent average tax rate, a 40 per cent marginal rate and pay a whopping $143.30 in tax. Similarly, a single income family on average weekly earnings paid an average tax rate in March 1983 of 17.5 per cent, its marginal tax rate was 30 per cent, and it paid only $65 tax a week. But today its average tax rate is 21.6 per cent, its marginal tax rate is again 40 per cent, and it is paying a whopping $123.60 in tax. I find it interesting that the Treasurer chooses not to address those arguments, because they are pretty persuasive.

Similarly persuasive is the argument we have developed about the extent to which the standard of living of the average Australian has fallen, essentially because of the Government's tax take since 1982-83. We have suggested it would take $56 a week to compensate the average Australian for the fall in the standard of living as a result of taxation, the Medicare levy and so on. If we want to get a true picture, we have to add increased housing costs, which would probably be another $14 a week for the average Australian. There has been a significant fall in the standard of living of the average Australian under this Government.

Another way of looking at this is to look at the Government's tax record. These are not the sorts of calculations that the Treasurer likes. For example, total income tax on individuals since 1982-83, including this year, shows a 63.7 per cent increase. Inflation over the same period has gone up by only 43.5 per cent. That makes a pretty persuasive point in relation to bracket creep. Company tax over that period has gone up by 67.7 per cent, total income tax has gone up by 68.5 per cent and sales tax-remember the man who was not going to broaden the sales tax base, not going to change the incidence of sales tax, and abandoned the idea of any of these sorts of things-by 103.8 per cent over the life of this Government, 2 1/2 times the rate of inflation, a staggering increase, and total tax revenue by 56.5 per cent.

I come finally to the promised tax cuts for next year. This is an area where, I suggest, the world's greatest Treasurer has no credibility. There have been so many confusing statements and inconsistent remarks by so many people involved at all levels of this corporatist Government from the union movement, through some of the Ministers to the Treasurer himself, that the average Australian is left in a totally confused state as to what is going to happen next year. Interestingly, when the Treasurer went out of the country, going back to my Watergate example, the Deep Throats came into play in Australia. Senator Walsh and Senator Button are two perfect examples of Deep Throats in the area of the tax debate. They have done what they can to set the record straight against the inflationary rhetoric of this Treasurer and his Prime Minister. Senator Walsh started to down play expectations by drawing attention to what he called our vulnerability. He expressed his concern over the balance of payments figures for the first two months of this financial year and he painted what he called the `worst case scenario', that is, if the current account deficit continued to run at much higher levels than had been expected, which would call for `doing something further on the outlay side', and, by implication, put the tax cuts at risk. Today's balance of payments number nearly another $1 billion and significantly continues the trend we have seen in the first couple of months. Over the last six months there has been a fundamental weakness in our balance of payments. The current account deficit on that basis is running at an annual rate of about $12.5 billion to $13 billion a year. Senator Walsh, however, was not alone. He was followed by Senator Button, who said:
Some people have talked enormous figures in terms of tax cuts. I don't think they are affordable. I mean, we are really not in a position where we can indulge ourselves too much at the present time.

Given the way this Government runs its macro-economic strategy, he is dead right. It has not been prepared to cut government expenditure, so it would get itself into an awful mess if it were to move in the current circumstances. Just about everybody else has got in for their chop since that situation was created by Senator Walsh and Senator Button. We are all left with virtually no idea about what size tax cuts we will get next year, what the tax cuts depend on, where they will be concentrated and whether they will be phased in over one or two years or more.

Yesterday, in an effort at damage control, the Prime Minister put a gag on his Ministers talking about tax, except for himself and the Treasurer. I suggest to the Prime Minister that he should put a gag on the Treasurer, because he seems to be as confused as everybody else when it comes to tax. Look at his record in terms of statements over the last few months. At Budget time he spoke of substantial tax cuts, conditional then on wages outcomes in 1988-89 and the wage tax trade-off to be struck next year with the union movement. Then the Treasurer, with his usual degree of modesty, more recently said:
Next year's tax cuts will still go ahead even if Australia's trade performance suffers as a result of slower world economic growth forecasts. . .
I don't see a slowing by any margin that would complicate that-our trade performance.
The Government will handle all that-next year's wage tax trade-off-with due aplomb and skill.
As I said, a fairly modest statement from the Treasurer. Not long after that statement Mr Keating softened his line, and an article in the Australian Financial Review of 13 October stated:

Mr Keating appeared also to soften slightly the Government's commitment to tax cuts next July, answering only `I think so' when asked whether they would still go ahead despite poor current account figures . . .
Yesterday in Parliament he made the tax cuts explicitly conditional on economic circumstances next year when he said:

. . . in considering the magnitude and quality of such a tax trade-off we would need to see what wage outcomes were in this financial year and also look at the quality of such a trade-off in demand terms for the economy over the ensuing year. Those judgments will best be made some months away. On the basis of the Government's expressed view about this in the Budget, there is no point now, and one cannot possibly assess the macro-economic conditions which will obtain at the time such a tax cut would be negotiated.

At the time of the Budget he was linking tax cuts only to the wage outcomes in 1988-89 and to the nature of the trade-off between tax and wages struck next year. As of yesterday he had broadened that to include economic circumstances in the middle of the year, consistent with what had been a softening of his position on the commitment made on tax cuts. Yet today I read, just before coming into the House, that he has apparently now said that he will pay the tax cuts all in the one hit next year, without giving any indication as to what they will be. But he still raises the possibility that the top rate can be phased down. In fact he was quite explicit, in the quote I saw, in saying that this has been his position for some time.

I put it to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that the most amazing situation has now developed in one of the most important areas, and that is the area of income tax. The tax cuts that have been promised to the people of Australia, who have suffered a significant decline in their standard of living under this Government, are now no clearer. There is no firmer commitment than there was when this idea was floated some months ago. The average Australian is still left totally in doubt as to whether he will get the tax cuts given the likely trend in the balance of payments over the coming months.

I was interested today to see with the balance payments number that the Government now has to achieve balance payments deficits on average, in each of the next nine months of this year, of about $628m per month. Since early 1985, when we had that exchange rate crisis, I think there have been only three months when the monthly balance of payments deficit number was below $628m, and that was during a period which had seen very favourable commodity prices. I suggest that the balance of payments is a fundamental structural weakness and that our tax cuts are therefore clearly at risk.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am privileged to follow the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson) whose technical knowledge of the issues, I would suggest, is unsurpassed in this House, a point which I think the Treasurer (Mr Keating) will increasingly discover over the months to come.

SPEECH.PARA: In addressing the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) and cognate Bills this evening I would like to take the opportunity of highlighting three attributes of the Hawke-Keating Government's approach to economic management, and in particular its taxation record since 1983. I regret to say that some of these attributes were reflected once again in this place during Question Time this afternoon. What are those attributes? The first one is an attribute of arrogance, clearly demonstrated by the Treasurer during his recent overseas trip when he lectured major powers on the need to do better, whereas clearly he should have restricted his comments to the domestic problems that we have at the moment. The second attribute is one of aloofness. The Hawke-Keating Government has lost touch with the ordinary people and, in particular, is preoccupied with big business. We only have to look at the 12 per cent swing in the Oxley by-election on 8 October to be reminded of what I am saying.

The Government has forgotten about the pensioners. I thought that last evening the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) gave an eloquent dissertation on the problems for those pensioners. It has forgotten about small business and, very importantly, it has forgotten about the pay as you earn (PAYE) taxpayer. The third attribute is immorality, particularly in respect of its high taxing regime. It is not allowing the Australian people the benefits of personal income tax reductions now but rather holding them up as a blatant political carrot for the next general election, whether it be late next year or early in 1990. If it occurs, I hope that it is seen exactly for what it is. It will be a crass, opportunistic ballot box bribe.

I draw particular attention to six major points germane to the Treasurer's projected $5.5 billion surplus in 1988-89. The first point is that tax, as a proportion of gross domestic product (GDP), is estimated at 25.7 per cent in 1988-89. Of course, that maintains last year's record peacetime level. I point out that, under the previous coalition government, the ratio average was about 3 per cent less than that. The second point is that PAYE tax receipts will rise by 13.8 per cent or $4.3 billion to $35.2 billion, with total individual tax receipts, including the Medicare levy and prescribed payments system, rising by 13.6 per cent or $5.7 billion to $47.6 billion. Of course, the provisional tax uplift factor has been increased by 1 per cent to 12 per cent, even though inflation is officially expected to fall over the year. The third point is that income tax receipts, as a proportion of total revenue, will increase from 51.7 per cent in 1987-88 to 54.3 per cent in 1988-89. My fourth point is that the Treasurer has tried to muddy the waters claiming that total revenue as a proportion of GDP has fallen from a peak of 28 per cent of GDP in 1986-87 to an estimated 27.3 per cent in 1988-89, whereas this ratio, which includes non-tax receipts, has fallen because non-tax revenue has fallen, principally in the area of Reserve Bank of Australia profits, which are down $1 billion on 1987-88.

My fifth point is that the Treasurer also claims, as the honourable member for Wentworth indicated, that bracket creep in 1988-89 will be only $1.5 billion which is more than offset by cuts in indirect taxes, reduced company tax and tariff reductions and lower Reserve Bank profits worth $3 billion. Finally, my sixth point is that since 1983 Labor has increased its tax take from superannuation by 1,000 per cent. In other words, the Treasurer has taxed the shirts off all Australians and is now promising, with some qualification subject to the vagaries of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, to give back the buttons in 12 months' time. I agree entirely with what the honourable member for Barker (Mr Porter) had to say in this place earlier this afternoon about `the insatiable greed' of the Hawke-Keating Government. Furthermore, there is a persuasive statistical argument that Australia is now in the hands of international bankers. I exemplify that by pointing out that in 1977 gross foreign debt, as a proportion of GDP, was 4.4 per cent. In 1983 that had climbed to 13.5 per cent. In the financial year 1987-88 it had escalated to $115 billion or by in the region of 32 per cent.

This evening I would also like to make a comment on the administration of the taxation system, its complicated legislative framework and, in particular, the provocative role that the Commissioner of Taxation, Mr Trevor Boucher, is playing in the administrative processes. Of course, this factor was referred to in this place last evening by the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) and earlier this evening by the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher). What did the Treasurer have to say about the tax system? Late last month he said:

. . . the Government has given Australia a decent tax system for the first time ever and is now going to be polluted by an attempt by lesser people to intimidate the Tax Commissioner in the carrying out of his statutory responsibilities. I have told the Commissioner to come down like a ton of bricks on companies and institutions which rort the system.
Of course, in the process he accused some of the business leaders of what he termed a `lurk' mentality. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) on that point said:
I am all in favour of stamping out rorts and evasion and any decent citizen and any honest businessman should support any government that does that.
He went on to talk about the atmospherics being created and said:

This idea that you smear everybody with the sins of a few and create a climate of hostility towards sections of the business community is quite ridiculous. The rhetoric of Mr Keating's remarks and the Commissioner's are creating that atmosphere. I am objecting to the impression being created that the law will be what the Commission decides it to be as distinct from what in reality it is.

Other people have spoken of Mr Boucher's attitude. In particular, I draw the House's attention to the Chief Executive of the Confederation of Australian Industry, Mr Darryl George, who last month said:

It appears the Commissioner is moving into areas beyond artificial schemes. We are simply supporting the right of people to optimise their total net income, provided this is strictly within their law.
Mr Martin Souter said:
The Tax Commissioner appears not to recognise that there can be any tax minimisation through legitimate application of the law. Companies must aim to minimise tax, not to maximise it.
Moving on to the Law Council of Australia, the President, Mr Denis Byrne, also referred to Mr Boucher in the following terms:
. . . an over-zealous official pursuing a crusade collecting revenue according to his own standards of fairness instead of according to the law.
He was doubly disturbed that the Treasurer had come out publicly in support of Mr Boucher. He went on to say:

The views of Mr Boucher and Mr Keating that there is something wrong in a taxpayer arranging his or its affairs so as to minimise liability for tax fully deserves the condemnation they have received. It was for Parliament to determine the rules governing liability to tax and it was then for taxpayers to arrange their affairs with those rules in mind. Their responsibility is to comply with the law.
He went on to say:

Instead of exhorting people to pay their fair share of tax, Mr Boucher should give urgent consideration to the way his officers were conducting searches of solicitors' offices with scant regard for the professional privilege which attaches to documents held by them.

I think it is fair to say that business unease has been heightened by Tax Office raids in recent months on the offices of leading institutions, including Citibank in Sydney and the prestige law firm Allen Allen and Hemsley, prompting the Chairman of Western Mining Corporation Ltd, Sir Arvi Parbo, to comment:
To invade an office and break open the records and filing cabinets . . . it doesn't seem to fit our type of community.

As far as the professional groups are concerned, the normally conservative Australian Society of Accountants is accusing Mr Boucher of `scaremongering' and jeopardising the confidence and trust of the business community. Society President, Elizabeth Alexander, has said that the Tax Commissioner is creating unnecessary discord. She went on to say:

He seems to be suggesting that all taxpayers should organise their affairs to pay a maximum of tax, but every company has the right to arrange its affairs to pay the minimum of tax legally due. Maximising tax benefits may well be a vital means by which many Australian businesses become more viable and internationally competitive.

Furthermore, the Institute of Chartered Accountants says that Mr Boucher's attempts to make taxpayers bear the burden of establishing the spirit of the tax laws is ridiculously unfair. Of course, for their part the tax officials say that Mr Boucher really believes that he is doing the right thing for the right reasons, so the business community's criticism just bounces off him.

I remind the House that before Mr Boucher's appointment the Commissioner of Taxation had never really tested the limits of his powers. But now both business and the accounting industry are mortally afraid that he has become, to quote from the Australian Financial Review of 23 September, `the 800-pound gorilla who decides to sit where he likes'. I understand the alarm of the business community at what it seems as the Taxation Office's excessively hard line approach, which the Treasurer has supported. What has particularly angered business interests is the Tax Office statement that businesses that did not obey the spirit of the law would be prosecuted even though they might have obeyed the letter of the law. As both the Confederation of Australian Industry and the Business Council of Australia have pointed out, Australia's tax laws are confusing and cumbersome, with many grey areas that are open to interpretation by the taxpayer and by the Tax Commissioner. But when companies sought to interpret the law for themselves they were accused of being cheats or, in the Treasurer's words, of taking a `conceptually squalid' approach. I have no sympathy with companies that spend their time devising schemes, the aim of which is to exploit loop holes and minimise, if not flagrantly avoid, their share of taxation. But to tar all companies with that brush is grossly unfair. The fact is that the taxation laws need to be made clear and comprehensible so that there is no contradiction between the spirit and the letter of the law.

I would now like to draw the House's attention to one specific ruling affecting not just one group of constituents. It has far wider implications. It was referred to in this place earlier this afternoon by the honourable member for Fairfax (Mr Adermann). With the House's indulgence, I will read an excerpt from a letter that I received in July this year from a group. The letter states:

We have just learnt that the Commissioner of Taxation has ruled that donations to support the activities of Mobile Life Education Centres throughout Australia no longer qualify for income tax deductions under subparagraph 78 (1) (a) (ii) of the Income Tax Assessment Act. These centres exist due to public demand for specialised educational programs to prepare our children to resist drug abuse and so build a happier and healthier Australia. The whole purpose of the centres is to prevent drug abuse rather than to spend scarce resources on the very lengthy and costly process of rehabilitation. Ironically, funds spent after a drug problem has been created are still tax deductible. The ruling of the Tax Commissioner goes against the well accepted fact that `prevention is better than the cure'. Currently life education centres in Queensland receive only $63,270 from the State Government. The rest of the funds necessary to educate and help our children to resist drug abuse comes from the people of Queensland who until this ruling had some taxation relief for their urgently needed donations.
I wrote to the Treasurer in August. On 19 September I received a reply from the Minister Assisting the Treasurer (Mr Peter Morris). The letter stated, inter alia:

The Commissioner of Taxation confirmed that for donations to mobile life education centres to be deductible, it is necessary that the latter meet the description of a public benevolent institution. Although the phrase public benevolent institution does not have a statutory definition, it is generally understood to be an institution for the relief of poverty, sickness, suffering, distress, destitution, misfortune and helplessness. Public benevolent institutions have, as a common feature, the giving of relief freely to those who are in need of it and are unable to care for themselves.
. . . Consequently, the Commissioner concluded by saying that gifts to such centres do not qualify for deduction under the existing provisions of the Act.

In the last few days I have written back to Minister Morris expressing my disappointment at this overly legalistic approach. I hope that in the fullness of time, as the Treasurer said in the House this afternoon, that will be reconsidered.

In summary, the Treasurer asserts that many companies and individuals are rorting the tax system. I have to say that some are. None of us should condone this. More importantly, the Treasurer is deceiving the Australian people by not allowing personal income tax cuts and by allowing tax revenue, particularly from pay as you earn taxpayers, to build up by over $4 billion in the financial year 1988-89. He is clearly using the Australian people as the tax scapegoat to set the scene for a general election some time next year or in 1990. Furthermore, he is using officers of the Australian Taxation Office-notably Mr Boucher-to push his fixation with increased revenue as part of his strategy of a `taxing surplus' as distinct from an `axing surplus'. I therefore hope that Mr Boucher will temper his public views and that in tax matters the Government will think a little more about Mr and Mrs Average Australian rather than its big business mates. In particular, there should be a more sympathetic interpretation of a `public benevolent institution' in so far as it affects such irreplaceable association as the life education centres, without which the youth of our great nation would not be prepared for the drug and alcohol abuse so inherent in society. I hope that Ministers Keating and Morris will heed this call.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable members who participated in the debate last evening and today. I refer briefly to the second reading amendment moved by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock). The amendment to the motion for the second reading questions the raising of the uplift factor for calculating 1988-89 provisional tax. The level of the factor will be 12 per cent. The uplift factor is intended to ensure that the provisional tax payable in respect of the income of the year of income will approximate the tax ultimately payable in respect of that income and the uplift factor has regard to the expected movement in property incomes and incomes in the unincorporated business sector. An uplift factor of 11 per cent was used for calculating 1987-88 provisional tax. Ultimately, the actual movement in taxable incomes of provisional taxpayers for that year was higher. The estimated movement of incomes for provisional taxpayers for 1988-89 indicates a movement higher than 11 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: Separately, the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) criticised the removal of the 5:3 depreciation concession and he indicated that the decision will increase the cost of capital for small business. Again I say that the Government was concerned that the 5:3 depreciation provided investors in certain plant and equipment with a significant tax deferral benefit and that this benefit resulted in a substantial and increasing cost to revenue. It also found that the existing accelerated depreciation concessions led to a distortion in investment decisions and that they gave greater tax benefits for investment in long lived assets relative to short lived assets. The new effective life system with a 20 per cent loading will provide a tax benefit to investment in all plant and equipment. It will also remove the distortion to investment in long lived assets.

I refer to the matter raised by the honourable gentleman who has just resumed his seat, the honourable member for Groom (Mr Taylor) in respect of the representations made to the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and to myself and referred to by the Treasurer in Question Time today. Obviously, the Treasurer made it clear that he was prepared to review the matter and look at it in light of all the other circumstances involved. Therefore, I do not want to say any more about that at this stage than just to recognise that the matter has been raised. I believe it does not contribute anything to public debate to have the kind of attack that we have heard in this Chamber, not only from the last speaker but also from earlier speakers, on the Commissioner of Taxation. Honourable members on the other side of the House, particularly the Deputy Leader of the Opposition and those on this side know very well that public officials are charged with public duties. Parliament legislates in respect of those duties and, put simply, those officials are in the position of being damned if they do and damned if they don't.

Considerable public consultancy work has been carried out by the Australian Taxation Office, its officers, regional managers, deputy commissioners and assistant commissioners participating in business forums and public forums to ensure as far as possible that the changes that have been made in taxation law in recent years are known as widely as possible around Australia. Even commencing that task is almost a superhuman task but that action has been taken and I am sure that honourable members in this chamber are aware of the efforts being made. I have read many of the press reports in respect of that action but to assault in this place the official charged with the responsibility does not achieve anything, and I refer particularly to some of the concluding remarks of the honourable gentleman who resumed his seat a few moments ago.

I do not want to say any more about it than that. I was thinking of saying more but this issue has been raised by people on either side of the chamber on past occasions. There are proper ways, if an honourable member feels that a genuine grievance has occurred in respect of a constituent or a company or business, to raise the matter. I see some of those coming through in my correspondence and I reply to some of them. I am sure that if they were brought to the attention of the Taxation Commissioner himself, he, similarly, would want to see that the proper and courteous consideration were given to those representations and to anything that somebody may feel should not have occurred in the manner of conduct.

Two other matters were mentioned also-that of Citibank and Allen Allen and Hemsley. Again I do not want to comment on those because both of those cases are subject to current appeal proceedings and there has been some publicity about them. I think they have been dealt with and court decisions have been taken.
In conclusion, I thank the honourable members who have participated in the debate for the contributions they have made. I commend the Bill to the House and reject the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 13, page 13, lines 31 and 32, omit ``4 February 1985'', substitute ``31 August 1988''.
(2) Clause 24, page 20, line 7, omit ``after 31 August 1988''.

The amendments that I have moved to clauses 13 and 24 of this Bill were foreshadowed in my speech in the second reading debate. As I said then, we are attempting to stop what the Opposition considers a gross case of retrospective abuse. The substance of clauses 13 and 24 deals with the introduction of a tax on non-cash business benefits. This was prompted by the opening of an apparent loophole since a Federal Court decision held that existing law takes non-cash business benefits only if the benefits are convertible to cash and are in the nature of income according to ordinary concepts. Where a benefit is not convertible to cash, it is not presently subject to tax under any provision of the law.

The Opposition has no objection to the substance of the legislation. What it does object to, however, is the outrageous attempt to retrospectively apply the legislation to a date 3 1/2 years ago. I spoke on this matter at great length last night in the second reading debate, so I do not want to cover it in the same detail as I did then. But this proposal is bringing government by press releases to ludicrous heights. We therefore believe that it would be extremely inequitable for the legislation to apply retrospectively.

Clause 13 should apply only to benefits provided on or after the day of introduction of this Bill-that is, 31 August 1988. As I noted in my speech during the second reading debate, the press release did not give taxpayers much indication of how affected benefits would be valued. The announcement stated:
As a general rule the value to be taxed will be the amount which the benefit would have cost the taxpayers in an arm's length transaction.
Undoubtedly, taxpayers could reasonably have expected that detailed valuation rules would apply to the benefits from the date on which they were announced, certainly not some date 3 1/2 years ago.

Under the proposed legislation, benefits must be valued, broadly speaking, at the amount the recipient would have had to pay to obtain the benefit under an arm's length transaction. Therefore, to determine the taxable value of benefits received over the previous 3 1/2 years, taxpayers will have to ascertain the amount they would have had to pay to obtain those benefits at the time each benefit was granted. Unquestionably, administrative nightmares will abound.

Being late in the day, and so trenchant was I on this issue last night, I will not delay the Committee unnecessarily. I will more succinctly say that the Government and its Treasurer (Mr Keating) have a shameful record of government by press release. That record is an absolute insult to the Parliament. It is in fact a usurping of Parliament's primacy over the executive branch of Government. It is a sign of pathetic administration. We have had illustration after illustration of legislation being introduced six months, 12 months, 18 months and two years after press releases have been issued. But in this instance the period is 3 1/2 years. The Minister Assisting the Treasurer (Mr Peter Morris) will seek to say that the Opposition is taking an exaggerated view. I say to the Committee that there is no way from the general statement of a press release that one can interpret with accuracy the way in which the legislation is in fact provided for. It is grossly unfair to have to wait 3 1/2, having sought to make arrangements in that period.

When we went into opposition in March of 1983, I said to my shadow Cabinet that if there was any element of retrospectivity around, it would have to be washed out of our hair. I said that we would oppose the Government on every occasion that it sought to bring forward legislation which effectively acted retrospectively.

This enormous omnibus Bill contains many provisions. We will vote against the retrospective element in regard to non-convertible cash benefits because of the 3 1/2 year delay and the retrospectivity that is unquestionably present. I say to the Minister that it takes a touch of exquisite genius to wait 3 1/2 years to insert two pages of legislation in a large Bill such as this. We cannot in conscience let this go through without moving the amendment. Three and a half years to produce about two pages of legislation is a nonsense and we will not let it pass here unchallenged.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —As has been said by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) when moving the Opposition's amendment, the Government's announced intention to legislate for a new tax on certain non-cash benefits goes way back to February 1985. Here we are, over three and a half years later, being called on to pass an amendment to section 21a of the Act. In the interim, those taxpayers, who were always going to be affected, have proceeded out of commercial necessity to do business on their understanding of what the law was going to require. Of necessity, that understanding had to be gleaned from a press statement issued in February 1985. In taking the natural meaning of the words in that press statement, affected businesses took the usual precaution of obtaining professional advice, and offered incentives which they had every reason to believe would not incur to them or those given the incentives additional tax. In the event, they were unwise because the Treasurer (Mr Keating) was again about to show himself as not to be as good as his word.

SPEECH.PARA: Section 21a, as he proposes to see it, does not match the word of the Treasurer as he gave it in writing, by press release, on 4 February 1985. Those now to be saddled with a new impost were hoodwinked. They have been allowed to go their merry ways for more than three and a half years because the Treasurer is trying so hard to emulate his lame duck Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in breaking undertakings or promises. It bodes ill for the promised July 1989 tax cuts.

The example before us is the clearest yet of the malpractice of legislating by press release. It is an example of that unjust technique which the Law Council of Australia might have had in mind when it renewed its condemnation of the practice of the Federal Government known as `legislation by press release'. The Law Council reiterated its cogently argued concern as recently as 18 July 1988. Sadly, it is not a new practice. The Law Council in its statement reminded us of the words of the now Chief Justice Mason-then Mr Justice Mason of the High Court of Australia. In 1985, in condemning the practice of legislation by press release, he said.
There is, first, the risk that the proposed alteration will not be made by Parliament and there is, secondly, the possibility, sometimes unfortunately realised . . .
and this is one of those occasions:
. . . that the law when enacted will not correspond exactly with the antecedent announcement. Above all, it is a technique calculated to encourage people to disregard and, indeed, to disobey the law.

The last sentence has no relevance here but I thought I should quote it in full. It is the words `that the law when enacted will not correspond exactly with the antecedent announcement' that have application in this debate. Amended section 21a, as proposed by the Treasurer, will not `correspond exactly with the antecedent announcement'. Therein lies the reason for our amendment.

Given that the Government's amendment is not exactly the same as it described on 4 February 1985, the application of section 21a should have effect only from 31 August 1988-the latter date being the first on which the Treasurer's intentions were spelled out. In any other forum, the amendment moved by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition would be accepted. It is fair, just and reasonable. Regrettably, these are not virtues cherished by the Treasurer.

I have one other reservation about section 21a. Section 21a is designed to help attribute a taxable amount to a person who receives a non cash benefit of an income nature as a reward relating to some business dealing. It was inserted to overcome the decision in the Cooke and Sherden case whereby independent retailers of soft drinks were not assessable on the value of a holiday given to them by the manufacturer of drinks because of the achievement of a certain sales target. Broadly the section, as it is proposed, does what I would expect it to do. However, there is some suggestion that it interacts with section 51ak. Section 51ak denies a tax deduction to a person who incurs business expenditure to acquire property for a service and also receives a `sweetener' or incentive benefit for entering into the business. It seems to me, and certainly in the absence of anything said on behalf of the Government, it may be that the two proposed sections have no overlap. But particularly because section 51ak requires an agreement before it is operative whereas section 21a has no such requirement, there may be no overlap. I am not at all convinced that non cash business benefits would not be caught by both sections, thus effectively resulting in double taxation, and that is my concern. It seems to me that the law should make clear if it intends to allow such an overlap. That is my second quibble, if the Committee likes, with section 21a as proposed by the Treasurer. Otherwise, I simply reiterate my total support for the amendment moved by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition. He is on sound ground, both legally and, heaven forbid, morally. It is one that we should uphold and contest through the both Houses of Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I briefly endorse the intention of the Opposition on this issue of retrospectivity. The Government has adopted a practice that was instigated by the Opposition of a Treasurer making an announcement and at a later date legislating for those announced changes to tax law. But three and a half years is an intolerable time for that delay to take place. The community cannot operate in this way. This action is typical of the Treasurer and the way in which he has administered his portfolio. Even simple inquiries from honourable members failed to be acknowledged. The disdain and arrogance of the Treasurer with respect to the community at large are recognised in this Parliament and even more widely. Three and a half years retrospective legislation is not good enough. We are waiting, as I am reminded, for legislation to change the superannuation arrangements announced in the mini Budget. I do not know how much longer we will have to wait. Those people seeking to take up superannuation or adjust their arrangements are in a state of limbo. And it goes on and on, time and time again, where the Government slowly and retrospectively tells the community of its intentions. No doubt the same thing will apply to the market linked changes to investments for pensioners where there are consistent and long delays.

SPEECH.PARA: The community has been significantly damaged by the policies of this Government. Not only has the Government ripped off additional tax to the extent of $56 a week out of the pockets of the average Australian, but also is insult added to that injury of not taking people into the Government's confidence by stating its intentions. Press releases are too general for people to make decisions on. We have a rampant Commissioner of Taxation who runs wild, making interpretations on law and on press releases in such a way that the community is at a loss to know how to manage its own affairs. I just wish to reiterate my statement that the community will not tolerate these actions.

TALK.START.PARA: —The previous speaker, the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman), took a cheap shot at the attitude of the Treasurer (Mr Keating). I want to reject that. He also took a cheap shot at the Commissioner of Taxation. The Taxation Commissioner, as I said earlier, is carrying out his responsibilities under taxation law. It does not help the performance of public responsibility to receive that kind of cheap shot. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), said that it took an exquisite genius to be able to come back in 1988 and legislate for an announcement that was made in February 1985. Similarly, there was an exquisite piece of inaction on the part of those who sit opposite when back in 1980 the full Federal Court of Australia highlighted the substantive limiting factor in the tax law in holding that non-convertible non-cash benefits were not caught within the existing tax law. What did the then Government-the current Opposition-do about it? It did nothing. This Government, as part of cleaning up the mess left by the Opposition whilst in power, announced in February 1985 that these tax free arrangements should be taxed and should not be subsidised by the rest of the community.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not know what part of Australia honourable members opposite are moving around in but I can tell them about the very resounding message that is coming from the communities I move in: they want to see a fair tax system. They do not want a continuation of the rorts and the avoidance and the preferential treatment that those who now sit in Opposition practiced over the years. The Opposition can peddle its line, but what Australians want is a fair taxation system, not a tax system that is weighted against salary and wage earners.

I want to make it clear that since 1985, by various tax reform measures such as the fringe benefits tax, the capital gains tax, imputation and the foreign tax credits system, this Government has made the tax system fairer and more equitable for all Australians. It also has to be said that the vast tax reform work undertaken by Treasurer and Australian Taxation Office officials with the limited resources available has meant that some legislation has had to come later in the queue than other legislation. We accept that, accordingly, there has been a longer than usual delay between the announcement and the legislation. We do not think that because there has been a delay it can be said-as claimed by those opposite, particularly the Deputy Leader of the Opposition-that there is a retrospective application of this law. The Deputy Leader claimed that there was a lack of clarity in the announcement. He spent only six minutes speaking on it last night and he touched on it very briefly tonight. It is not clear from his statements, what aspects of the 1985 press release lack certainty. In that announcement the Treasurer provided a clear and comprehensive statement as to what arrangements were to be caught, what benefits were to be assessable, how to value them and who was to pay tax. I suggest to honourable members-without taking time now because we are into adjournment time-that if they read page 2 of that press release they will find it is set out quite clearly. If they cannot follow that, I think they are contriving not to understand it.

To ensure that the legislation contained in the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1988 has no element of retrospectivity, transitional provisions have been included in clause 54. The clause makes provisions in terms as contained in the 1985 announcement. It ensures that taxpayers will be assessed in those terms only in respect of non-cash benefits provided before 31 August 1988. The words and the language of clause 54 were drafted on the basis of the 1985 announcement so that no taxpayer could complain that the legislation now contains any new approach. The provisions of the other related clauses, 12 and 24, apply only after 31 August 1988. Clause 13 applies subject to the transitional provisions found in clause 54. The valuation rule contained in clause 13 is the same valuation basis mentioned in the press release-the arm's length value of the benefit. No new valuation rule has been included in this legislation. There is no retrospectivity in this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course there is.
—We had a public announcement telling people what was to be legislated. That announcement and that undertaking are being carried forward.
—Look at the Bill.

—The honourable member can dispute that, but I will come to it in a moment. I have already explained it to him. If he does not want to accept that, that is his decision. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition also suggested that the proposed legislation would double tax on non-cash benefits when received by employees. That is clearly incorrect. Section 23l of the Income Tax Assessment Act removes the possibility of any double taxation of a benefit received by an employee. Where a taxpayer derives a fringe benefit within the meaning of the fringe benefits legislation, the benefit is exempt income under the Income Tax Assessment Act. I want to emphasise that the advice I have is that since 1985 the professional taxation journals have highlighted the proposed non-cash legislation as being outstanding. When it was introduced into this House it did not surprise taxpayers or their advisers. We on this side of the House believe that the Opposition, in proposing this amendment, is again acting on behalf of a minority who claim that they were not aware of what was going to happen or on behalf of some who may have been aware but are seeking to avoid paying their fair share of taxes. In effect, that means that honest taxpayers are required to continue to subsidise those whose revenue has been forgone.
—We are not disagreeing with the principle. We are disagreeing with the date.

—It is not retrospective. The honourable member read the statement. He is an intelligent, very able politician and a very able former Minister. I defy anybody to convince me that he could not understand what that means when the provisions in the statement have virtually been written into the clauses of the Bill. It may make people unhappy that eventually it is coming through, but the Government made the announcement. There has been no representation that further advice should be sought. In those circumstances, the Government has no alternative but to reject the amendment.

It represents a deprivation of the aged, the sick and the poor in this country of the provision of adequate medical care and a continuation by the Opposition of its support for the strongest trade union in this country, the Australian Medical Association, and the denial of assistance and medical care to the aged and to the sick.
